div1.head: παρρησιαστής
div1.sense: a free speaker, Arist.

div1.head: παρρησιαστικός
div1.sense: freespoken, Arist.

div1.head: παρυφαίνω
div1.sense: to furnish with a hem or border (παρυφή) :—ὅπλα παρυφασμένα armed men hemming in an unarmed crowd, Xen.

div1.head: παρυφή
div1.sense: a border woven along a robe, Lat. clavus.

div1.head: πάρφυκτος
div1.sense: to be avoided, Pind.

div1.head: παρῳδία
div1.sense: a song or poem in which serious words become burlesque, a burlesque, parody, Arist.

div1.head: παρῳδός
div1.sense: singing indirectly, obscurely hinting, Eur.

div1.head: παρωθέω
div1.sense: to push aside, reject, slight, Soph., Eur.:—Pass. to be set aside, slighted, Xen., Dem.
Mid. to push away from oneself, reject, renounce, Eur., Aeschin.
of Time, to put off, Plat.

div1.head: παρωκεάνιος
div1.sense: near or on the ocean, Plut.

div1.head: παρώμαλος
div1.sense: nearly even or equal, Strab.

div1.head: παρωνύμιος
div1.sense: = παρ-ώνῠμος, Plat.
as Subst., παρωνύμιον, ου, a derivative, Plat.
a surname, Plut.

div1.head: παρώνυμος
div1.sense: formed by a slight change, derivative, Aesch.

div1.head: παρώρεια
div1.sense: a district on the side of a mountain, Polyb.

div1.head: παρωρείτης
div1.sense: a mountaineer, Anth.

div1.head: πάρωρος
div1.sense: out of season, untimely: neut. πάρωρα as adv., Anth.

div1.head: παρωροφίς
div1.sense: the projecting eaves or cornice of a roof, Hdt.

div1.head: πασιμέλουσα
div1.sense: of the ship Argo, a care to all, i. e. known to all, Od.

div1.head: πασπάλη
div1.sense: the finest meal: metaph., ὕπνου οὐδὲ πασπάλη not a morsel of sleep, Ar.

div1.head: πᾶς
div1.sense: Lat. omnis, all, when used of many; when of one only, all, the whole:
in pl. all, πάντες τε θεοὶ πᾶσαί τε θέαιναι Il.; τῶν Σαμίων πάντες Thuc.; ἅμα πάντες, πάντες ἅμα all together, Il., etc.
with a Sup., πάντες ἄριστοι all the noblest, Lat. optimus quisque, Hom.
all, the whole, πᾶσα ἀλήθεια all the truth, Il.; χαλκέη πᾶσα all of bronze, Hdt.; ἦν ἡ μάχη ἐν χερσὶ πᾶσα all hand to hand, Thuc.; ἡ πᾶσα βλάβη nothing but mischief, Soph.
= ἕκαστος, every, Hom., etc.; πᾶς χώρει let everyone go, Ar.:—also, πᾶς ἀνήρ Soph., etc.; πᾶς τις every single one, Hdt., etc.; πᾶς ὅστις . . Soph.; πᾶν ὅσον Aesch., etc.
When the Art. is used, it is generally put after πᾶς, πᾶσαν τὴν δύναμιν all his force, Hdt.; πᾶσαν τὴν ἀλήθειαν Thuc.
πᾶς is put between the Art. and Subst., to denote totality, ὁ πᾶς ἀριθμός Aesch.; τὸ πᾶν πλῆθος Thuc.
as a Subst., τὸ πᾶν the whole, Aesch.; τὰ πάντα the whole, Aesch.
With Numerals it marks an exact number, ἐννέα πάντες quite nine, full nine, no less, Od.; δέκα πάντα τάλαντα Il.; but, κτήνεα τὰ θύσιμα πάντα τρισχίλια ἔθυσε 3000 of all kinds, Hdt.
with the Article, in all, οἱ πάντες εἷς καὶ ἐννενήκοντα Hdt.
Special Usages:—in dat. pl. masc. πᾶσι, with or in the judgment of all, Il., Soph.
πᾶσι as neut., in all things, altogether, Soph.
πάντα γίγνεσθαι to become all things, i. e. assume every shape, Od.; εἰς πᾶν ἀφικνεῖσθαι to venture everything, Xen.
πάντα εἶναί τινι to be everything to one, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
πάντα as adv. for πάντως, in all points, entirely, wholly, Od., Soph., etc.:—but, τὰ πάντα in every way, by all means, altogether, Hdt.
neut. sg. τὸ πᾶν the whole, oneʼs all, περὶ τοῦ παντὸς δρόμον θέειν Hdt.; τοῦ π. ἐλλείπειν Aesch.: — τὸ πᾶν as adv., on the whole, altogether, Soph., etc.; with a negat. at all, Aesch.
πᾶν everything, anything, πᾶν μᾶλλον ἢ στρατιήν anything rather than an army, Hdt.; πᾶν ποιῶν by any means whatever, Plat.; so, πάντα ποιῶν Dem.
ἐπὶ πᾶν on the whole, in general, generally, Plat.
παντὸς μᾶλλον above all, absolutely, necessarily, Lat. ita ut nihil supra, Plat.:—in answers, π. γε μᾶλλον yes, absolutely so, Plat.

with Preps., ἐς πᾶν κακοῦ ἀπικέσθαι to all extremity of ill, Hdt.; so, εἰς πᾶν ἀφικέσθαι Xen.; ἐς τὸ πᾶν altogether, Aesch.:— ἐν παντὶ ἀθυμίας εἶναι in all extremity of despair, Thuc.:— περὶ παντὸς ποιεῖσθαι to esteem above all, Lat. maximi facere, Xen.:— διὰ παντὸς (sc. χρόνου) , or as one word διάπαντος, for ever, continually, Soph., Thuc., etc.: but also, altogether, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: πασσαλευτός
div1.sense: pinned down, Aesch.

div1.head: πασσαλεύω
div1.sense: to pin or fasten to, τί τινι Aesch., Eur.
to drive in like a peg, Aesch.

div1.head: πάσσαλος
div1.sense: a peg on which to hang clothes, arms, etc., Hom., etc.; ἀπὸ πασσαλόφι ζυγὸν ᾕρεον Il.; ἀπὸ πασσάλου αἴνυτο τόξον Od.; ἐκ πασσαλόφι κρέμασεν φόρμιγγα Od.
a gag, Ar.

div1.head: πάσσος
div1.sense: πάσσος, οἶνος, Lat. vinum passum, raisin wine, Polyb.

div1.head: πάσσων
div1.etym: irreg. Epic comp. of παχύς, for παχύτερος or παχίων
div1.sense: thicker, stouter, Od.

div1.head: πάσσω
div1.sense: to sprinkle, φάρμακα πάσσων laying salves upon a wound, Il.: —c. gen. partit., πάσσε ἁλός sprinkle some salt, Il.
to besprinkle, χρυσῶι, ῥόδοις π. τινά Ar.
metaph. to embroider, broider, Il.; π. ἀέθλους to work battles in embroidery, Il.

div1.head: παστάς
div1.sense: a porch, Hdt.: also, a colonnade, piazza, corridor, Xen.
like θάλαμος, an inner room, bridal chamber, Eur., Theocr.; of the cave in which Antigone was immured, Soph.

div1.head: παστέος
div1.sense: to be besprinkled, Ar.

div1.head: παστός
div1.sense: a bridal chamber, Luc.

div1.head: πάσχα
div1.sense: the Hebrew Passover (from pasach to pass over), the paschal supper, NTest.

div1.head: πάσχω
div1.sense: radical sense, to receive an impression from without, to suffer, as opp. to doing, ἔρξαν τʼ ἔπαθόν τε Od.; δρᾶν καὶ πάσχειν, etc.; ὁμοίως π. τινί to be in the same case with . . , Hdt.
the sense is often limited by some word expressing good or evil:

κακῶς πάσχειν to be ill off, in evil plight, unlucky, Od., etc.; κακῶς π. ὑπό τινος to be ill used, ill treated by . . , Aesch.; often with an adj., κακά, λυγρὰ π. Il., etc.; δεινὰ π. Dem.; also with a Subst., ἄλγεα π. etc., Hom.
εὖ πάσχειν to be well off, in good case, lucky, Theogn., etc.; also, to receive benefits, opp. to εὖ δρᾶν, Aesch., etc.; so, ἀγαθὰ π. Hdt., etc.

without a limiting word, it always refers to evil, being used for κακῶς or κακὰ π., μάλα πολλʼ ἔπαθον Od., etc.; μή τι πάθηις lest thou suffer any ill, Hom.; εἴ τι πάθοιμι or ἤν τι πάθω, a euphemism, if aught were to happen to me, i. e. if I were to die, Hdt., Attic
τί πάθω; to express the extreme of perplexity, what is to become of me? what can I do? Hom., etc.; τί πάσχεις; what are you about? Ar.
the interrog. τί παθών; expresses something amiss, τί παθόντες γαῖαν ἔδυτε; what ailed you that you died? Od.

to be affected in a certain way, be in a certain state of mind, entertain certain feelings, Thuc., Plat.; ὅπερ ἂν οἱ πολλοὶ πάθοιεν as would be the case with most men, Thuc.; ἵνα μὴ ταὐτὸ πάθητε τῶι ἵππωι that it be not with you as with the horse in the fable, Arist.; ὑϊκὸν πάσχει he is swinishly disposed, Xen.; so of things, πάσχει τοῦτο καὶ κάρδαμα this is just the way with cress, Ar.
τὰ εὖ πεπονθότα benefits received, Aeschin.; cf. δράω.

div1.head: παταγέω
div1.sense: to clatter, clash, clap, of the sharp noise caused by the collision of two bodies, Ar.; of waves, to dash, plash, Theocr.: to chatter, as birds, Soph.
trans., τύμπανα π. to beat drums, Luc.

div1.head: πάταγος
div1.sense: a clatter, crash, of trees falling, Il.; a chattering of teeth, Il.; the plash of a body falling into water, Il.; the rattling or crash of thunder, Ar.: a clashing of arms, Hdt., Trag.

div1.head: Παταικίων
div1.sense: the name of a notorious impostor, Aeschin.

div1.head: Πάταικοι
div1.sense: Phoenician deities of dwarfish shape, forming the figure-heads of ships, Hdt.

div1.head: πατά
div1.sense: Scythian word, Hdt.

div1.head: πατάσσω
div1.sense: intr. to beat, knock, Lat. palpito, θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσι πάτασσεν Il.; κραδίη στέρνοισι πατάσσει (as Shaksp., "my heart knocks at my ribs") Il.
like πλήσσω, to strike, smite, π. τινὰ δορί Eur.; absol., Soph., etc.; of a deadly blow, ἐὰν λίθος ἢ σίδηρος πατάξηι Dem.
πατάξαι θύραν to knock at the door, Ar.
metaph., πατάξαι θυμόν Soph.; π. καρδίαν Ar.

div1.head: πατέομαι
div1.sense: to eat, σπλάγχνʼ ἐπάσαντο Il.; c. gen. partit. to eat of, partake of, σίτοιό τʼ ἐπασσάμεθʼ ἠδὲ ποτῆτος Od.; δείπνου πασσάμενος, etc., Od.: absol. to taste food, οὔτι πεπάσμην Od.

div1.head: πατερίζω
div1.sense: to say or call father, Ar.

div1.head: πατέριον
div1.sense: little father, Luc.

div1.head: πατέω
div1.sense: to tread, walk, Pind., Aesch.
trans. to tread on, tread, πορφύρας πατεῖν Aesch.; χῶρος οὐχ ἁγνὸς πατεῖν, i.e. it is holy ground, Soph.; πατεῖν πύλας to pass the gates, Aesch.
to walk in, i. e. to dwell in, frequent, Soph., Theocr.:—metaph., like Lat. terere, εὐνὰς π. to frequent, use, misuse, Aesch.; π. Αἴσωπον to be always thumbing Aesop, Ar.
to tread under foot, trample on, Aesch., Soph., etc.

div1.head: πατήρ
div1.etym: acc. always πατέρα gen. pl. rarely πατρῶν
div1.sense: a father, Hom., etc.; πατρὸς πατήρ a grandfather, Il.; τὰ πρὸς πατρός πατρόθεν, by the fatherʼs side, Hdt.
among the gods Zeus is called πατήρ, πατὴρ Ζεύς, π. ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε Hom., Hes.; so Ζεὺς π. Aesch.; Ζεῦ πάτερ καὶ θεοί Ar.
a respectful mode of addressing elderly persons, Od.
metaph. the father of anything, Lat. auctor, π. ἀοιδᾶν Pind., etc.
in pl. fathers, i.e. forefathers, Hom.; ἐξ ἔτι πατρῶν as an inheritance from oneʼs fathers, Od.

div1.head: πατησμός
div1.sense: a treading on, εἱμάτων Aesch.

div1.head: πάτος
div1.sense: a trodden or beaten way, path, Hom.: —metaph., ἔξω πάτου out-of-the-way, Luc.

div1.head: πατραλοίας
div1.sense: one who slays his father, a parricide, Ar., etc.

div1.head: πάτρα
div1.sense: oneʼs fatherland, native land, country, home, Il., Trag.: — πατρίς was the common prose form.
fatherhood, descent from a common father, ὁμὸν γένος ἤδʼ ἴα πάτρη Il.: then, like πατριά II, a house, clan, Lat. gens, Pind.

div1.head: Πάτραι
div1.sense: a city of Achaia, now Patras, Thuc.

div1.head: Πατρεύς
div1.sense: citizen of Patras, Hdt.

div1.head: πάτρηθε
div1.sense: from a race or family, Pind.

div1.head: πατριά
div1.sense: lineage, pedigree, by the fatherʼs side, Hdt.
= πάτρα II, a clan, house, family, Hdt., NTest.

div1.head: πατριάρχης
div1.sense: the father or chief of a race, a patriarch, NTest.

div1.head: πατρίδιον
div1.sense: Comic Dim. of πατήρ, daddy, Ar.

div1.head: πατρικός
div1.sense: derived from oneʼs fathers, paternal, hereditary, Ar., Thuc., etc.
= πάτριος, of or belonging to oneʼs father, ἡ πατρική (sc. οὐσία) patrimony, Eur.; τὰ πατρικά Anth.
like a father, paternal, Arist.

div1.head: πάτριος
div1.sense: of or belonging to oneʼs father, Lat. patrius, Pind., Soph., etc.

= πατρικός, derived from oneʼs fathers, hereditary, οἱ π. θεοί Hdt., Ar., etc.: —τὰ πάτρια, Lat. instituta majorum, κατὰ τὰ πάτρια Ar., Thuc., etc.; rarely in sg., τὸ πάτριον παρείς neglecting the rule of our fathers, Thuc. Cf. πατρῷος.

div1.head: πατρίς
div1.sense: of oneʼs fathers, πατρὶς γαῖα, αἶα, ἄρουρα oneʼs fatherland, country, Hom.
as Subst., like πάτρα, Il., Attic

div1.head: πατριώτης
div1.sense: one of the same country, a fellow-countryman, applied to barbarians who had only a common πατρίς, πολῖται being used of Greeks who had a common πόλις (or free state), Plat.; ἵπποι πατρ. Xen.; by a metaph., Mount Cithaeron is the πατριώτης of Oedipus, Soph.

div1.head: πατριῶτις
div1.etym: fem. of πατριώτης, π. γῆ πατρίς, Eur.

div1.head: πατρόθεν
div1.sense: from or after a father, πατρόθεν ἐκ γενεῆς ὀνομάξων naming him by descent by his fatherʼs name, Il.; ἐμὸς τὰ πατρόθεν mine by the fatherʼs side, Soph.; ἀναγραφῆναι π. to have oneʼs name inscribed as the son of oneʼs father, Hdt.
coming from, sent by oneʼs father, π. ἀλάστωρ Aesch.; π. εὐκταία φάτις a fatherʼs curse, Aesch.

div1.head: πατροκασίγνητος
div1.sense: a fatherʼs brother, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: Πάτροκλος
div1.sense: Patroclus the friend of Achilles
div1.etym: the obl. cases as if from Πατροκλεύς, gen. Πατροκλῆος, acc. Πατροκλῆα, voc. Πατρόκλεις, Il.; nom. pl. Πάτροκλοι, Ar.;—a nom. Πατροκλῆς, Theocr.

div1.head: πατροκτονέω
div1.sense: to murder oneʼs father, Aesch.

div1.head: πατροκτονία
div1.sense: murder of a father, parricide, Plut.

div1.head: πατροκτόνος
div1.sense: murdering oneʼs father, parricidal, Trag.; π. μίασμα the pollution of parricide, Aesch.:—but χεὶρ πατροκτόνος a fatherʼs murdering hand, Eur.

div1.head: πατρολέτωρ
div1.sense: a parricide, Anth.

div1.head: πατρομήτωρ
div1.sense: a motherʼs father, Luc.

div1.head: πατρονομέω
div1.sense: Pass. to be under a patriarchal government, Plat.

div1.head: πατρονομία
div1.sense: paternal government, Luc.

div1.head: πατρονομικός
div1.sense: of or like a πατρονόμος: ἡ -κή (sc. ἀρχή or τροφή) the rule of a father, Plat.

div1.head: πατροπάτωρ
div1.sense: a fatherʼs father, Pind.

div1.head: πατροστερής
div1.sense: reft of father, Aesch.

div1.head: πατροῦχος
div1.sense: holding from the father: π. παρθένος a sole-heiress, Hdt.

div1.head: πατροφονεύς
div1.sense: murderer of oneʼs father, Od.

div1.head: πατροφόνος
div1.sense: parricidal, Aesch., Eur.:—as Subst. a parricide, Plat.

div1.head: πατρωνύμιος
div1.sense: named after his father, Aesch.

div1.head: πατρῷος
div1.sense: of or from oneʼs father, coming or inherited from him, Lat. paternus, Hom., etc.; ξεῖνος πατρώιος my hereditary friend, Il.; γαῖα πατρωίη oneʼs fatherland, Il.; πατρώια oneʼs patrimony, Il., etc.; π. δόξα hereditary glory, Xen.; Ζεὺς π. also the god who protects a parentʼs rights, Ar.
like πάτριος, of or belonging to oneʼs father, Pind., Soph.; τὰ πατρώια the cause of oneʼs father, Opp. to τὰ μητρώια, Hdt.

div1.head: πάτρως
div1.sense: a fatherʼs brother, uncle by the fatherʼs side, Lat. patruus, Hdt., Pind.

div1.head: παῦλα
div1.sense: rest, a resting-point, stop, end, pause, Soph.; οὐκ ἐν παύλῃ ἐφαίνετο there seemed to be no end of it, Thuc.
c. gen., π. νόσου cessation of disease or rest from it, Soph.; παῦλάν τινʼ αὐτῶν some means of stopping them, Xen.

div0.div1: παυράκι like ὀλιγάκις seldom, Theogn. 859 [see LSJ supp]

div1.head: παυροεπής
div1.sense: of few words, Anth.

div1.head: παῦρος
div1.sense: little, small, of Time, short, Hes., Pind.
of number, few, Hom., Hes., etc.: comp. παυρότερος, fewer, Il.;—neut. pl. παῦρα as adv. few times, seldom, Hes., Ar.

div1.head: παυσάνεμος
div1.sense: stilling the wind, θυσία Aesch.

div1.head: παυσίλυπος
div1.sense: ending pain, Eur.

div1.head: παυσίνοσος
div1.sense: curing sickness, Anth.

div1.head: παυσίπονος
div1.sense: ending toil or hardship, c. gen., Eur.

div1.head: παυστέος
div1.sense: one must stop, Plat.

div1.head: παυστήριος
div1.sense: fit for ending or relieving, νόσου Soph.

div1.head: παυστήρ
div1.sense: one who stops, calms, a reliever, νόσου Soph.

div1.head: παυσωλή
div1.sense: like παῦλα, rest, Il.

div1.head: παύω
div1.sense: Causal, to make to cease:

of persons, to bring to an end, check, make an end of (by death), Hom., etc.:—Pass. and Mid. to take oneʼs rest, rest, cease, have done, Il.:—also of things, to make an end of, stop, abate, Il., etc.; π. τόξον to let oneʼs bow rest, Od.; π. τὸν νόμον to annul it, Eur.; π. τυραννίδα to put it down, Dem.

c. acc. pers. et gen. rei, to make to rest, stop, hinder, keep back from a thing, π. Ἕκτορα μάχης, etc., Hom., etc.: —π. τινὰ τῆς βασιλείας to depose one from being king, Hdt., etc.:—Pass. and Mid. to leave off from, rest or cease from, πολέμου Hom., etc.; τῆς μάχης Hdt., etc.; ἐκ τρόχων πεπαυμένοι at rest from play, Eur.
rarely c. gen. rei only, αἴ κέ ποθι Ζεὺς παύσηι ὀϊζύος oh that Zeus would make an end of woe! Od.; φάρμαχʼ, ἅ κεν παύσηισι ὀδυνάων Il.

c. part. praes. to stop a person from doing or being, π. τινὰ ἀριστεύοντα to stop him from being first, Il., Attic:—Pass. and Mid. to leave off doing or being, ἄνεμος μὲν ἐπαύσατο θύων left off blowing, Od.; the partic. omitted, αἷμα ἐπαύσατο the blood stopt [flowing], Il., etc.
inf. for part., ἔμʼ ἔπαυσας μάχεσθαι Il.; with μή inserted, θνητούς γʼ ἔπαυσα μὴ προδέρκεσθαι Aesch.
intr. in imperat., παῦε cease, leave off, Soph., Ar.; so, παῦε, παῦε τοῦ λόγου Ar.

div1.head: Παφλαγών
div1.sense: a Paphlagonian, Il.:—adj. Παφλαγονικός, ή, όν, Xen.

div1.head: παφλάζω
div1.sense: to boil, bluster, of the sea, Il.:— metaph. to splutter, bluster, of the angry Cleon (hence called Παφλαγών) , Ar.

div1.head: πάφλασμα
div1.sense: a boiling, of the sea:—metaph., παφλάσματα blusterings, Ar.

div1.head: Πάφος
div1.sense: Paphos, a town in Cyprus celebrated for its temple of Aphrodite, Od.:—adj. πάφιος, η, ον, of Aphrodite, Ar.

div1.head: πάχετος
div1.sense: massive, Od.
div1.etym: seemingly a poet. form of παχύς, as περιμήκετος of περιμήκης

div1.head: πάχνη
div1.sense: hoar-frost, rime, Lat. pruina, Od., Aesch.: metaph., κουροβόρος π. the clotted blood of the eaten children, Aesch.

div1.head: παχνόω
div1.sense: to congeal, make solid: metaph., ἐπάχνωσεν φίλον ἦτορ he made his blood run cold, made it curdle, Hes.; Pass., ἦτορ παχνοῦται his heart is cold and stiff [with grief], Il.; παχνοῦσθαι πένθεσιν, λύπῃ Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: πάχος
div1.sense: thickness, Od., Thuc.:— absol., πάχος in thickness, Hdt.
π. σαρκός stoutness, Eur.

div1.head: παχύκνημος
div1.sense: with stout calves, Ar.

div1.head: παχυλός
div1.sense: thickish: adv. -λῶς, coarsely, roughly, Arist.

div1.head: παχυμερής
div1.sense: consisting of thick or coarse parts: metaph. in adv. roughly, Strab.

div1.head: παχύνω
div1.sense: to thicken, fatten, Plat., Xen.:—Pass. to grow fat, Ar.: to become thick, of the skull, Hdt.
metaph. to increase:—Pass., ὄλβος ἄγαν παχυνθείς Aesch.
metaph. also to make gross or stupid:—Pass., NTest.

div1.head: παχύς
div1.sense: thick, stout, Hom., Hes.:— later, stout, fat, Ar.
of things, thick, massive, Hom., Ar.:—adv. -έως, roughly, of stating or arguing, Arist.; παχύτερον or -έρως, Plat.
of liquids, thick, curdled, clotted, Il., Hdt.
οἱ παχέες the men of substance, the wealthy class, Hdt.; τοὺς παχεῖς καὶ πλουσίους Ar.
in Com. and Prose, thick-witted, gross, dull, stupid, like Lat. pinguis, crassus, Com.
comp. παχύτερος, sup. -ύτατος:—irreg. comp. πάσσων, ον, Od.:—Sup. πάχιστος, Il.

div1.head: παχύστομος
div1.sense: speaking broad or roughly, Strab.

div1.head: παχύτης
div1.sense: thickness, stoutness, Hdt.
the thickness or sediment of liquor, Hdt.

div1.head: πεδάω
div1.sense: to bind with fetters, to bind fast, make fast, Od., Hdt., Aesch.
to shackle, trammel, constrain, Hom., Soph.; c. inf. to constrain one to do a thing, Hom.

div1.head: πέδη
div1.sense: a fetter, Lat. pedica, compes, mostly in pl. fetters, shackles, Il., etc.; πεδέων (Ionic) ζεῦγος a pair of fetters, Hdt.; metaph., πέδαι ἀχάλκευτοι fetters not forged by smiths, of the robe in which Agamemnon was entangled, Aesch.
a mode of breaking in a horse, Xen.

div1.head: πεδήτης
div1.sense: one fettered, a prisoner, Luc.

div1.head: πεδητής
div1.sense: a hinderer, Anth.

div1.head: πεδιακός
div1.sense: of or on the plain:— οἱ πεδιακοί the party of the plain, i. e. those who opposed Peisistratus, Arist.; called οἱ ἐκ τοῦ πεδίου by Hdt.; οἱ πεδιεῖς by Plut.

div1.head: πεδιάσιος
div1.sense: of the plain, Strab.

div1.head: πεδιάς
div1.sense: poet. fem. of πέδιος, πεδινός, flat, level, Hdt.: ἡ πεδιάς (sc. γῆ) the level country, Hdt.
on or of the plain, Soph.; λόγχη πεδιάς spearmen on the plain, Soph.

div1.head: πεδιήρης
div1.sense: abounding in plains, level, Aesch.

div1.head: πέδιλον
div1.sense: mostly in pl. sandals, Hom., Hes., Eur.
any covering for the foot, shoes or boots, Hdt.
metaph., Δωρίῳ πεδίλῳ φωνὰν ἐναρμόξαι, i.e. to adapt the song to Doric rhythm, Pind.; also, ἐν τούτῳ πεδίλῳ πόδʼ ἔχειν to have oneʼs foot in this shoe, i. e. to be in this condition or fortune, Pind.

div1.head: πεδινός
div1.sense: flat, level, Hdt.: comp. πεδινώτερος Plat.
of or on the plain, Xen.

div1.head: πεδίονδε
div1.sense: to the plain, Hom., Ar.

div1.head: πεδιονόμος
div1.sense: dwelling in plains, π. θεοί gods of the country, Aesch.

div1.head: πεδίον
div1.sense: a plain or flat, and collectively a plain flat open country, Hom., Hes., etc.

div1.head: πεδοβάμων
div1.sense: earth-walking, Aesch.

div1.head: πεδόθεν
div1.sense: from the ground, Hes., Eur.
from the bottom, Pind.: metaph. from the bottom of the heart, Od.
from the beginning, Pind.

div1.head: πέδοι
div1.sense: on the ground, on earth, Aesch.

div1.head: πεδοκοίτης
div1.sense: lying on the ground, Anth.

div1.head: πέδονδε
div1.sense: to the ground, earthwards, Il., Soph.
to the plain, Od.

div1.head: πέδον
div1.sense: the ground, earth, Hhymn., Attic; πέδῳ πεσεῖν to fall on the ground, to earth, Aesch.; so, ῥίπτειν πέδῳ Eur.
= πεδίον, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: πεδοστιβής
div1.sense: earth-treading, Eur.:— on foot, opp. to ἱππηλάτης, Aesch.

div1.head: πεδώρυχος
div1.sense: digging the soil, Anth.

div1.head: πέζα
div1.sense: = πούς, Anth.
metaph. the bottom or end of a body, πέζῃ ἔπι πρώτῃ at the far end, Il.
the edge or border of anything, of a garment, Anth.

div1.head: πέζαρχος
div1.sense: a leader of foot, Xen.

div1.head: πεζέμπορος
div1.sense: trafficking by land, Strab.

div1.head: πεζέταιροι
div1.sense: the foot-guards in the Macedon. army, the horse-guards being ἑταῖροι, Dem.

div1.head: πεζεύω
div1.sense: to go or travel on foot, walk, opp. to riding, Eur.
to go by land, opp. to going by sea, Xen.; οἱ πεζεύοντες land-forces, Arist.

div1.head: πεζικός
div1.sense: on foot, of or for a foot-soldier, τὸ πεζικόν the foot, the infantry, Xen.; τὰ π. the evolutions of infantry, Xen.
like πεζός, of a land force, opp. to a fleet, Xen., Aeschin., etc.

div1.head: πεζοβατέω
div1.sense: to walk over, Anth.

div1.head: πεζοβόας
div1.sense: one who shouts the battle-cry on foot, a foot-soldier, Pind.

div1.head: πεζομαχέω
div1.sense: to fight by land, opp. to ναυμαχέω, Hdt., Ar.; τισί with others, Thuc.; π. ἀπὸ τῶν νεῶν to fight like soldiers from ship-board, Thuc.

div1.head: πεζομαχία
div1.sense: a battle by land, opp. to ναυμαχία, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: πεζομάχος
div1.sense: fighting on foot, Luc.
fighting as a soldier, opp. to ναυμάχος, Plut.

div1.head: πεζονόμος
div1.sense: commanding by land, Aesch.

div1.head: πεζοπορέω
div1.sense: to go on foot, Xen.
to go by land, to march, Polyb.

div1.head: πεζοπόρος
div1.sense: going by land, Anth.; ναύτης ἠπείρου π. πελάγους, of Xerxes, Anth.

div1.head: πεζός
div1.sense: on foot, πεζοί fighters on foot, opp. to horsemen, Hom.:—also on land, going by land, opp. to sea-faring, Hom.:—so, ὁ πεζὸς στρατός, or ὁ πεζός alone, sometimes foot-soldiery, infantry, opp. to cavalry (ἡ ἵππος) , Hdt., Xen.
ὁ πεζός, also, a land-force or army, opp. to a naval force, Hdt., Thuc.; so, τὸ πεζόν Hdt.; στρατιὰ καὶ ναυτικὴ καὶ πεζή Thuc.; τὰ πεζὰ κράτιστοι strongest by land, Thuc.
of animals, land, as opp. to birds and fishes, τὰ π. καὶ τὰ πτηνά beasts and birds, Plat.
metaph. of language, not rising above the ground, prosaic, Luc.
dat. fem. πεζῇ (sub. ὁδῷ) as adv., on foot, Xen.
by land, Thuc.

div1.head: πειθάνωρ
div1.sense: obeying men, obedient, Aesch.

div1.head: πειθαρχέω
div1.sense: to obey one in authority, c. dat., π. πατρί Soph.; τοῖς νόμοις Ar.: absol. to be obedient, Arist.:—so in Mid., Hdt.

div1.head: πειθαρχία
div1.sense: obedience to command, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: πειθαρχικός
div1.sense: obeying readily, Arist.

div1.head: πείθαρχος
div1.sense: obedient, Aesch.

div1.head: πειθώ
div1.sense: Peitho, Persuasion as a goddess, Lat. Suada, Suadela, Hes., Hdt., Trag.
as appellat., the faculty of persuasion, winning eloquence, persuasiveness, Aesch., Plat., etc.
a persuasion in the mind, Aesch.
a means of persuasion, inducement, argument, Eur., Ar.
obedience, Xen.

div1.head: πείθω
div1.sense: Act. to prevail upon, win over, persuade, τινά Hom., etc.:—c. acc. pers. et inf. to persuade one to do, Il., etc.; also, π. τινὰ ὥστε δοῦναι, etc., Hdt.; π. τινα ὡς χρή Plat.; π. τινὰ εἴς τι Thuc.; in part., πείσας by persuasion, by fair means, Soph.
Special usages:
to talk over, mislead, ἔληθε δόλωι καὶ ἔπεισεν Ἀχαιούς Od.
to prevail on by entreaty, Hom.
π. τινὰ χρήμασι to bribe, Hdt.; so, π. ἐπὶ μισθῶι or μισθῶι Hdt., Thuc.: so, πείθειν τινά alone, Xen., NTest.
c. dupl. acc., πείθειν τινά τι to persuade one of a thing, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
Pass. and Mid. to be prevailed on, won over, persuaded, absol., Hom., Attic; the imperat. πείθου or πιθοῦ listen, comply, Trag.; c. inf. to be persuaded to do, Soph.; also, πείθεσθαι ὥστε . . Thuc.
πείθεσθαί τινι to listen to one, obey him, Hom., etc.; νῦν μὲν πειθώμεθα νυκτὶ μελαίνηι, of leaving off the labours of the day, Il.; —πάντα πείθεσθαί τινι to obey him in all things, Od., etc.

πείθεσθαί τινι, also, to believe or trust in a person or thing, Hom., etc.: —c. acc. et inf. to believe that, Od., etc.: with an adj. neut., π. τὰ περὶ Αἴγυπτον Hdt.; ταῦτʼ ἐγώ σοι οὐ πείθομαι I do not take this on your word, Plat.

perf. 2 πέποιθα, like the Pass., to trust, rely on, have confidence in a person or thing, Hom., etc.; c. inf., πέποιθα τοῦτʼ ἐπισπάσειν κλέος I trust to win this fame, Soph.; πέποιθα τὸν πυρφόρον ἥξειν Aesch.;— πεπ. εἴς τινα, ἐπί τινα NTest.
perf. pass. πέπεισμαι to believe, trust, c. dat., Aesch., Eur.: c. acc. et inf., πεπ. ταῦτα συνοίσειν Dem.

div1.head: πειναλέος
div1.sense: also ος, ον, hungry, Anth.; π. πίνακες empty dishes, Anth.

div1.head: πεῖνα
div1.sense: hunger, famine, Od., Plat.
metaph. hunger or longing for a thing, Plat.

div1.head: πεινάω
div1.etym: forms in αε contr. into η not ᾱ, as in διψάω
div1.sense: to be hungry, suffer hunger, be famished, Lat. esurio, Hom., etc.: πεινᾶντι (Doric for -ῶντι) μὴ προσενθῆις donʼt go near a hungry man, Theocr.
c. gen. to hunger after, Od.: —metaph., π. χρημάτων, ἐπαίνου Xen., NTest.

div1.head: πειράζω
div1.sense: to make proof or trial of, τινός Od.:—c. inf. to attempt to do, NTest.:—Pass., πεπειράσθω let trial be made, Ar.
c. acc. pers. to try or tempt a person, put him to the test, NTest.: absol., ὁ πειράζων the tempter, NTest.:—Pass. to be sorely tempted, to be tempted to sin, NTest.

div1.head: Πειραιεύς
div1.sense: Peiraeeus, the most noted harbour of Athens; gen. Πειραιέως, Attic Πειραιῶς, dat. Πειραιεῖ, acc. Πειραιᾶ, Ionic Πειραιέα.— adj. Πειραϊκός, ή, όν, Plut.

div1.head: πειραϊκός
div1.sense: over the border, γῆ π. border- country, the march, Thuc.

div1.head: πειραίνω
div1.sense: to fasten by the two ends, to tie fast, σειρὴν ἐξ αὐτοῦ πειρήναντε having tied a rope to him, Od.

div1.head: πεῖρα
div1.sense: a trial, attempt, essay, experiment, Theogn., Soph., etc.; —πεῖραν ἔχειν to be proved, Pind.; but, πεῖραν ἔχειν τινός to have experience of a thing, Xen.; π. ἔχει τῆς γνώμης involves a trial of your resolution, Thuc.; —πεῖράν τινος λαμβάνειν to make trial or proof of . . , Xen., etc.: —πεῖράν τινος διδόναι, Lat. specimen sui edere, Thuc.

with Preps., ἀπὸ πείρης by experiment, Hdt.: —εἰς πεῖράν τινος ἔρχεσθαι, ἰέναι Eur., Thuc.: —ἐν πείρᾳ τινὸς γίγνεσθαι to be acquainted with, associate with one, Xen.: —ἐπὶ πείρᾳ by way of test or trial, Ar.
an attempt on or against one, c. gen., Soph.
generally, an attempt, enterprise, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: πεῖραρ
div1.sense: an end, mostly in pl., πείρατα γαίης the ends of the earth, Hom.:— absol., πείρατα the ends or ties of ropes, Od.; cf. ἐπαλλάσσω.
the end or issue of a thing, Od.; ἑκάστου πείρατʼ ἔειπεν of the issues or chief points, Il.:—pleonastic, πείρατα νίκης νίκη, πείρατʼ ὀλέθρου
act. that which gives the finish to a thing, πείρατα τέχνης, the finishers of his art (of tools), Od.

div1.head: πειρασμός
div1.sense: trial, temptation, NTest.

div1.head: πειραστικός
div1.sense: tentative, Arist.

div1.head: πειρατέος
div1.sense: one must attempt, Plat.

div1.head: πειρατεύω
div1.sense: to be a pirate, Strab.

div1.head: πειρατήριον
div1.sense: φόνια πειρατήρια the murderous ordeal, Eur.
a pirateʼs nest, Strab., Plut.

div1.head: πειρατής
div1.sense: a pirate, Lat. pirata, i. e. one who attacks ships, Polyb., Plut.

div1.head: πειρατικός
div1.sense: piratical, Plut.: τὰ π. gangs of pirates, Strab.

div1.head: πειράω
div1.sense: Act. to attempt, endeavour, try to do, c. inf., Il., Hdt., etc.
c. gen. pers. to make trial of one, Il.: in hostile sense, to make an attempt on, Hom., Hdt.
absol. to try oneʼs fortune, try oneʼs skill in thieving, Hhymn.; ναυσὶ π. to make an attempt by sea, Thuc.; cf. πειρατής.
c. acc. pers. to make an attempt on, Ar.
Dep. in the same sense, c. inf. to try to do, Il., Hdt.;—also foll. by εἰ, to try whether, Il.; by μή, Od.
most commonly, c. gen.,

c. gen. pers. to make trial of one, to see whether he is trustworthy, Hom., Hdt.:—also in hostile sense, to make trial of the strength of an enemy, Il.; π. τῆς Πελοποννήσου to make an attempt on it, Hdt.; τοῦ τείχους Thuc.

c. gen. rei, to make proof or trial of oneʼs strength, Hom.:— to try oneʼs chance at or in a work or contest, Hom.:—also to make proof of a thing, to see what it is good for, τόξου, νευρῆς Od.:— to make proof of, have experience of, make acquaintance with others, Hdt., Thuc.
absol. to try oneʼs fortune, try the chances of war, Il.
c. dat. modi, to make a trial or attempt with, ἐπειρήσαντο πόδεσσι tried their luck in the foot-race, Od.; σφαίρηι πειρήσαντο Od.; also, π. σὺν ἔντεσι, σὺν τεύχεσι πειρηθῆναι Il.
c. acc. rei, ἢ ἕκαστα πειρήσαιτο or should examine into each particular, Od.
c. acc. pers. to make an attempt on, Pind.

div1.head: πειρητίζω
div1.sense: to attempt, try, prove, c. inf., or absol., Hom.
c. gen. pers. to make trial of, Hom.: c. gen. rei, σθένεος καὶ ἀλκῆς Od.
c. acc., π. στίχας ἀνδρῶν to attempt, i. e. attack, the lines, Il.

div1.head: πείρινς
div1.sense: a wicker-basket fixed upon the ἅμαξα or carriage, being in fact the body of the cart, Hom.

div1.head: πείρω
div1.sense: to pierce quite through, fix meat on spits, for roasting, Il.; κρέα ἀμφʼ ὀβελοῖσιν ἔπειραν Il.:—also, διὰ πεῖρεν ὀδόντων ἔγχεϊ he ran him through the teeth with a spear, Il.:— Pass., ἥλοισι πεπαρμένον studded with golden nails, Il.; but, ὀδύνηισι πεπαρμένος pierced with pain, Il.; also, πεπαρμένη περὶ δουρί Il.
metaph., κύματα πείρειν to cleave the waves, Hom.; πεῖρε κέλευθον clave her way [through the sea], Od.

div1.head: πεῖσα
div1.sense: poet. for πειθώ, obedience, ἐν πείσηι κραδίη μένε, i. e. it remained calm, Od.

div1.head: πεισίβροτος
div1.sense: persuading or controlling mortals, of a kingʼs sceptre, Aesch.

div1.head: πεισιχάλινος
div1.sense: obeying the rein, Pind.

div1.head: πεῖσμα
div1.sense: a shipʼs cable, Od., Aesch.:— generally, a rope, Od. (Properly, that which holds in obedience.)

div1.head: πεισμονή
div1.sense: persuasion, NTest.

div1.head: πειστέος
div1.sense: one must persuade, Plat.
(from Pass.) one must obey, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: πειστήριος
div1.sense: persuasive, Eur.

div1.head: πειστήρ
div1.sense: a rope, Theocr.

div1.head: πειστικός
div1.sense: persuasive, Plat.

div1.head: πεκτέω
div1.sense: to shear, clip, Ar.

div1.head: πέκω
div1.sense: to comb or card wool, Od.: Mid., χαίτας πεξαμένη when she combed her hair, Il.
to shear sheep, Hes., Theocr.: Mid., πόκως πέξασθαι to have their wool shorn, Simon. ap. Ar.

div1.head: πελαγίζω
div1.sense: to form a sea or lake, of a river that has overflowed, Hdt.:—of places, to be flooded, Hdt.
to keep the sea, cross the sea, Xen.

div1.head: πελάγιος
div1.sense: of the sea, Lat. marinus, Eur.:—of animals, living in the sea, Eur.
out at sea, on the open sea, Soph.; of seamen or ships, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πελαγῖτις
div1.sense: fem. adj. of or on the sea, Anth.

div1.head: πέλαγος
div1.sense: the sea, esp. the high sea, open sea, the main, Lat. pelagus, Hom., etc.; joined with other words denoting sea, ἁλὸς ἐν πελάγεσσιν (cf. aequora ponti), Od.; πόντιον π. or πόντου π., Pind.; ἅλς πελαγία Aesch.; ἅλιον π. Eur.: often of parts of the sea (θάλασσα) , Αἰγαῖον p. Aesch.; ἐκ μεγάλων πελαγῶν, τοῦ τε Τυρσηνικοῦ καὶ τοῦ Σικελιοῦ Thuc.
metaph., of any vast quantity, π. κακῶν a "sea of troubles, " Aesch.; π. δύης Aesch.; εἰς τὸ π. τῶν λόγων Plat.; also of great difficulties, Soph.

div1.head: πελάζω
div1.sense: intr. to approach, come near, draw near or nigh, c. dat., πέλασεν νήεσσι Il.; τούτοις σὺ μὴ π. Aesch., etc.
rarely c. gen., πελάσαι νεῶν to come near the ships, Soph.; πελάζειν σῆς πάτρας Soph.
with a prep., π. πρὸς τοῖχον Hes.; εἰς ὄψιν τινός Eur.; c. acc. loci, δῶμα πελάζειν Eur.; οὐκέτι πελᾶτε will no more approach me, Soph.
absol., Xen.

Causal, to bring near or to, make to approach, Κρήτηι ἐπέλασσεν (sc. τὰς νέας) Od.; νευρὴν μαζῶι πέλασεν brought the string up to his breast, in drawing a bow, Od.; ἐπέλασσα θαλάσσηι στῆθος, in swimming, Od.; πέλασε χθονί brought them to earth, Il.; π. τινὰ δεσμοῖς Aesch.:—metaph., π. τινὰ ὀδύνηισι to bring him into pain, Il.; ἔπος ἐρέω, ἀδάμαντι πελάσσας having made it firm as adamant, Orac. ap. Hdt.
followed by a prep., με νῆσον ἐς Ὠγυγίην πέλασαν θεοί Od.
in Pass., like the intr. Act. to come nigh, approach, etc., c. dat., Il.; πλῆτο χθονί he came near (i. e. sank to) earth, Il.
rarely c. gen., Soph.
foll. by a prep., πελασθῆναι ἐπὶ τὸν θεόν Soph.
to approach or wed, of a woman, Aesch.

div1.head: πελάθω
div1.etym: collat. form of πελάζω intr., Aesch. ap. Ar., Eur.

div1.head: πελανός
div1.sense: any half-liquid substance, of various consistency, as oil, Aesch.; clotted blood, Aesch.; foam at the mouth, Eur.
a mixture offered to the gods, of meal, honey, and oil, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: πελαργιδεύς
div1.sense: a young stork, Ar.

div1.head: Πελαργικός
div1.sense: τὸ Πελαργικόν the northern slope of the Acropolis at Athens, Ar.; written Πελασγικόν in Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: πελαργός
div1.sense: the stork, Lat. ciconia, Ar., etc.
div1.etym: From πελός, ἀργός, properly, the blackandwhite.

div1.head: πελαργώδης
div1.sense: like a stork, Strab.

div1.head: Πελασγικός
div1.sense: Thessalian, but later for Argive, Eur.:—so Πελάσγιος, η, ον, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: Πελασγιῶται
div1.sense: Pelasgiotes (in Thessaly), Strab.:—fem. adj. Πελασγίς, ίδος, Hdt.

div1.head: Πελασγός
div1.sense: a Pelasgian; in Il., the Pelasgians appear among the allies of the Trojans; in Od. we hear of them in Crete; but in Il., Achilles prays to Dodonaean Zeus as Pelasgian, and τὸ Πελασγικὸν Ἄργος was Thessalian Argos, the original seat of the Hellenes; Hdt. contrasts them with the Hellenes; but Πελασγοί is used for Greeks in Eur., as in Virg.

div1.head: πέλας
div1.sense: near, hard by, close, c. gen., Od., Hdt., Trag.
like ἐγγύς, c. dat., Pind., Aesch.
absol., χριμφθεὶς πέλας Od.; π. στείχειν, παρεῖναι, στῆναι Trag.
οἱ πέλας (sc. ὄντες) oneʼs neighbours, Thuc., etc.: hence oneʼs fellow-creatures, all men, Hdt., Trag.: in sg., ὁ πέλας oneʼs neighbour, any man, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: πελάτης
div1.sense: one who approaches or comes near, Soph.: a neighbour, Lat. accola, Aesch.
esp. of one who approaches a woman, τὸν πελάταν λέκτρων Διός, of Ixion, Soph.
one who approaches to seek protection, a dependant, Plat.; the Rom. cliens, Plut.

div1.head: πέλεθος
div1.sense: ordure, Ar.

div1.head: πέλεια
div1.sense: the wild-pigeon, rock-pigeon, stock-dove, so called from its dark colour, Hom., Soph.
πέλειαι, ῶν, αἱ, name of prophetic priestesses, prob. borrowed from the prophetic doves of Dodona, Hdt.

div1.head: πελειάς
div1.sense: = πέλεια, Il., Hdt., Trag.
= πέλεια II, Soph.

div1.head: πελειοθρέμμων
div1.sense: dove-nurturing, Aesch.

div1.head: πελεκᾶς
div1.sense: the woodpecker, as if joiner-bird, Ar.

div1.head: πελεκάω
div1.sense: to hew or shape with an axe, Lat. dolare, Od. (in Epic aor1 πελέκκησε), Ar.

div1.head: πελεκίζω
div1.sense: to cut off with an axe, esp. to behead, Polyb.

div1.head: πελεκῖνος
div1.sense: a water-bird of the pelican kind, Ar.

div1.head: πέλεκκον
div1.sense: an axe-handle, Il.

div1.head: πέλεκυς
div1.sense: an axe for felling trees, with two edges, opp. to the ἡμιπέλεκκον, Hom., Xen.

a sacrificial axe, Hom.—That it was not, properly, a battle axe appears from the phrase, οὐ δόρασι μάχεσθαι, ἀλλὰ καὶ πελέκεσι to fight not with spears only, but with common axes, i. e. to the last, Hdt.
in Theophr. Char., πέλεκυς as a childʼs nickname seems to mean a sharp blade.

div1.head: πελεκυφόρος
div1.sense: an axe-bearer, Lat. consul or praetor, before whom axes are carried, Polyb.

div1.head: πελεμίζω
div1.sense: to shake, to make to quiver or tremble, Il.; π. τόξον to struggle at the bow, in order to bend it, Od.:—Pass. to be shaken, to tremble, quiver, quake, Il.
to shake or drive from his post, Il.: Pass., χασσάμενος πελεμίχθη Il.

div1.head: πελιδνός
div1.sense: livid, Thuc.

div1.head: πελιός
div1.sense: livid, Dem.

div1.head: πέλλα
div1.sense: Lat. pelvis, a wooden bowl, milk-pail, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: Πελοποννασιστί
div1.sense: in the Peloponnesian (i. e. Dorian) dialect, Theocr.

div1.head: Πελοποννησιακός
div1.sense: Peloponnesian, Strab.

div1.head: Πελοποννήσιος
div1.sense: Peloponnesian, inhabitant of the Peloponnese, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Πελοπόννησος
div1.sense: for Πέλοπος νῆσος, the Peloponnesus, now the Morea, Hhymn., etc.

div1.head: πελλός
div1.sense: Lat. pullus, dark-coloured, dusky, ash-coloured, Theocr.

div1.head: Πέλοψ
div1.sense: Pelops, i. e. dark-face, son of Tantalus, who migrated from Lydia, and gave his name to Peloponnesus, Il.

div1.head: πελτάζω
div1.sense: to serve as a targeteer, Xen.

div1.head: πελταστής
div1.sense: one who bears a light shield (πέλτη) instead of the heavy ὅπλον, a targeteer, Lat. cetratus, Eur., Thuc., etc. The peltasts held a place between the ὁπλῖται and ψιλοί.

div1.head: πελταστικός
div1.sense: skilled in the use of the πέλτη, like a targeteer, Plat.:— ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art or skill of a targeteer, Plat.: τὸ -κόν, οἱ πελτασταί, Xen. —Sup. adv., πελταστικώτατα quite in the manner of πελτασταί, in the best style, Xen.

div1.head: πέλτη
div1.sense: a small light shield of leather without a rim (ἴτυς) , a target, Lat. cetra, orig. used by the Thracians, Hdt., Eur., etc.
a body of πελτασταί, Eur.
a horseʼs ornament, Eur.
= παλτόν, a shaft, pole, Xen.

div1.head: πελτοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing a target, Xen.

div1.head: πέλυξ
div1.sense: a kind of axe, Babr.

div1.head: πέλω
div1.sense: The orig. sense, to be in motion, appears in Hom., κλαγγὴ πέλει οὐρανόθι πρό the cry goes, rises to heaven, Il.; τῶι δεκάτηι πέλεν ἠώς to him came the tenth morn, Od.; γῆρας καὶ θάνατος ἐπʼ ἀνθρώποισι πέλονται old age and death come upon men, Od.:—this sense of motion is plain in the compd. participles ἐπιπλόμενος, περιπλόμενος.
commonly to be, Hom.; but generally implying continuance, to be used or wont to be, Il.:—the imperf. in pres. sense, ὀϊζυρὸς ἔπλεο thou wast doomed to be, i. e. thou art, Hom.

div1.head: πελώριος
div1.sense: Like πέλωρος, gigantic, Hom.: of things, huge, ἔγχος, λᾶας, κύματα Hom.; τὰ πρὶν πελώρια the mighty things, or mighty ones, of old, Aesch.

div1.head: πέλωρον
div1.sense: a monster, prodigy, of the Gorgon, Hom.; of a large stag, Od.; of the animals transformed by Circe, Od.; πέλωρα θεῶν portents sent by the gods, Il.

div1.head: πέλωρος
div1.sense: monstrous, prodigious, huge, gigantic, with collat. notion of terrible, like πελώριος, Hom., Hes.:—neut. pl. as adv., πέλωρα βιβᾷ he strides gigantic, Hhymn.

div1.head: πέλωρ
div1.sense: a portent, prodigy, monster, only in nom. and acc., of the Cyclops, Od.; of Scylla, Od.; even of Hephaestus, Il.

div1.head: πέμμα
div1.sense: any kind of dressed food; but mostly in pl., pastry, cakes, sweetmeats, Hdt.

div1.head: πεμπάδαρχος
div1.sense: a commander of a body of five, Xen.

div1.head: πεμπάζω
div1.sense: properly to count on the five fingers, i. e. to count by fives, and then, generally, to count, Aesch.:—so in Mid., ἐπὴν πάσας πεμπάσσεται (Epic for πεμπάσηται aor1 subj.) when he has done counting them all, Od.

div1.head: πεμπάς
div1.sense: a body of five, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: πεμπαστής
div1.sense: one who counts: used as a Verbal c. acc., μύρια π. reviewing by tens of thousands, Aesch.

div1.head: πεμπταῖος
div1.sense: on the fifth day, agreeing with the Subject, πεμπταῖοι ἱκόμεσθα on the fifth day we came, Od.; πεμπταῖον ἐγένετο it was on the fifth day, Dem.; π. προκεῖσθαι to have been five days laid out as dead, Ar.

div1.head: πεμπτέος
div1.sense: to be sent, Luc.
πεμπτέον, one must send, Xen.

div1.head: πέμπτος
div1.sense: the fifth, oneself with four others, πέμπτος μετὰ τοῖσιν Od.; πέμπτος αὐτός Thuc.; π. σπιθαμή, i. e. 4 cubits and a span, Hdt.; τὸ πέμπτον μέρος a fifth, Plat.
ἡ πέμπτη (sc. ἡμέρα) the fifth day, Hes., Ar.

div1.head: πεμπτός
div1.sense: sent, Thuc.

div1.head: πεμπώβολον
div1.sense: a five-pronged fork, for stirring the sacrificial fire, Hom.

div1.head: πέμπω
div1.sense: to send, despatch, Il., etc.; of a ship, to convey, carry, Od.; c. dupl. acc., ὁδὸν π. τινά to conduct one on his way Soph.
to send forth or away, dismiss, like ἀποπέμπω, to send home, Hom.; χρὴ ξεῖνον παρεόντα φιλεῖν, ἐθέλοντα δὲ πέμπειν, welcome the coming, speed the parting guest, " Od.
of missiles, to discharge, shoot forth, Hes.
of words, to send forth, utter, Aesch., Soph.

to conduct, convoy, escort, Lat. deduco, Hom., etc.; ὁ πέμπων absol., of Hermes, Soph.:— πομπὴν πέμπειν to conduct a procession, Hdt., Thuc.; π. χορούς Eur., Xen.: in Pass., πέμπεσθαι Διονύσωι to be carried in procession in his honour, Hdt.
to send with one, give as provision for a journey, Od., Hdt., etc.
like ἀναπέμπω, to send up, produce, Soph.
in Mid., πέμπεσθαί τινα, μεταπέμπεσθαι, to send for one, Soph., Eur.
to send for oneself, to send in oneʼs own service or cause some one to be sent, Soph.

div1.head: πέμψις
div1.sense: a sending, mission, dispatch, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: πενεστεία
div1.sense: the class of Penestae, Arist.

div1.head: πενέστης
div1.sense: a labourer, workman:—the πενέσται were the Thessalian serfs, ascripti glebae, Ar., Xen., etc. Like the Εἵλωτες in Laconia, they were orig. a conquered tribe, afterwards increased by prisoners of war, and formed a link between the freemen and the born slaves.
generally, any slave or bondsman, Eur.:— a poor man, Ar.

div1.head: πένης
div1.sense: one who works for his daily bread, a day-labourer, a poor man, distinguished from πτωχός (beggar), Hdt., Soph., etc.
as adj. of a poor man, δόμος Eur.; ἐν πένητι σώματι Eur.: c. gen., π. χρημάτων poor in money, Eur.; π. φίλων Plat.:— comp. πενέστερος Xen.; Sup. πενέστατος Dem.

div1.head: πενητοκόμος
div1.sense: tending the poor, Anth.

div1.head: πενθαλέος
div1.sense: sad, mourning, Anth.

div1.head: πενθερά
div1.sense: a mother-in-law, Lat. socrus, Dem.

div1.head: πενθερός
div1.sense: a father-in-law, Lat. socer, Hom., etc.:—in pl. parents-in-law, Eur.
generally, a connexion by marriage, e. g. brother-in-law, Eur.

div1.head: πενθέω
div1.sense: to bewail, lament, mourn for, Il.; πενθεῖν τινὰ ὡς τεθνεῶτα Hdt., etc.:—Pass. to be mourned for, Isocr.

div1.head: πένθημα
div1.sense: lamentation, mourning, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: πενθήμερος
div1.sense: of five days, κατὰ πενθήμερον for alternate spaces of five days, Xen.

div1.head: πενθημιμερής
div1.sense: consisting of five halves, or two and a half:—in Prosody, τομὴ π. the caesura after two feet and a half, as in hexam. and iamb. verses.

div1.head: πενθημιπόδιος
div1.sense: consisting of five half feet, i. e. of 2 1/2 feet, Xen.

div1.head: πενθήρης
div1.sense: lamenting, mourning, Eur.

div1.head: πενθητήριος
div1.sense: of or in sign of mourning, Aesch.

div1.head: πενθητήρ
div1.sense: a mourner, Aesch.:— fem., κακῶν πενθήτρια, she who mourns for evils, Eur.

div1.head: πενθικός
div1.sense: of or for mourning, mournful:—adv., πενθικῶς ἔχειν τινός to be in mourning for a person, Xen.

div1.head: πένθιμος
div1.sense: mournful, mourning, sorrowful, Aesch., Eur.
mournful, sorry, wretched, γῆρας Eur.

div1.head: πένθος
div1.sense: grief, sadness, sorrow, Hom., etc.; τινός for one, Od.:—esp. of the outward signs of grief, mourning for the dead, Hom., etc.; π. ποιήσασθαι to make a public mourning, Hdt.
a misfortune, Hdt., Pind.
of persons, a misery, Soph.
div1.etym: Related to πάθος, as βένθος to βάθος.

div1.head: πενία
div1.sense: poverty, need, Od., etc.

div1.head: πενιχρός
div1.sense: poor, needy, Od., Theogn.

div1.head: πένομαι
div1.sense: Dep., used in pres. and impf. :
intr. to work for oneʼs daily bread; generally, to toil, work, labour, Hom.
to be poor or needy, Solon, Eur., etc.
c. gen. to be poor in, have need of, Aesch., Eur.
trans. to work at, prepare, get ready, δαῖτα πένοντο Od.; τί σε χρὴ ταῦτα πένεσθαι; Od.

div1.head: πενταδραχμία
div1.sense: five drachmae, Xen.

div1.head: πεντάδραχμος
div1.sense: of the weight or value of five drachmae, Hdt.

div1.head: πενταετηρίς
div1.sense: = πεντετηρίς, Arist.
as adj. coming every fifth year, Pind.

div1.head: πενταέτηρος
div1.sense: five years old, Hom.

div1.head: πενταετής
div1.sense: five years old, Hdt.
of Time, lasting five years, Thuc.:— neut. adv. πεντάετες, for five years, Od.

div1.head: πεντάζωνος
div1.sense: with five zones, Strab.

div1.head: πένταθλον
div1.sense: the contest of the five exercises, Lat. quinquertium, Pind.; πεντάεθλον ἀσκεῖν or ἐπασκεῖν Hdt.—These exercises were ἅλμα, δίσκος, δρόμος, πάλη, πυγμή, the last being exchanged for the ἀκόντισις or ἀκών; they are summed in one pentam., ἅλμα, ποδωκείην, δίσκον, ἄκοντα, πάλην.

div1.head: πένταθλος
div1.sense: one who practises the πένταθλον or conquers therein, Arist.: metaph. of "a jack of all trades, " Xen.

div1.head: πένταιχμος
div1.sense: five-pointed, Anth.

div1.head: πεντακισμύριοι
div1.sense: five times ten thousand, 50, 000, Hdt.

div1.head: πεντάκις
div1.sense: five times, Pind., Aesch., etc.:—in late Poets πεντάκι, Anth.

div1.head: πεντακισχίλιοι
div1.sense: five thousand, Hdt.

div1.head: πεντακοσιάρχης
div1.sense: the commander of 500 men, Plut.

div1.head: πεντακόσιοι
div1.sense: five hundred, Od., Hdt.
at Athens, οἱ πεντακόσιοι the senate of 500 (ἡ βουλή) , chosen by lot (ἀπὸ κυάμου) , 50 from each tribe, Dem., etc.

div1.head: πεντακοσιομέδιμνος
div1.sense: possessing land which produced 500 medimni yearly, Thuc., Arist.:—acc. to Solon.ʼs distribution of the Athen. citizens, the πεντακοσιομέδιμνοι formed the first class.

div1.head: πεντακοσιοστός
div1.sense: the five-hundredth, one of 500, Ar.

div1.head: πεντακυμία
div1.sense: the fifth wave, supposed to be larger than the four preceding, Luc.

div1.head: πενταμερής
div1.sense: in five parts, Strab.

div1.head: πενταπάλαιστος
div1.sense: five handbreadths wide, long, Xen.

div1.head: πεντάπηχυς
div1.sense: five cubits long or broad, Hdt.

div1.head: πενταπλάσιος
div1.sense: five-fold, Hdt.; π. τινος five times as large as . . , Arist.

div1.head: πεντάρραγος
div1.sense: with five berries, Anth.

div1.head: πενταρχία
div1.sense: a magistracy of five, Arist.

div1.head: πεντασπίθαμος
div1.sense: five spans long or broad, Xen.

div1.head: πενταστάδιος
div1.sense: of five stades, Strab.:— also πεντα-σταδιαῖος, Luc.

div1.head: πεντάστιχος
div1.sense: of five lines or verses, Anth.

div1.head: πεντάστομος
div1.sense: with five mouths or openings, of rivers, Hdt.

div1.head: πεντάτευχος
div1.sense: consisting of five books: as Subst., ἡ π. (sc. βίβλος) the five books of Moses, Pentateuch.

div1.head: πενταφυής
div1.sense: of five-fold nature, five, Anth.

div1.head: πένταχα
div1.sense: five-fold, in five divisions, Il.

div1.head: πενταχοῦ
div1.sense: in five places, Hdt.

div1.head: πεντεκαιδεκαναΐα
div1.sense: a squadron of 15 ships, Dem.

div1.head: πεντεκαίδεκα
div1.sense: fifteen, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: πεντεκαιδεκατάλαντος
div1.sense: worth fifteen talents, Dem.

div1.head: πεντεκαιδέκατος
div1.sense: the fifteenth, NTest.

div1.head: πεντεκαιπεντηκονταετής
div1.sense: fifty-five years old, Plat.

div1.head: πέντε
div1.sense: five, Hom., etc.

div1.head: πεντεσύριγγος
div1.sense: with five holes, ξύλον π. a pillory, furnished with five holes, through which the head, arms, and legs of criminals were passed, Ar.

div1.head: πεντετάλαντος
div1.sense: worth or consisting of five talents, Dem.; π. δίκη an action for the recovery of five talents, Ar.

div1.head: πεντετηρικός
div1.sense: happening every five years, quinquennial, Strab.

div1.head: πεντετηρίς
div1.sense: a term of five years, Lat. quinquennium, διὰ πεντετηρίδος every five years, Hdt.
a festival celebrated every five years, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: πεντέτης
div1.sense: of five years, σπονδαί Ar.

div1.head: πεντετριάζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to conquer five times, Anth.

div1.head: πεντηκοντάδραχμος
div1.sense: worth fifty drachmae, Plat.

div1.head: πεντηκονταετής
div1.sense: fifty years old, Plat.
of or lasting fifty years; fem., πεντηκονταέτιδες σπονδαί Thuc.

div1.head: πεντηκοντακαιτριέτης
div1.sense: of fifty-three years, Polyb.

div1.head: πεντηκοντακάρηνος
div1.sense: fifty-headed, Hes.

div1.head: πεντηκοντάπαις
div1.sense: consisting of fifty children, Aesch.
having fifty children, Aesch.

div1.head: πεντήκοντα
div1.sense: fifty, Lat. quinquaginta, Il., etc.

div1.head: πεντηκονταρχέω
div1.sense: to be a πεντηκόνταρχος, Dem.

div1.head: πεντηκόνταρχος
div1.sense: the commander of fifty men, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: πεντηκοντήρ
div1.sense: the commander of fifty men, an officer in the Spartan army, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πεντηκοντόγυος
div1.sense: of fifty acres of corn-land, Il.

div1.head: πεντηκοντόργυιος
div1.sense: fifty fathoms deep, high, long, Hdt.

div1.head: πεντηκόντορος
div1.sense: (sc. ναῦς) , a ship of burden with fifty oars, Pind., Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: πεντηκοντούτης
div1.sense: fifty years old, Plat.

div1.head: πεντηκόσιοι
div1.sense: five hundred, Od.

div1.head: πεντηκοστεύομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be charged with the tax πεντηκοστή on any articles, Dem.

div1.head: πεντηκοστολόγος
div1.sense: a collector of the tax πεντηκοστή, Dem.

div1.head: πεντηκοστός
div1.sense: fiftieth, Plat.
as Subst., ἡ πεντηκοστή,

(sc. μερίς) , at Athens the duty of one-fiftieth, or two per cent., on all exports and imports, Oratt.; εὕρηκε καινὴν ἱππικῆς τινὰ πεντηκοστήν he invented a new two per cent. duty, in lieu of his cavalry service, i. e. paid this instead of it, Dem.
(sc. ἡμέρα) , the fiftieth day (after the Passover), Pentecost, NTest.

div1.head: πεντηκοστύς
div1.sense: a number of fifty, esp. as a division of the Spartan army, Thuc.; κατὰ πεντηκοστῦς (acc. pl.) Xen.

div1.head: πεντήρης
div1.sense: (sc. ναῦς) , a quinquereme, Hdt.:—so, πεντηρικὸν, πλοῖον, σκάφος Polyb.:—v. τριήρης.

div1.head: πέντοζος
div1.sense: like πεντάοζος, with five branches: Hes. calls the hand πέντοζον, the five-branch.

div1.head: πεντόργυιος
div1.sense: of five fathoms, Anth.

div1.head: πέος
div1.sense: membrum virile, Ar., etc.

div1.head: πεπαίνω
div1.sense: to ripen, make ripe, Hdt.; absol., διασκοπῶν τὰς ἀμπέλους, εἰ πεπαίνουσιν ἤδη, i. e. if the grapes are ripening, Ar.:—Pass. to become ripe, Hdt., etc.
metaph. to soften, assuage anger, Ar., Xen.; of a person, ἢν πεπανθῆις Eur.

div1.head: πέπανος
div1.etym: rarer collat. form of πέπων, Anth.

div1.head: πεπαρεῖν
div1.sense: to display, manifest, only in Pind.

div1.head: πέπειρος
div1.sense: ripe, Lat. maturus, Anth.
metaph. softened, ὀργή Soph.

div1.head: πέπερι
div1.sense: pepper, the pepper-tree, Lat. piper.

div1.head: πεπλασμένως
div1.etym: from πέπλασμαι, perf. pass. of πλάσσω.
div1.sense: artificially, by pretence, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: πέπλος
div1.sense: in late Poets with heterog. pl. πέπλα, any woven cloth used for a covering, a sheet, carpet, curtain, veil, Il., Eur.
a robe, worn by women over the common dress, and falling in folds about the person, answering to the manʼs ἱμάτιον or χλαῖνα, Hom., etc.
esp. of the πέπλος of Athena, embroidered with mythol. subjects, which was carried like the sail of a galley in public procession at the Panathenaea, Eur., Plat.
a manʼs robe, Trag.; esp. of the long Persian dresses, Aesch.

div1.head: πέπλωμα
div1.sense: a robe, Trag.

div1.head: πέπνυμαι
div1.etym: old Epic perf. pass. of πνέω, with pres. sense
div1.sense: to have breath or soul, and metaph. to be wise, discreet, prudent, πέπνῡσαι νόωι Il.; inf. πεπνῦσθαι Hom.; 2 sg. plup. with imperf. sense, πέπνῡσο Od.; part. πεπνῡμένος, as adj., sage, wise, sagacious, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: πεποίθησις
div1.sense: trust, confidence, boldness, NTest.

div1.head: πέπων
div1.sense: of fruit, cooked by the sun, ripe, mellow, Lat. mitis, Hdt., Ar., etc.

metaph. in voc., mostly as a term of endearment, kind, gentle, ὦ πέπον my good friend, Il.; κριὲ πέπον my pet ram, Od.;— in bad sense, soft, weak, Il.; ὦ πέπονες ye weaklings, Il.: —μόχθος πέπων softened pain, Soph., etc.: c. dat., ἐχθροῖς π. gentle to oneʼs foes, Aesch.

div1.head: πέραθεν
div1.sense: from beyond, from the far side, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: περαίνω
div1.sense: to bring to an end, finish, accomplish, execute, Trag., etc.:—Pass. to be brought to an end, be finished, πάντα πεπείρανται Od.: to be fulfilled, accomplished, Eur. etc.
in speaking, to end a discourse, finish speaking, Aesch., etc.
to repeat from beginning to end, Ar.:— to relate, Eur.
absol. to effect oneʼs purpose, esp. with a neg., οὐδὲν π. to come to no issue, do no good, make no progress, Eur., Thuc.
intr. to make way, reach or penetrate, Aesch., Plat.
intr. to come to an end, end, Plut.

div1.head: περαῖος
div1.sense: on the other side:—as Subst., ἡ περαίη (sc. γῆ, χώρα) the opposite country, the country on the other side of a strait, Strab.; ἡ π. τῆς Βοιωτίης χώρης the part of Boeotia over against [Chalcis], Hdt.; ἡ π. τῶν Τενεδίων the coast [of Mysia] opposite Tenedos, Strab.

div1.head: περαιόω
div1.sense: to carry to the opposite side, carry over or across, στρατιὰν ἐπεραίωσε, Lat. trajecit exercitum, Thuc.:—Pass., with fut. mid., to pass over, cross, pass, Od., Ar., Thuc.;—also c. acc. loci, ἐπεραιώθη τὸν Ἀραξέα Hdt.; τὸ πέλαγος Thuc.

div1.head: περαίτερος
div1.sense: beyond, ὁδοὶ περαίτεραι roads leading further, Pind.
adv. περαιτέρω, further, Eur.; καὶ ἔτι π. Thuc.
c. gen., τῶνδε καὶ π. Aesch.; π. τοῦ μετρίου Xen.; and absol., π. (sc. τοῦ δέοντος) πεπραγμένα beyond what is fit, too far, Soph.

div1.head: περαίωσις
div1.sense: a carrying over, Strab.

div1.head: πέραν
div1.sense: on the other side, across, beyond, Lat. trans, c. gen., πέρην ἁλός Il.; τὰ πέρην τοῦ Ἴστρου Hdt.; πόντου πέραν Aesch.
absol. on the other side, Hdt., Xen.

with Verbs of motion, foll. by εἰς, over or across to, πέρην ἐς τὴν Ἀχαιίην διέπεμψαν Hdt.; πέραν εἰς τὴν Ἀσίαν διαβῆναι Xen.: also without εἰς, διαβαλόντες πέρην having crossed over to the main land, Hdt.
with the Art., διαβιβάζειν εἰς τὸ πέραν τοῦ ποταμοῦ Xen.; τὰ πέραν things done on the opposite side, Xen.:— ἡ πέραν γῆ the country just over the border, the border- country. Thuc.
over against, opposite, c. gen., πέρην Εὐβοίης Il.
= πέρα, beyond, c. gen., π. γε πόντου τερμόνων τʼ Ἀτλαντικῶν Eur.

div1.head: περαντικός
div1.sense: conclusive, logical, Ar.

div1.head: πέρα
div1.sense: beyond, across or over, further, Lat. ultra, Plat.
c. gen., Ἀτλαντικῶν πέρα ὅρων Eur.
of Time, beyond, longer, Xen.
c. gen., π. μεσούσης ἡμέρας Xen.
beyond measure, excessively, extravagantly, πέρα λέγειν, φράζειν Soph., etc.

c. gen. more than, beyond, exceeding, π. δίκης, καιροῦ Aesch.; π. τῶν νῦν εἰρημένων Soph.; θαυμάτων π. more than marvels, Eur.:—sometimes the gen. is omitted, ἄπιστα καὶ πέρα things incredible, and more than that, Ar.
also as comp., foll. by ἤ, Soph.
above, higher than, τῶν ἐχθρῶν πέρα Soph.

div1.head: περάσιμος
div1.sense: passable, Plut.

div1.head: πέρασις
div1.sense: a crossing, βίου πέρασις passage from life to death, Soph.

div1.head: πέρας
div1.sense: an end, limit, boundary, ἐκ περάτων γῆς Thuc.
an end, finish, οὐ π. ἔχων κακῶν Eur.; πέρας ἐστὶ τοῦ βίου θάνατος Dem.
an end, completion, Luc.
as adv., like τέλος, at length, at last, Aeschin., etc.

div1.head: πέρατος
div1.sense: on the opposite side:—as Subst., περάτη (sc. χώρα) an opposite land or quarter, esp. of the west, as opp. to the east, ἐν περάτῃ Od.

div1.head: περάω
div1.sense: to drive right through, λευκοὺς ἐπέρησεν ὀδόντας Il.

commonly, to pass across or through a space, to pass over, pass, cross, traverse, περᾶν θάλασσαν, πόντον Od.; πύλας πέρησεν passed through the gates, Il.; τάφρος ἀργαλέη περάαν hard to pass, Il.; τὰς φυλακὰς π. to pass the guards, Hdt.:—metaph., κίνδυνον π. to pass through, i. e. overcome, a danger, Aesch.; π. ὅρκον, prob. to go through the words of the oath, Lat. jusjurandum peragere, Aesch.
rarely of Time, to pass through, complete, τοῦ βίου τέρμα Soph.; τὴν τελευταίαν ἡμέραν Eur.
intr. to penetrate or pierce right through, of a weapon, Il.; of rain, Od.: to extend to a place, Xen.
to pass across, to pass, δι’ Ὠκεανοῖο Od.; ἐπὶ πόντον Il.; διὰ Κυανέας ἀκτάς through the Symplegades, Eur.
to pass to or from a place, εἰς Ἀΐδαο Theogn.; ἔξω δωμάτων Soph.:—c. acc. loci, π. Δελφούς Eur.
rarely of Time, διὰ γήρως π. Xen.; εὐδαίμων π. to live happy, Orac. ap. Xen.
to pass all bounds, to go too far, Soph.; so, π. ὀργῆς to pass all bounds in anger (or to cease from anger), Soph.
with instrument of motion in acc., π. πόδα, ἴχνος Eur.
div1.head: περάω
div1.sense: to carry beyond seas for the purpose of selling, to export for sale; then like πέρνημι, to sell men as slaves, Hom.; π. τινα Λῆμνον to sell one to Lemnos, Il.; or with a prep., π. τινὰ ἐς Λῆμνον Il.; π. τινὰ πρὸς δώματά τινος Od.

div1.head: Πέργαμος
div1.sense: Pergamus, the citadel of Troy, Il.; τὸ Πριάμου Πέργαμον Hdt.; τὰ Πέργαμα Soph., Eur., etc.: —then, any citadel, Aesch., Eur.
also Περγαμία, Pind.

div1.head: Περγασή
div1.sense: a deme of the φυλὴ Ἐρεχθηίς.

div1.head: Περγασῆσι
div1.sense: at Pergase, Ar.

div1.head: περδικοτρόφος
div1.sense: keeping partridges, Strab.

div1.head: πέρδιξ
div1.sense: a partridge, Lat. perdix, Soph.

div1.head: πέρδομαι
div1.sense: to break wind, Lat. pedere, Ar.

div1.head: πέρθω
div1.etym: syncop. aor2 inf. πέρθαι, like δέχθαι from δέχομαι
div1.sense: to waste, ravage, sack, destroy, a town, Hom.
of persons, to destroy, slay, Pind., Soph.:—metaph. of love, Eur.
of things, to destroy, Aesch., Soph.
to get by plunder, Il., Eur.

div1.head: περιαγής
div1.sense: broken in pieces, Anth.
= περιηγής, quite round, Anth.

div1.head: περιαγνίζω
div1.sense: to purify all round, Luc.

div1.head: περιάγνυμι
div1.sense: to bend and break all round: Pass., ὂψ περιάγνυται the voice is broken all round, i. e. spreads all round, Il.

div1.head: περιάγω
div1.sense: to lead or draw round, Hdt.
to lead about with one, have always by one, Xen.; so in Mid., Xen.
to turn round, turn about, τὴν κεφαλήν Ar., etc.:— π. τὴν σκυταλίδα to twist it round in order to tighten a noose, Hdt.
to put off, Luc.
to bring round to a point, πρός τι Arist., etc.
c. acc. loci, to go round, περιάγουσι τὴν λίμνην κύκλῳ Hdt.; π. τὰς πόλεις NTest.

div1.head: περιαγωγεύς
div1.sense: a windlass, capstan, Luc.

div1.head: περιαγωγή
div1.sense: a going round, a revolution, Plat.

div1.head: περιᾴδω
div1.sense: to go about singing, Luc.

div1.head: περιαιρετός
div1.sense: that may be taken off, Thuc.

div1.head: περιαιρέω
div1.sense: to take off something that surrounds, take off an outer coat, take away, strip off, τὰ τείχη Hdt., Thuc.; π. τὸν κέραμον taking off the earthen jar into which the gold had been run, Hdt.:—Mid. to take off from oneself, π. τὴν κυνέην to take off oneʼs helmet, Hdt.; βιβλίον περιαιρεόμενος taking [the cover] off the letter, i. e. opening it, Hdt.:—but Mid. often just like Act. to strip off, take away, Xen., Plat.:—Pass. to be taken off, τοῦ ἄλλου περιῃρημένου when the rest has been taken away, Thuc.
Pass. also c. acc. rei, to be stript of a thing, περιῃρημένοι χρήματα καὶ συμμάχους Dem.; τοὺς στεφάνους περιῄρηνται Dem.

div1.head: περιακτέος
div1.sense: one must bring round, Plat.

div1.head: περιαλγέω
div1.sense: to be greatly pained at, τινί Thuc.

div1.head: περιαλγής
div1.sense: much pained, very sorrowful, Plat.

div1.head: περιαλείφω
div1.sense: to smear all over, anoint, Ar.

div1.head: περίαλλος
div1.sense: before all others; in adv. περίαλλα, before all, Hhymn., Pind.: exceedingly, Soph.

div1.head: περιαλουργός
div1.sense: with purple all round, κακοῖς π. double-dyed in villany, Ar.

div1.head: περίαμμα
div1.sense: anything worn about one, an amulet, Anth.

div1.head: περιαμπέχω
div1.sense: to put round about, π. τινά τι to put a thing round or over one, Ar.:—Mid. to put round oneself, put on, Plat.
to cover all round, Plat.

div1.head: περιαμύνω
div1.sense: to defend or guard all round, Plut.

div1.head: περίαπτος
div1.sense: hung round one: as Subst., περίαπτον, τό, περίαμμα, Plat.: an appendage, Arist.

div1.head: περιάπτω
div1.sense: to tie, fasten, hang about or upon, apply to, γυίοις φάρμακα περάπτων (Aeolic form) Pind.: —Mid. to put round oneself, put on to wear, Plat.
metaph., π. τιμάς, αἶσχός τινι to attach to one, Ar.; ἀντὶ καλῆς δόξης αἰσχρὰν π. τῇ πόλει Dem.
to light a fire all round or in the midst, NTest.

div1.head: περιαρμόζω
div1.sense: to fit on all round, τί τινι Plut.

div1.head: περιαρτάω
div1.sense: to hang round or on:—Pass. to be hung round, c. dat., Plut.

div1.head: περιαστράπτω
div1.sense: to flash around, c. acc., NTest.

div1.head: περιασχολέω
div1.sense: to be busy about a thing, Luc.

div1.head: περιαυχένιος
div1.sense: put round the neck, Hdt.

div1.head: περιβαίνω
div1.sense: to go round, of one defending a fallen comrade, either to walk round and round him, or, like ἀμφιβαίνω, to bestride him, absol., Il.; c. gen., περιβῆναι ἀδελφειοῦ κταμένοιο Il.; also, c. dat., Πατρόκλῳ περιβάς Il.; so, περὶ τρόπιος βεβαῶτα astride of the keel, Od.; c. acc., π. ἵππον to bestride a horse, Plut.
of sound, to come round oneʼs ears, Soph.

div1.head: περιβάλλω
div1.sense: to throw round, περὶ χαῖρε βαλών having thrown his arms round him, Od.; χέρας π. τινί Eur.; περὶ δʼ ὠλένας δέρᾳ βάλοιμι Eur.; π. τινὶ δεσμά Aesch.; π. ναῦν περὶ ἕρμα to wreck it on a reef, Thuc.:—Mid. to throw round oneself, put on, c. acc. rei, τεύχεα περιβαλλόμενοι putting on their arms, Od.; π. ἔρυμα, ἕρκος, τείχεα to throw round oneself for defence, Hdt.; c. dupl. acc., τεῖχος περιβάλλεσθαι πόλιν to build a wall round it, Hdt.:—in perf. pass. to have a thing put round one, Plat.; περιβεβλημένος τὸ τεῖχος having his wall around him, Plat.
metaph. to put round a person, i. e. invest him with it, π. τινὶ βασιληίην, τυραννίδα Plat., Eur.; δουλείαν Μυκήναις Eur.; π. ἀνανδρίαν τινί, i. e. to make him faint-hearted, Eur.

reversely, c. dat. rei, to surround, encompass, enclose with, περιβάλλειν βρόχῳ τὸν αὐχένα Hdt.; τινὰ πέπλοις Eur.; π. τινὰ χερσί to embrace, Eur.:—metaph., π. τινὰ συμφοραῖς, κακοῖς to involve one in calamities, evils, etc., Eur.:—so in Mid. to surround or enclose for oneself, Xen.
π. τινὰ χαλκεύματι to put him round the sword, i. e. stab him, Aesch.

c. acc. only, to encompass, surround, περιβάλλει με σκότος Eur.; π. τινά to embrace him, Xen.; but also to clothe, NTest.:—Pass., τὸ περιβεβλημένον the space enclosed, enclosure, Hdt.:—Mid., ἤλαυνον περιβαλλόμενοι τὰ ὑποζύγια surrounding them, Hdt.
to fetch a compass round, double, c. acc., ἵπποι περὶ τέρμα βαλοῦσαι Il.; of ships, π. τὸν Ἄθων Hdt., etc.
to frequent, be fond of a place, Xen.
Mid. to bring into oneʼs power, aim at, Lat. affectare, as we say "to compass" a thing, π. ἑωυτῷ κέρδεα Hdt.; σωφροσύνης δόξαν π. Xen.:—perf. pass. to have come into possession of a thing, Hdt.
to cloke or veil in words, Plat.
to throw beyond, and so, generally, to excel, surpass, μνηστῆρας δώροισι Od.; or, simply, π. ἀρετῇ to be superior in virtue, Il.

div1.head: περίβαρυς
div1.sense: exceeding heavy, Aesch.

div1.head: περιβιόω
div1.sense: to survive, Plut.

div1.head: περίβλεπτος
div1.sense: looked at from all sides, admired of all observers, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: περιβλέπω
div1.sense: intr. to look round about, gaze around, Xen., etc.
trans. to look round at, πάντας Xen.: so in Mid., NTest.
to seek after, look about for, τινά or τι Luc.
to gaze on, admire, respect, Soph.; π. βίαν to be jealous of, suspect force, or to covet it, Eur.:—Pass., περιβλέπεσθαι τίμιον, Lat. digito monstrari, Eur.

div1.head: περίβλεψις
div1.sense: a looking about: close examination, Plut.

div1.head: περιβόητος
div1.sense: poet. περί-βωτος, noised abroad, much talked of, famous, Thuc., Dem.
in bad sense, notorious, scandalous, Dem.:—adv. -τως, notoriously, Aeschin., Dem.
with or amid shouts, epith. of Ares, Soph.

div1.head: περιβόλαιον
div1.sense: that which is thrown round, a covering, θανάτου περιβόλαια corpse-clothes, Eur.; π. σαρκὸς ἡβῶντα youthful incasements of flesh, i. e. youth, manhood, Eur.: a chariot-cover, Plut.

div1.head: περιβολή
div1.sense: anything which is thrown round, a covering, Plat.; χειρῶν περιβολαί embraces, Eur.; so περιβολαί alone, Xen.; περιβολαὶ χθονός, i. e. the grave, Eur.; π. ξίφεος a scabbard, Eur.: absol. of walls round a town, ἑπτάπυργοι π. Eur.
a space enclosed, compass, οἰκίης μεγάλης περιβολή a house of large compass, Hdt.
a circumference, circuit, Thuc.; π. ποιεῖσθαι to make a circuit, Xen.
metaph.,
a compassing, endeavouring after, τῆς ἀρχῆς, Lat. affectatio imperii, Xen.
ἡ π. τοῦ λόγου the whole compass of the matter, long and short of it, Isocr.

div1.head: περίβολος
div1.sense: going round, compassing, encircling, Eur.
as Subst., περίβολος περιβολή, ἐχίδνης περίβολοι the spires or coils of a serpent, Eur.; in pl. walls round a town, Hdt., Eur.; so in sg., Thuc.
an enclosure, circuit, compass, π. νεωρίων Eur.; of a temple, the precincts, Plut.

div1.head: περιβόσκομαι
div1.sense: :—Mid.-Pass., of cattle, to feed on all round, c. acc., Luc.

div1.head: περιβραχιόνιος
div1.sense: round or on the arm, Plut.:— περιβραχιόνιον, ου, an armlet or piece of armour for the arm, Xen.

div1.head: περιβρύχιος
div1.sense: engulfed by the surge all round, οἴδματα π. waves swallowed up by one another, i. e. wave upon wave, Soph.

div1.head: περιβύω
div1.sense: to stop up round about, to stuff in all round, τί τινι Luc.

div1.head: περιγίγνομαι
div1.sense: to be superior to others, to prevail over, overcome, excel, c. gen., ἡνίοχος περιγίγνεται ἡνιόχοιο Il., etc.; rarely c. acc., π. Ἕλληνας Hdt.:—absol. to be superior, prevail, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
of things, ἤν τι περιγένηταί σφι τοῦ πολέμου if they gain any advantage in the war, Thuc.; π. ὑμῖν πλῆθος νεῶν you have a superiority in number of ships, Thuc.

to live over, get over, to survive, escape, Lat. salvus evadere, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; οἱ περιγενόμενοι the survivors, Hdt.; also c. gen. rei, περιεγένετο τούτου τοῦ πάθεος he survived this disaster, Hdt.
of things, to remain over and above, Ar., Xen.
of things also, to be a result or consequence, ἐκ τῶν μεγίστων κινδύνων μέγισται τιμαὶ περιγίγνονται Thuc.; περιγίγνεταί τι the upshot of the matter is so and so, Dem.

div1.head: περιγλαγής
div1.sense: full of milk, Il.

div1.head: περιγληνάομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to turn round the eyeballs, glare around, of a lion, Theocr.

div1.head: περίγλωσσος
div1.sense: ready of tongue, Pind.

div1.head: περιγνάμπτω
div1.sense: to double a headland, Μάλειαν Od.

div1.head: περίγραμμα
div1.sense: a line drawn round a ring, Luc.

div1.head: περιγραπτέος
div1.sense: one must trace out, Plat.

div1.head: περιγραπτός
div1.sense: marked round, ἐκ περιγραπτοῦ from a circumscribed space, Thuc.

div1.head: περιγραφή
div1.sense: a line drawn round, an outline, sketch, Plat., Arist.
a circumference, circuit, Arist.
that which is marked by an outline, a contour, π. ποδοῖν Aesch.
dress, Luc.

div1.head: περιγράφω
div1.sense: to draw a line round, mark round, Lat. circumscribo, Hdt.; π. κύκλον to draw a circle round, Hdt.:—absol. to draw a circle, Ar.
to define, determine, Xen.:—Pass., περιεγέγραπτο, limits had been drawn, Xen.
to draw in outline, sketch out, Lat. delineare, Arist.
to enclose as it were within brackets, to cancel, Anth.; π. τινὰ ἐκ πολιτείας to exclude from civic privileges, Aeschin.

div1.head: περιδεής
div1.sense: very timid or fearful, Hdt.; τινος of or for a person or thing, Thuc.; π. μὴ . . , Thuc.:— adv. -ῶς, in great fear, Thuc.

div1.head: περιδείδια
div1.sense: to be in great fear about, c. gen., Δαναῶν περιδείδια Il.; c. dat. to be in great fear for, Αἴαντι περιδδείσαντες Il.; ἐμῇ κεφαλῇ περιδείδια Il.

div1.head: περιδέξιος
div1.sense: with two right hands, i.e. using both hands alike, Il.
very dexterous, Ar.

div1.head: περιδέραιος
div1.sense: passed round the neck: as Subst., περιδέραιον, ου, a necklace, Arist., Plut.

div1.head: περιδέω
div1.sense: to bind, tie round or on, τί τινι Hdt.:—Mid. to bind round oneself, put on, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: περιδίδομαι
div1.etym: Mid. of περιδίδωμι, which does not occur
div1.sense: to stake or wager, c. gen. rei (i. e. pretii), τρίποδος περιδώμεθα ἠὲ λέβητος let us make a wager of a tripod, i. e. let us wager a tripod (to be paid by the loser), Il.; ἐμέθεν περιδώσομαι αὐτῆς I will wager for myself, i. e. pledge myself, Od.; π. πότερον to lay a wager whether, Ar.; so, περιδίδομαι περὶ τῆς κεφαλῆς I stake my head, Ar.; c. dat. pers. added, περίδου μοι περὶ θυματιδᾶν ἁλῶν have a wager with me for a little thyme-salt, Ar.; περίδου νῦν ἐμοί Ar.

div1.head: περιδινέω
div1.sense: to whirl or wheel round, Aeschin.: —Pass. to run circling round, πόλιν περιδινηθήτην (3 dual aor1 pass.) Il.:—so in Mid., Anth.; to spin round like a top, Xen.

div1.head: περιδίνησις
div1.sense: a whirling round, Plat.

div1.head: περιδίω
div1.sense: to be in great fear for, c. dat., only in 3rd sg. imperf., περὶ γὰρ δίε νηυσὶν Ἀχαιῶν Il., etc.

div1.head: περιδιώκω
div1.sense: to pursue on all sides, Strab.

div1.head: περιδράσσομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to grasp a thing with the hand, c. gen. rei, Plut.

div1.head: περιδινής
div1.sense: whirled round, Anth.

div1.head: περιδρομή
div1.sense: a running round, Plut.; π. ποιεῖσθαι to wheel about, Xen.
a revolution, orbit, Eur.

div1.head: περίδρομος
div1.sense: running round, of a chariot-rail, of the nave of a wheel, Il.; of the rim of a shield, Eur.
going about, roaming, Theogn., Ar.
pass. that can be run round, and so standing apart, detached, Hom.

div1.head: περίδρομος2
div1.sense: as Subst. that which surrounds, as the rim of a shield, Eur.; the string that runs round the top of a net (cf. ἐπίδρομος) , Xen.; a gallery running round a building, Xen.

div1.head: περιδρύπτω
div1.sense: to tear all round, to peel the bark off a tree, Anth.:—Pass., ἀγκῶνας περιδρύφθη (Epic aor. 1 pass.) he had the skin all torn from off his arms, Il.

div1.head: περιδύω
div1.sense: to pull off from round, strip off, περίδυσε χιτῶνας Il.

div1.head: περιείλω
div1.sense: to fold or wrap round, σακκία περὶ τοὺς πόδας Xen.
to wrap up, swathe:—Mid. to swathe oneself, περιειλάμενος (aor1 part.), Ar.

div1.head: περίειμι
div1.sense: to be around a place, c. dat., Thuc.; τὰ περιόντα circumstances, Dem.

to be better than, superior to another, surpass, excel, c. gen., Il., Hdt.; περίεσσι γυναικῶν εἶδός τε μέγεθός τε Od.; οἳ περὶ μὲν βουλὴν Δαναῶν, περὶ δ’ ἐστὲ μάχεσθα ( = μάχην) Il.; c. dat. rei, σοφίᾳ π. τῶν Ἑλλήνων Plat.: absol. to be superior, Hdt., etc.; ἐκ περιόντος at an advantage, Thuc.
to overlive, outlive, τινι Hdt.: absol. to survive, remain alive, Hdt., Dem., etc.:—of things, to be extant, to be in existence, Hdt.
to be over and above, to remain in hand, of property, money, etc., Thuc.; οἰόμενοι περιεῖναι χρήματά τῳ imagining that any one has a balance in his hands, Dem.

to be a result or consequence, περίεστιν ὑμῖν ἐκ τούτων what you have got by all this is . . , Dem.; τοσοῦτον ὑμῖν περίεστιν τοῦ πρὸς ἐμὲ μίσους you have so much hatred against me left, Philipp. ap. Dem.; c. inf., περίεστι ὑμῖν αὐτοῖς ἐρίζειν it remains for you to quarrel with them, Dem.

div1.head: περίειμι
div1.sense: to go round fetch a compass, Hdt.; π. κατὰ νώτου τινί to get round and take him in rear, Thuc.:— to go about with idle questions or stories, Dem.
c. acc. loci, to go round, compass, π. τὸν νηὸν κύκλῳ Hdt.; π. φυλακάς to go round the guards, visit them, Hdt.:—of sounds, αὐλῶν σε περίεισιν πνοή Ar.
to come round to one, in succession or by inheritance, ἢ ἀρχή, βασιληίη περίεισι εἴς τινα Hdt.
of revolving periods, χρόνου περιιόντος as time came round, Hdt.; περιιόντι τῷ θέρει Thuc.

div1.head: περιείρω
div1.sense: to insert or fix round, Hdt.

div1.head: περιεκτικός
div1.sense: grasping, Luc.

div1.head: περιέλασις
div1.sense: a place for driving round, a roadway, Hdt.

div1.head: περιελαύνω
div1.sense: to drive round, τὰς κύλικας π. to push the cups round, Xen.
to drive about, harass, Ar.:—Pass., Hdt.
to draw or build round, περὶ δʼ ἕρκος ἔλασσε Il.:—Pass., περὶ δʼ ἕρκος ἐλήλαται Od.
seemingly intr. (sub. ἅρμα, ἵππον) , to drive or ride round, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: περιελίσσω
div1.sense: to roll or wind round, τι περί τι Hdt.:—Mid., π. ἱμάντας to wind caestus straps round oneʼs arms, Plat.:— Pass. to be wound round, περιελιχθέντα περὶ τὴν γῆν Plat.

div1.head: περιέλκω
div1.sense: to drag round, drag about, Xen.
to draw round another way, κύκλῳ π. τινά, Lat. huc illuc ducere, Plat.:—Pass., Plat.

div1.head: περιέννυμι
div1.sense: to put round, περὶ εἵματα ἕσσον Il.; περὶ τεύχεα ἕσσεν Il.: Mid., χλαῖναν περιέσσασθαι to put on oneʼs cloak, Hes.

div1.head: περιέπω
div1.sense: to treat with great care:
in good sense, εὖ π. τινά to treat him well, Hdt.; ὡς κάλλιστα π. τινά Hdt.; π. τινὰ ὡς εὐεργέτην Xen.: alone also, to treat with respect or honour, to caress, Lat. colo, foveo, Xen.
in bad sense, τρηχέως, κάρτα τρηχέως π. to treat, handle roughly, Hdt.; π. τινὰ ὡς πολέμιον Hdt.:—Pass., τρηχέως περιεφθῆναι ὑπό τινος Hdt.

div1.head: περιεργάζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:

to take more pains than enough about a thing, to waste oneʼs labour on it, with a part., Σωκράτης περιεργάζεται ζητῶν Plat.; περιείργασμαι περὶ τούτων εἰπών Dem.:—c. dat. modi, τῷ θυλάκῳ περιειργάσθαι that they had overdone it with their "sack" (i. e. need not have used the word), Hdt.:—perf. in pass. sense, οὐδὲ περιείργασται nor is there any superfluity, Luc.
to be a busybody, meddle with other folkʼs affairs, Dem.

div1.head: περιεργία
div1.sense: over-exactness in doing anything, Luc.
intermeddling, officiousness, Theophr., Luc.

div1.head: περίεργος
div1.sense: careful overmuch, Lys., etc.
busy about other folkʼs affairs, meddling, a busybody, Xen.
pass. done with especial care, elaborate, Aeschin., etc.
superfluous, Plat., etc.
curious, superstitious, Plut.

div1.head: περιέργω
div1.sense: to inclose all round, encompass, Hdt., Thuc.:—Pass., ἐν περιειργμένοις παραδείσοις in enclosed parks, Xen.

div1.head: περιέρχομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:

to go round, go about, Hdt., Attic:— to go about, like a beggar, Xen.; like a canvasser, Lat. ambire, Dem.:—c. part. to go about doing a thing, Plat.:—c. acc. cogn., π. στάδια χίλια Ar.:—c. acc. loci, π. τὸν βωμόν to go round the altar, Ar.; τὴν ἀγοράν Dem.
c. acc. pers. to come round, encompass, of sounds, περὶ κτύπος ἦλθε ποδοῖιν the sound of feet came round him, Od.; of the effect of wine, Κύκλωπα περὶ φρένας ἤλυθεν οἶνος Od.
like Lat. circumvenire, to take in, to overreach, cheat, Hdt., Ar.

to go round and return to a point, come round, ἡ βασιληίη περιῆλθε ἔς τινα Hdt.; ἐς φθίσιν περιῆλθε ἡ νοῦσος the disease ended in . . , Hdt.; c. acc., ἡ τίσις περιῆλθε τὸν Πανιώνιον vengeance came at last upon him, Hdt.
of Time, to come round, Xen.

div1.head: περιεσθίω
div1.sense: to eat all round, eat away, nibble at, Luc.

div1.head: περιέσχατα
div1.sense: the surrounding extremities, Hdt.

div1.head: περίεφθος
div1.sense: thoroughly well cooked, Luc.

div1.head: περιέχω
div1.sense: to encompass, embrace, surround, Plat.
to surround so as to guard, Plut.
in Pass. to be shut in or beleaguered, ὑπό τινος Hdt., Xen.
to embrace, comprise, comprehend, Plat., etc.
to overcome, gain the victory, Thuc.: of an army, to outflank the enemy, Thuc.
Mid. to hold oneʼs arms round another, take charge of, c. gen. pers., περίσχεο (Ionic aor2 mid. imperat.) παιδὸς ἐῆος Il.; c. acc. to protect, Od.
to cling to, be fond of a person or thing, c. gen., Hdt.
c. inf., περιείχετο μὴ ἐκλιπεῖν he was urgent with them that they should not leave him, Hdt.

div1.head: περιζαμενῶς
div1.sense: very violently, Hhymn.

div1.head: περιζέω
div1.sense: to boil round, Luc.; poet. -ζείω Anth.

div1.head: περίζυγον
div1.sense: a spare strap, Xen.

div1.head: περίζωμα
div1.sense: a girdle round the loins, apron, Plut.

div1.head: περιζώννυμι
div1.sense: to gird round oneself, gird oneself with, ἐσθῆτα Plut.; τοῦτον τὸν ἄνδρα περιεζώσατο put him on as a defence, Ar.; περιεζῶσθαι τὴν φορβείαν to have their halter girded round them, Arist.

div1.head: περιζώστρα
div1.sense: a ribbon twined round a garland, Theocr.

div1.head: περιηγέομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:
to lead round, π. τινι τὸ οὖρος to shew one the way round the mountain, Hdt.
to explain, describe, Luc.

div1.head: περιήγησις
div1.sense: like περιγραφή, an outline, contour, Hdt.
a leading round and explaining what is worth notice, a full description, such as is given by guides and cicerones, Luc.:— geographical description, Strab.

div1.head: περιηγής
div1.sense: = περιαγής II: of the arms, tied behind one, Anth.

div1.head: περιηγητής
div1.sense: one who guides strangers about and shews what is worth notice, a cicerone, showman, Luc.:— a describer of geographical details, Luc.

div1.head: περιήκω
div1.sense: to have come round to one, τὰ σὲ περιήκοντα that which has fallen to thy lot, Hdt.; τοῦτον τὸν ἄνδρα φαμὲν περιήκειν τὰ πρῶτα we say that the greatest luck befel this man, Hdt.
of Time, to have come round, Plut.

div1.head: περιήλυσις
div1.sense: a coming round, encompassing, Plut.
a revolution, Hdt.

div1.head: περιημεκτέω
div1.sense: to be much aggrieved, to chafe greatly at, c. dat., Hdt.; c. gen. pers. to be aggrieved at or with him, Hdt. (Deriv. of -ημεκτέω uncertain.)

div1.head: περιηχέω
div1.sense: to ring all round, Il.:—so in Mid., νῆσος περιηχουμένη τῷ κύματι Luc.

div1.head: περιήχησις
div1.sense: a resounding, echoing, Plut.

div1.head: περιθαμβής
div1.sense: much alarmed, Plut.

div1.head: περίθεσις
div1.sense: a putting on, NTest.

div1.head: περίθετος
div1.sense: put round, περιθεταὶ τρίχες false hair, Polyb.

div1.head: περιθέω
div1.sense: to run round, Hom., Hdt.; c. acc. loci, Hdt., Xen.
to run about, Lat. discurro, Ar., Plat.
to rotate, revolve, ἀσπίδος αἰεὶ περιθεούσης, i. e. as he was always swaying his shield round and round, Hdt.

div1.head: περιθεωρέω
div1.sense: to go round and observe, Luc.

div1.head: περιθρηνέομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to resound with wailing, Plut.

div1.head: περιθριγκόω
div1.sense: to edge or fence all round, Plut.

div1.head: περίθυμος
div1.sense: very wrathful, Aesch. adv. -μως, Aesch.; περιθύμως ἔχειν to be very angry, Hdt.

div1.head: περιιάπτω
div1.sense: to wound all round, περὶ θυμὸς ἰάφθη (3 sg. aor1 pass.) Theocr.

div1.head: περιιάχω
div1.sense: to ring around, re-echo, Od.; Epic imperf. περίαχε [ῑ], for περιίαχε, Hes.

div1.head: περιίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to sit round about, Hdt.; c. acc., Hdt.

div1.head: περιιππεύω
div1.sense: to ride round, Polyb.

div1.head: περιίστημι
div1.sense: in the trans. tenses, fut. -στήσω, aor1 -έστησα, to place round, π. τί τινι Hdt.; στρατὸν περὶ πόλιν Xen.:—metaph., π. τινὶ πλείω κακά Dem.
to bring round, π. πολιτείαν εἰς ἑαυτόν to bring it round to himself, Arist.:—esp. to bring into a worse state, Aeschin.
in aor1 mid. to place round oneself, Xen.
Pass. and Mid., with aor2 act. -έστην, perf. -έστηκα, plup. -έστηκειν, to stand round about, Il.; κῦμα περιστάθη a wave rose around (Epic aor1 pass.), Od.
c. acc. to stand round, encircle, surround, Hom.; μήπως με περιστήωσʼ ἕνα πολλοί (Epic 3rd pl. aor2 subj.), that their numbers surround me not, Il.; metaph., τὸ περιεστὸς ἡμᾶς δεινόν Thuc.
to come round to one, νομίσαντες τὸ παρανόμημα ἐς τοὺς Ἀθηναίους περιεστάναι Thuc.:—c. dat. to come upon one, ἡμῖν ἀδοξία περιέστη Thuc.; τοῦ πολέμου περιεστηκότος τοῖς Θηβαίοις Dem.
