div1.sense: a small tablet, on which the δικασταί wrote their verdict, π. τιμητικόν, Lat. tabella damnatoria, Ar.;—on which a law was written, Ar.; —on which the information in case of εἰσαγγελία was written, Dem.;—on which the rules for the δικασταί were written, Dem.:— tablets, a memorandum book, Plat.
a tablet for painting upon, Luc.

div1.head: πινακίς
div1.sense: in pl., tablets, Plut.

div1.head: πινακοθήκη
div1.sense: a picture-gallery, Strab.

div1.head: πινακοπώλης
div1.sense: one who sells small birds plucked and ranged upon a board, Ar.

div1.head: πίναξ
div1.sense: a board, plank, of a ship, Od.
a tablet for writing on, Il., Plat., etc.
a trencher, platter, Od.
a panel, picture, Lat. tabula, Simon.: generally, an engraved plate, of a map, Hdt.
a register, list, Lat. album, Dem., etc.

div1.head: πιναρός
div1.sense: dirty, squalid, Eur.

div1.head: Πινδάρειος
div1.sense: of Pindar, Ar.

div1.head: Πινδόθεν
div1.sense: from Mount Pindus, Pind.

div1.head: πίνη
div1.sense: the pinna, a bivalve, with a silky beard, Com.

div1.head: πινοτήρης
div1.sense: the pinna-guard, a small crab that lives in the pinnaʼs shell, like the hermit-crab: metaph. of a little parasitical fellow, Ar.

div1.head: πινόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be rusted, of statues, Plut.

div1.head: πίνος
div1.sense: dirt, filth, Lat. squalor, Soph., Eur.; metaph., σὺν πίνῳ χερῶν, i.e. by foul means, Aesch.

div1.head: πινύσκω
div1.sense: to make prudent, admonish, correct, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: πινυτή
div1.sense: understanding, wisdom, Hom.

div1.head: πινυτός
div1.sense: wise, prudent, discreet, understanding, Od., Solon.

div1.head: πινυτόφρων
div1.sense: of wise or understanding mind, Anth.

div1.head: πινώδης
div1.sense: dirty, foul, Eur.

div1.head: πίνω
div1.sense: to drink, Hom., etc.; π. ὕδωρ Αἰσήποιο to drink its water, i. e. live on its banks, Il.;—or c. gen. partit. to drink of a thing, π. οἴνοιο (as Fr. du vin), Od.; αἵματος ὄφρα πίω Od.:—also, πίνειν κρητῆρας οἴνοιο to drink bowls of wine, Il.; π. ἀπὸ κρήνης to drink of a spring, Theogn.; δέπα, ἔνθεν ἔπινον Od.; π. ἐκ ταὐτοῦ ποτηρίου Ar.; ἐξ ἀργύρου ἢ χρυσοῦ Plat.; ἀπὸ τοῦ ποταμοῦ Xen.: —also, σκύφον ὧιπερ ἔπινον with which . . , Od.:— absol., Hom., etc.; πῖνε, πῖνʼ ἐπὶ συμφοραῖς Ar.; διδόναι πιεῖν to give to drink, Hdt.; πιεῖν αἰτεῖν Xen.:— in perf. πέπωκα, to be drunk, Eur.; but, πίνοντά τε καὶ πεπωκότα drinking and having finished drinking, Plat.
metaph. to drink up, as the earth does rain, Hdt.; πιοῦσα κόνις μέλαν αἷμα Aesch., etc.

div1.head: πῖος
div1.sense: unctuous, Hdt.

div1.head: πῖ
div1.sense: Π, π, πῖ, indecl.: sixteenth letter of Gr. alphabet. As numeral π 80, but , π 80, 000. π is the tenuis labial mute, related to the medial β and the aspirate φ. Changes of π in the Gr. dialects, etc.
π becomes φ, βλέπ-ω βλέφ-αρον, λάπ-τω λαφ-ύσσω.

in Aeolic and Ionic, it stands for the asp. φ, ἀμπί for ἀμφί, πανός for φανός, ἀπικέσθαι for ἀφικ-: in Ionic it was retained in apostrophe before an aspirate, ἀπʼ ἡμῶν, ἐπʼ ἡμέρην, ὑπʼ ὑμῶν, etc.: on the contrary the aspirated form was preferred in Attic, ἀσφάραγος for ἀσπάραγος, σφόνδυλος for σπόνδυλος.
in Ionic Prose, π becomes κ in relatives and interrogatives, κῶς ὅκως ὁκοῖος ὁκόσος for πῶς ὅπως ὁποῖος ὁπόσος.
in Aeolic, π is used for μ, ὄππα for ὄμμα, πεδά for μετά.
in Aeolic and Doric, π for τ, πέτορες for τέσσαρες, πέμπε for πέντε.
sometimes interchanged with γ, as in λαπαρός λαγαρός, λαπάρα λαγών, λάγος lepus.
in Aeolic and Epic Poetry, π is often doubled in relatives, as ὅππη ὅππως ὁπποῖος for ὅπη, etc.
in Poets, τ is inserted after π, as in πτόλις, πτόλεμος for πόλις, πόλεμος.

div1.head: πιπίσκω
div1.sense: to give to drink, πίσω σφε Δίρκας ὕδωρ I will make them drink the water of Dirce, Pind.

div1.head: πιπράσκω
div1.etym: πιπράσκω shortd. from πιπεράσκω, redupl. form of περάω
div1.sense: to sell, Dem.:— Pass. to be sold, esp. for exportation, Hdt., Attic
to sell for a bribe, of political leaders, Dem.:—metaph. in Pass., πέπραμαι I am bought and sold! i. e. betrayed, ruined, undone, Soph.

div1.head: πίπτω
div1.sense: to fall, fall down, Hom., etc.; πίπτειν ἐν κονίηισιν to fall in the dust, i. e. to fall and lie there, Il.; π. ἐν δεμνίοις Eur., etc.; or without ἐν, πεδίωι πίπτειν Il.; π. δεμνίοις Eur.; also, π. ἐπὶ χθονί Od.; ἐπὶ γᾶι Soph.; πρὸς πέδωι Eur.; with a Prep. of motion, π. ἐς πόντον Hes.; ἐπὶ γᾶν Aesch.; πρὸς οὖδας Eur.
Special usages:
πίπτειν ἔν τισι to fall violently upon, attack, ἐνὶ νήεσσι πέσωμεν Il.; πρὸς μῆλα καὶ ποίμνας Soph.
to throw oneself down, fall down, πρὸς βρέτη θεῶν Aesch.; ἀμφὶ γόνυ τινός Eur.
to fall in battle, πίπτε δὲ λαός Il., etc.; οἱ πεπτωκότες the fallen, Xen.; π. δορί by the spear, Eur.; —π. ὑπό τινος to fall by anotherʼs hand, Hdt.
to fall, be ruined, ὁ hέρξεω στρατὸς αὐτὸς ὑπʼ ἑωυτοῦ ἔπεσε, Lat. mole sua corruit, Hdt.
to fall, sink, ἄνεμος πέσε the wind fell (so Virg. cadunt austri), Od.
to fall short, fail, Plat.; of a play, to fail, Ar.

ἐκ θυμοῦ πίπτειν τινί to fall out of his favour, Il.; so, π. ἐξ ἐλπίδων Eur.: —reversely, π. ἐς κακότητα Theogn.; εἰς νόσον Aesch.; φόβον, ἀνάγκας Eur., Thuc., etc.; also, π. ἐν φόβωι Eur.; π. δυσπραξίαις Soph.
π. εἰς ὕπνον to fall asleep, Soph.; or simply ὕπνωι Aesch.
πίπτειν μετὰ ποσσὶ γυναικός to fall between her feet, i. e. to be born, Il.
of the dice, τὰ δεσποτῶν εὖ πεσόντα θήσομαι I shall count my masterʼs throws good or lucky, Aesch.; so of lots, ὁ κλῆρος π. τινί or παρά τινα Plat.; ἐπί τινα NTest.
generally, to fall, turn out, εὖ, καλῶς πίπτειν to be lucky, Eur., etc.
to fall under, belong to a class, Arist.

div1.head: Πισαῖος
div1.sense: of or from Pisa, Anth.

div1.head: Πῖσα
div1.note: Πῖσα, or Πίση, Doric Πίσα, ης, ἡ,
div1.sense: Pisa, name of a fountain at Olympia, Hdt., Pind.

div1.head: Πισάτης
div1.sense: a person from Pisa, Pind.

div1.head: Πίσηθεν
div1.sense: from Pisa, Anth.

div1.head: πίσινος
div1.sense: made of peas, ἔτνος π. pea-soup, Ar.

div1.head: πῖσος
div1.sense: meadows, Hom.

div1.head: πίσος
div1.sense: the pea, Lat. pisum, Ar.

div1.head: πίσσα
div1.sense: pitch, Lat. pix, Il., Hdt., etc.: proverb., ἄρτι μῦς πίττης γεύεται, i. e. he has got the first taste of misery, Dem.

div1.head: πίσσινος
div1.sense: like pitch, Luc.

div0.div1: πισσόω, πίσσα Mid. to remove the hair by means of a pitch-plaster, Luc.

div1.head: πισσωτής
div1.sense: one who pitches, Luc.

div1.head: πιστευτικός
div1.sense: disposed to trust, confiding, Arist.: —adv., πιστευτικῶς ἔχειν τινί to rely upon one, Plat.
creating belief, Plat.

div1.head: πιστεύω
div1.sense: to trust, trust to or in, put faith in, rely on, believe in a person or thing, c. dat., π. τινί Hdt., Attic; with neut. adj., λόγοις ἐμοῖσι πίστευσον τάδε believe my words herein, Eur.:—later, π. εἰς Θεόν to believe on or in God, NTest.; π. ἐπὶ τὸν Κύριον NTest.:—absol. to believe, Hdt., Thuc.:—Pass. to be trusted or believed, Plat.; πιστεύεσθαι ὑπό τινος to enjoy his confidence, Xen.; π. παρά τινι, πρός τινα Dem.; ὡς πιστευθησόμενος as if he would be believed, Dem.:—Mid. to believe mutually, Dem.
to comply, Soph.

c. inf. to believe that, feel sure or confident that a thing is, will be, has been, Eur., etc.; π. ποιεῖν to dare to do a thing, Dem.:—Pass., πιστεύομαι ἀληθεύσειν I am believed likely to speak truth, Xen.
c. dat. et inf., τοῖσι ἐπίστευε σιγᾶν to whom he trusted that they would keep silence, in whose secresy he confided, Hdt.
to believe, have faith, NTest.
π. τί τινι to entrust something to another, Xen., etc.:—Pass., πιστεύομαί τι I am entrusted with a thing, have it committed to me, Xen.

div1.head: πιστικός
div1.sense: liquid, NTest.: others refer it to πίστις, in the sense of genuine, pure.

div1.head: πιστικός2
div1.sense: faithful:—adv., πιστικῶς ἔχειν τινί Plut.
genuine, v. πιστικόs1

div1.head: πίστις
div1.sense: trust in others, faith, Lat. fides, fiducia, Hes., Theogn., Attic; c. gen. pers. faith or belief in one, Eur.:— generally, persuasion of a thing, confidence, assurance, Pind., Attic
good faith, trustworthiness, faithfulness, honesty, Lat. fides, Theogn., Hdt., Attic
in a commercial sense, credit, trust, πίστις τοσούτων χρημάτων ἐστί μοι παρά τινι I have credit for so much money with him, Dem.; εἰς πίστιν διδόναι τί τινι Dem.
in Theol. faith, belief, as opp. to sight and knowledge, NTest.
that which gives confidence: hence,

an assurance, pledge of good faith, warrant, guarantee, Soph., Eur.; πίστιν καὶ ὅρκια ποιεῖσθαι to make a treaty by exchange of assurances and oaths, Hdt.; οὔτε π. οὔθʼ ὅρκος μένει Ar.; πίστιν διδόναι to give assurances, Hdt.; διδόναι καὶ λαμβάνειν to interchange them, Xen.:—of an oath, θεῶν πίστεις ὀμνύναι Thuc.; πίστιν ἐπιτιθέναι or προστιθέναι τινί Dem.: —φόβων π. an assurance against fears, Eur.
a means of persuasion, an argument, proof, such as used by orators, Plat., etc.

div1.head: πιστός
div1.sense: liquid medicines, opp. to βρώσιμα, Aesch.

div1.head: πιστός2
div1.sense: pass. to be trusted or believed:
of persons, faithful, trusty, true, Il., Hes., Attic:—in Persia οἱ πιστοί were Privy-councillors, "trusty and well-beloved, " Xen.; πιστὰ πιστῶν = πιστότατοι, Aesch.
trustworthy, worthy of credit, Thuc., etc.
of things, trustworthy, sure, of oaths, etc., Hom., etc.; οὐκέτι πιστὰ γυναιξίν no longer can one trust women, Od.; ἐλπὶς πιστὴ λόγῳ warranted by reason, Thuc.
deserving belief, credible, probable, Hdt., Plat., etc.

πιστόν, οῦ, as Subst., like πίστις II, a pledge, security, warrant, certainty, Soph., etc.; τὸ π. τῆς ἐλευθερίας Thuc.; τὸ π. ἔχοντες κἂν περιγενέσθαι feeling confidence that they should survive, Thuc.:—in pl., τὰ πιστὰ ποιεῖσθαι πίστιν ποιεῖσθαι, Hdt.; πιστὰ θεῶν, of oaths, Xen.; πιστόν or πιστὰ δοῦναι καὶ λαβεῖν to give and receive pledges, to interchange pledges, Xen., etc.
act. like πίσυνος, believing, trusting in, relying on, τινι Theogn., Aesch., etc.
obedient, Xen.
faithful, believing, NTest.
adv. πιστῶς, with good faith, persuasively Dem.
with disposition to believe, Dem.

div1.head: πιστότης
div1.sense: good faith, honesty, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: πιστόω
div1.sense: to make trustworthy, πιστοῦν τινα ὅρκοις to bind him by oaths, Thuc.
Pass. to be made trustworthy, give a pledge or warrant, ὅρκῳ πιστωθῆναί τινι to bind oneself to another by oath, Od.
to feel trust or confidence, i. e. to trust, to be persuaded, πιστωθῆναι ἐνὶ θυμῷ Od.; πιστωθεὶς ὅτι . . , feeling confidence that . . , Soph.
Mid. to give mutual pledges of fidelity, exchange troth, χεῖράς τʼ ἀλλήλων λαβέτην καὶ πιστώσαντο Il.:— πιστοῦσθαί τινα ὑφʼ ὅρκου to secure his good faith by oaths, Soph.
to confirm, prove, make good, guarantee, τι Polyb., Luc.

div1.head: πίστρα
div1.sense: a drinking-trough for cattle, Eur.

div1.head: πίστωμα
div1.sense: an assurance, warrant, guarantee, pledge, Aesch., etc.
of persons, γηραλᾶ πιστώματα, πιστοὶ γέροντες, Aesch.

div1.head: πιστωτέος
div1.sense: to be warranted, Luc.

div1.head: πίσυνος
div1.sense: trusting on, relying or depending on, confiding in another, c. dat., Il., Hdt.

div1.head: Πιτάνη
div1.sense: a place in Laconia, Hdt.

div1.head: Πιτανήτης
div1.sense: ὁ Πιτανητέων λόχος, a corps of the Spartan army, Hdt.

div1.head: πίτνημι
div1.sense: to spread out, ἠέρα πίτνα (Epic for ἐπίτνα) Il.; πιτνὰς εἰς ἐμὲ χεῖρας stretching out his arms to me, Od.; πίτναν τʼ εἰς αἰθέρα χεῖρας (for ἐπίτναν) Pind.:—Pass., ἀμφὶ δὲ χαῖται πίτναντο Il.

div1.head: πιτυλεύω
div1.sense: to ply the plashing oar, Ar.

div1.head: πίτυλος
div1.sense: the measured plash of oars, Eur.; ἑνὶ πιτύλῳ with one stroke, all together, Aesch.
any quick repeated sound,
the plash of falling drops, π. δακρύων Eur.; π. σκύφου, of wine poured into a cup, Eur.
the sound of repeated blows, Aesch., Eur.:—metaph., πίτυλος Ἀργείου δορός Eur.; δὶς δυοῖν πιτύλοιν twice with two strokes, Eur.; also of violent frantic gestures, violence, passion, Eur.

div1.head: πιτυοκάμπτης
div1.sense: pine-bender, epith. of the robber Sinis, who killed travellers by tying them between two pine-trees bent down so as nearly to meet, and then let go again, Strab., Plut.

div1.head: πιτυοτρόφος
div1.sense: growing pines, Anth.

div1.head: πίτυρον
div1.sense: the husks of corn, bran, mostly in pl., Dem., Theocr.

div1.head: πίτυς
div1.sense: the pine, stone pine, Hom.:—proverb., πίτυος τρόπον ἐκτρίβεσθαι to be destroyed like a pine, i. e. utterly, because the pine when cut down never grows again, Hdt.

div1.head: πιτύστεπτος
div1.sense: pine-crowned, Anth.

div1.head: πιτυώδης
div1.sense: abounding in pines, Strab.

div1.head: πιφαύσκω
div1.etym: redupl. form of !φα, Root of φαίνω
div1.sense: to make manifest, declare, tell of, Hom., Aesch.: absol., πιφαύσκων Διομήδεϊ making signal to him, Il.
to set forth words, utter, μῦθον, ἔπεα Od.
c. acc. et inf. to tell one to do, Aesch.
Mid. to make manifest, Il.; to tell of, disclose, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: πίων
div1.sense: neut. πῖον, gen. πίονος, fat, plump, Lat. pinguis, Hom.; π. δημός rich fat, Il.; of oil, Hdt.
of soil, fat, rich. Il.; also, πίονα ἔργα pingues segetes, Il.; ὀπώρας πίων ποτός, of wine, Soph.
of persons and places, rich, wealthy, Hom., Aesch.; πίονι μέτρῳ in plenteous measure, Theocr.
The comp. and Sup. are πῑότερος, πῑότατος, as if from πῖος.

div1.head: πλαγιάζω
div1.sense: to turn sideways or aside, πλ. πρὸς τοὺς ἀντίους ἀνέμους (sc. τὴν ναῦν) to beat up against adverse winds, Luc.: metaph., πλ. ἢ φωνὴν ἢ πρᾶξιν to adapt them to circumstances, Plut.

div1.head: πλαγίαυλος
div1.sense: the cross-flute, as opp. to the flute-a-bec, Theocr., Bion.

div1.head: πλάγιος
div1.sense: placed sideways, slanting, aslant, Lat. obliquus, Thuc.

πλάγια, ων, τά, the sides, Hdt.:—in military sense, τοῖς πλαγίοις ἐπιέναι to attack the flanks, Thuc.; εἰς τὰ πλ. παράγειν or παραπέμπειν to make an army file off right and left, Xen.; πλαγίους λαβεῖν τοὺς πολεμίους to take the enemy in flank, Xen.
with Preps. in adverb. sense, εἰς πλάγιον obliquely, Xen.; εἰς τὰ πλάγια, opp. to εἰς τὸ ἀντίον, Thuc.; —ἐκ πλαγίου in flank, Thuc.; κατὰ πλάγια Xen.
metaph. not straightforward, crooked, treacherous, φρένες Pind.; πλάγια φρονεῖν Eur.

div1.head: πλαγκτήρ
div1.sense: the beguiler, (or pass.) the roamer, of Bacchus, Anth.

div1.head: πλαγκτός
div1.sense: wandering, roaming, Aesch., Eur.
metaph. wandering in mind, erring, distraught, Od., Aesch.
Πλαγκταὶ πέτραι are rocks beyond Scylla and Charybdis, affording so narrow a passage that even birds could scarcely get through, Od.; transferred by later writers to the Symplegades, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: πλαγκτοσύνη
div1.sense: roaming, Od.

div1.head: πλάγος
div1.sense: the side, old Doric word.

div1.head: πλαδαρός
div1.sense: wet, damp, Anth.

div1.head: πλάζω
div1.sense: like πλανάω to make to wander or roam, Hom.
to lead astray, bewilder, Hom.

Pass. to wander, rove, roam about, Od.; ἀπὸ χαλκόφι χαλκὸς ἐπλάγχθη brass glanced off from brass, Il.; c. gen. to wander from, ἁμαξιτοῦ Eur.; so, τίς πλάγχθη πολύμοχθος ἔξω; i. e. τίς ἐπλάγχθη ἔξω τοῦ πολύμοχθος εἶναι; Soph.
μέγα κῦμα πλάζʼ ὤμους the wave drove his shoulder aside, Il.:Pass., κύματι πλάζετο was driven aside by the wave, Od.

div1.head: πλάθανον
div1.sense: a mould in which cakes were baked, Theocr.

div1.head: πλάθω
div1.sense: intr. to approach, draw near, c. dat., Soph.; c. acc., Eur.; absol., Eur.

div1.head: πλαίσιον
div1.sense: an oblong figure or body, Ar.; ἰσόπλευρον πλ. a square, Xen.; of an army, ἐν πλαισίῳ τετάχθαι to be drawn up in square, Lat. agmine quadrato, as opp. to marching order, Lat. agmine longo, Thuc., Xen.
div1.etym: Prob. from same Root as πλατύς.

div1.head: πλακερός
div1.sense: broad, Theocr.

div1.head: πλάκινος
div1.sense: made of planks, πλ. τρίπους a tripod with a board on it, Anth.

div1.head: πλακοῦς
div1.sense: a flat cake, Lat. placenta, Ar.

div1.head: πλανάω
div1.sense: like πλάζω, to make to wander, lead wandering about, Hdt., Aesch.:— to lead from the subject, in talking, Dem.
to lead astray, mislead, deceive, Soph., Plat.

Pass. to wander, roam about, stray, Il., Aesch.; c. acc. loci, to wander over, Lat. oberrare, Eur.; but c. acc. cogn., πολλοὺς ἑλιγμοὺς πλανᾶσθαι to wander about as in a labyrinth, Xen.:— of reports, to wander abroad, Soph.
to wander in speaking, digress, Hdt.
c. gen., πλαναθεὶς καιροῦ having missed oneʼs opportunity, Pind.
to do a thing irregularly or at random, Hdt.; ἐνύπνια τὰ ἐς ἀνθρώπους πεπλανημένα that have visited them irregularly, Hdt.
to wander in mind, to be at a loss, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: πλάνημα
div1.sense: a wandering, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: πλάνη
div1.sense: like ἄλη, a wandering, roaming, Hdt., Aesch.
a digression, Plat.
metaph. a going astray, error, Plat., etc.

div1.head: πλάνησις
div1.sense: a making to wander, a dispersing, τῶν νεῶν Thuc.

div1.head: πλάνης
div1.sense: a wanderer, roamer, rover, Soph., Eur.
πλάνητες ἀστέρες the planets, Xen.
as adj. wandering, Plut.

div1.head: πλανητέος
div1.sense: one must wander, Xen.

div1.head: πλανήτης
div1.sense: = πλάνης, Soph., Plat.
as adj. wandering, roaming, Eur.

div1.head: πλανητικός
div1.sense: disposed to wander, Strab.

div1.head: πλανητός
div1.sense: wandering, Plat.

div1.head: πλανόδιος
div1.sense: going by bye-paths, wandering, Hhymn.

div1.head: πλάνος
div1.sense: act. leading astray, cheating, deceiving, Theocr., Mosch.
πλάνος, πλάνη, a wandering, roaming, straying, Soph., Eur., etc.

metaph., φροντίδος πλάνοι the wanderings of thought, Soph.; but, πλ. φρενῶν wandering of mind, madness, Eur.; πλάνοις in uncertain fits, of a disease, Soph.; κερκίδος πλάνοι, of the act of weaving, Eur.
of persons, πλάνος, a deceiver, impostor, NTest.

div1.head: πλανοστιβής
div1.sense: trodden by wanderers, Aesch.

div1.head: πλανύττω
div1.sense: to wander about, Ar.

div1.head: πλάξ
div1.sense: a flat surface, flat land, a plain, Aesch.; πόντου πλάξ the ocean- plain, Pind.; αἰθερία πλάξ Eur.: the flat top of a hill, table-land, Soph.
a flat stone, tablet, Luc., NTest.

div1.head: πλάσμα
div1.sense: anything moulded, an image, figure, Ar., etc.
anything imitated, a counterfeit, forgery, Dem.
a formed style, affectation, in orators or actors, Plut.

div1.head: πλασματίας
div1.sense: one addicted to lying, Plut.

div1.head: πλάσσω
div1.sense: to form, mould, shape, Lat. fingere, properly of the artist who works in clay or wax, Hes., Hdt.; τὴν ὑδρίαν πλάσαι to mould the water-jar, Ar.; ἔπλαττεν οἰκίας made clay houses, Ar.:—Pass. to be moulded, made, ὁ μὲν πλάσσεται one is a-moulding, Hdt.
generally, to mould and form by education, training, Plat.
to form in the mind, form a notion of a thing, Plat.
to put in a certain form: Mid., πλασάμενος τῆι ὄψει having formed himself in face, i. e. composed his countenance, Thuc.

metaph. to make up, fabricate, forge, Soph., Dem.:— absol., πλάσας λέγειν to speak from invention, i. e. not the truth, Hdt.:—so in Mid., Xen., etc.:—Pass., οὐ πεπλασμένος ὁ κόμπος not fictitious, Aesch.

div1.head: πλαστεύω
div1.sense: to falsify, Byz.

div1.head: πλάστης
div1.sense: a moulder, modeller, Plat.

div1.head: πλάστιγξ
div1.sense: the scale of a balance, Ar.: dual, a pair of scales, Ar.
a collar for horses, Eur.
a scourge, Aesch.:—In this last sense, at all events, from πλήσσω.

div1.head: πλαστικός
div1.sense: fit for moulding, plastic, αἱ πλ. τέχναι the plastic arts, Plat.

div1.head: πλαστός
div1.sense: formed, moulded in clay or wax, Hes., Plat., etc.
metaph. fabricated, forged, counterfeit, Hdt., Eur.; πλαστός a supposititious son, Soph.

div1.head: πλαταγέω
div1.sense: to clap, clap the hands, Theocr.; to clash, crack, Theocr.:—so in Mid., Anth.
to beat the breasts, Bion.; πλ. τύμπανα Anth.

div1.head: πλατάγημα
div1.sense: a clapping, Theocr.

div1.head: πλαταγή
div1.sense: a rattle, Arist.

div1.head: πλαταγώνιον
div1.sense: the broad petal of the poppy or anemone, which lovers laid on the left hand, and struck with the right; it was a good omen if it burst with a loud crack, Theocr.

div1.head: Πλάταια
div1.sense: Plataea or Plataeae in Boeotia, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Πλαταιᾶσι
div1.sense: at Plataeae, Thuc.

div1.head: Πλαταιεύς
div1.sense: Plataean, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Πλαταιικός
div1.sense: of Plataea, Hdt.; τὰ -κά the events at Plataea, Hdt.; fem. ἡ Πλαταιὶς, γῆ, χώρα Hdt.

div1.head: πλαταμών
div1.sense: a flat stone, Hhymn.:— in pl. ledges of rock, Strab.

div1.head: πλατανιστοῦς
div1.sense: a grove of plane-trees, Lat. platanetum, Theogn.

div1.head: πλάτανος
div1.sense: the oriental plane, Lat. platanus, Ar., Plat.
div1.etym: From πλατύς, because of its broad leaves.

div1.head: πλατειάζω
div1.sense: to speak or pronounce broadly, like the Dorians, Theocr.

div1.head: πλατεῖον
div1.sense: a tablet, Polyb.

div1.head: πλάτη
div1.sense: a flat surface:
the blade of an oar, an oar, Trag.; ναυτίλῳ πλάτῃ by ship, by sea, Soph.; οὐρίῳ πλάτῃ with a fair voyage, Soph.
a sheet of paper, Anth.

div1.head: πλᾶτις
div1.sense: a wife, Ar.

div1.head: πλατόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be made flat like an oar-blade, Ar.

div1.head: πλατός
div1.sense: approachable, Aesch.

div1.head: πλάτος
div1.sense: breadth, width, Hdt., etc.:— absol., πλάτος or τὸ πλ., in breadth, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: πλατυγίζω
div1.sense: of a goose, to beat the water with its wings, to splash about:—metaph. to make a splash, to swagger, Ar.

div1.head: πλατυλέσχης
div1.sense: a wide-mouthed babbler, Anth.

div1.head: πλατυντέος
div1.sense: one must extend, Xen.

div1.head: πλατύνω
div1.sense: to widen, make wide, NTest.: —Mid., πλατύνεσθαι γῆν to widen oneʼs territory, Xen.:—Pass. to grow broad, widen out, Anth.: metaph., ἡ καρδία πεπλάτυνται is opened, enlarged, NTest.

div1.head: πλατύνωτος
div1.sense: broad-backed, Batr.

div1.head: πλατύπυγος
div1.sense: broad-bottomed, πλοῖα Strab.

div1.head: πλατύρρις
div1.sense: broad-nosed, Strab.

div1.head: πλατύρροος
div1.sense: broad-flowing, Aesch.

div1.head: πλατύς
div1.sense: Ionic fem. πλατέα:— wide, broad, Il.; αἰπόλια πλατέʼ αἰγῶν broad herds, i. e. large or widespread, Hom.; π. πρόσοδοι Pind.
flat, level, Hdt., Plat.; κάρυα τὰ πλατέα, i. e. chestnuts, Xen.
of a man, broad-shouldered, Soph.
metaph., πλατὺς κατάγελως flat (i. e. downright) mockery, Ar.: neut. as adv., flatly, merely, Ar.
πλατεῖα (sc. ὁδός) , a street, Lat. platea, Xen.:—(sub. χείρ) , the flat of the hand, Ar.
salt, brackish, Hdt.

div1.head: πλατύτης
div1.sense: breadth, bulk, Xen.

div1.head: Πλατωνικός
div1.sense: of Plato, Anth.; Sup. -ώτατος, Luc.: adv. -κῶς, after the manner of Plato, Strab.

div1.head: πλέγδην
div1.sense: adv. entwined, entangled, Anth.

div1.head: πλέγμα
div1.sense: plaited work, wicker-work, Plat., Xen.:—pl. wreaths, braids, Eur., NTest.

div1.head: πλεθριαῖος
div1.sense: broad or long, Xen.

div1.head: πλεθρίζω
div1.sense: to run the πλέθρον; metaph. to "shoot with a long bow, " Theophr.

div1.head: πλέθρον
div1.sense: as measure of length, a plethron, = 100 Greek or 101 English feet, 1/6 of a stade, Hdt., Xen.
as a square measure, 10, 000 square feet (Greek) = about 37 perches, Plat., Dem.;—used to translate the Rom. jugerum, though this was about 2 roods 19 perches, Plut.

div1.head: Πλειάδες
div1.sense: the Pleiads, seven daughters of Atlas, placed by Zeus among the stars, Hom., Hes.; only six are distinctly visible, whence the myth of the "lost Pleiad, " Ovid.
div1.etym: Prob. from πλέω, to sail, because they rose at the beginning of the sailingseason, as Ὑάδες from ὕω, with reference to the rainy season. Poets, adopting the form Πελειάδες, represented them as doves, and the ὑάδες as swine.

div1.head: πλειστάκις
div1.sense: mostly, most often, very often, Xen., etc.

div1.head: πλειστήρης
div1.sense: manifold, ἅπας πλ. χρόνος all the whole length of time, Aesch.

div1.head: πλειστηρίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to count as principal author, Aesch.

div1.head: πλειστοβόλος
div1.sense: throwing the most, of dicers, Anth.

div1.head: πλειστόμβροτος
div1.sense: crowded with people, Pind.

div1.head: πλεῖστος
div1.sense: most, largest, also very much, very large, both of number and size, Hom., etc.; πλεῖστός εἰμι τῇ γνώμῃ I incline most to the opinion, Hdt.
with the Art., οἱ πλεῖστοι, much like οἱ πολλοί, the greatest number, Thuc., etc.; τὸ πλεῖστον τοῦ βίου the greatest part of life, Plat.; also ἡ πλ. τῆς στρατιᾶς Thuc.

Special usages: ὅσας ἂν πλείστας δύναιντο καταστρέφεσθαι the greatest number that they could possibly subdue, Hdt.; ὅτι πλ. Thuc., etc.:— εἷς ἀνὴρ πλεῖστον πόνον παρασχών the greatest of all men, Aesch.
Adverb. usages:— πλεῖστον, μάλιστα, most, Il., Attic; ὡς πλεῖστον, Lat. quam maxime, Xen.; sometimes added to a Sup., πλεῖστον ἐχθίστη, πλ. κάκιστος Soph.; so, πλεῖστα Soph.:— furthest, Plat.
with the Art., τὸ πλ. for the most part, Ar.
with Preps.:
διὰ πλείστου furthest off, in point of space or time, Thuc.
εἰς πλεῖστον most, Soph.
ἐπὶ πλεῖστον over the greatest distance, to the greatest extent, in point of space or time, Hdt., Thuc.; ὡς ἐπὶ πλ. or ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ πλ. for the most part. Plat.; περὶ πλείστου ποιεῖσθαι, v. περί A. IV.
ἐν τοῖς πλεῖστοι or πλεῖσται about the most, Thuc.

div1.head: πλείων
div1.sense: more, larger, both of number and size, Hom., etc.; τὸν πλείω λόγον all further speech, Soph.; πλείω τὸν πλοῦν the greater part of . . , Thuc.:—of Time, longer, πλείων χρόνος Hdt.; πλέων νύξ the greater part of night, Il.

with the Art., οἱ πλέονες the greater number, like οἱ πολλοί, the mass or crowd, Hom.; οἱ πλεῦνες Hdt., etc.; c. gen., τὰς πλεῦνας τῶν γυκαικῶν Hdt.:— the many, the people, opp. to the chief men, Thuc., etc.:— τὸ πλεῖον πολέμοιο the greater part of war, Hom.
pecul. usages of neut.:

as a Noun, more, πλεῦν ἔτι τούτου Hdt.; τὸ δὲ πλέον nay, what is more, Eur., Thuc.:— πλέον or τὸ πλέον τινός a higher degree of a thing, Soph.; τὸ πλ. τοῦ χρόνου Thuc.:— πλέον ἔχειν to have the best of it, win, conquer, Thuc.; also, like πλεονεκτέω, c. gen., Hdt., etc.; also, πλέον ποιεῖν Plat.; ἐς πλ. ποιεῖν Soph.; οὐδὲν πλ. πράσσειν, etc., Eur.:— τί πλέον; what more, i. e. what good or use is it? Ar.; so, οὐδὲν ἦν πλέον Dem.:— ἐπὶ πλέον or ἐπίπλεον, as adv., more, further, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; c. gen. beyond, ἐπὶ τὸ πλ. τινὸς ἱκέσθαι Theocr.; cf. περί A. III.
as adv. more, rather, πλέον ἔφερέ οἱ ἡ γνώμη his opinion inclined rather, Hdt.:—also, τὸ πλέον, Ionic τὸ πλεῦν, for the most part, Hdt., etc.; τὸ πλ. μᾶλλον, Thuc.

with Numerals, τοξότας πλ. ἢ εἴκοσι Xen.:—in this sense a contr. form πλεῖν is used by Attic writers, πλεῖν ἢ τριάκονθʼ ἡμέρας Ar.; πλεῖν ἢ χιλίας (sc. δραχμάς) Ar., etc.;—but ἤ is often omitted, as in Lat. quam after plus, πλεῖν ἑξακοσίας Ar.; so, ἔτη γεγονὼς πλείω ἑβδομήκοντα annos plus septuaginta natus, Plat.:—Comic phrase, πλεῖν ἢ μαίνομαι more than to madness, Ar.
the pl. πλείω is also used like πλέον, Thuc., Dem.

div1.head: πλειών
div1.sense: a full period, a year, Hes.

div1.head: πλέκος
div1.sense: wicker-work, Ar.

div1.head: πλεκτανάομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be intertwined, πεπλεκτανημέναι δράκουσι, of the Erinyes, Aesch.

div1.head: πλεκτάνη
div1.sense: anything twined or wreathed, a coil, wreath, spire, of serpents, Aesch.; πλ. καπνοῦ a wreath of smoke, Ar.
in pl. the meshes of a spiderʼs web, Luc.; metaph., αἱ τῶν λόγων πλεκτάναι tortuous speeches, Luc.

div1.head: πλεκτή
div1.sense: properly fem. of πλεκτός·
a coil, wreath, Aesch.
a twisted rope, cord, string, Eur.

div1.head: πλεκτικός
div1.sense: of plaiting, τέχναι Plat.

div1.head: πλεκτός
div1.sense: plaited, twisted, Hom., Hes., etc.; π. στέγαι wicker mansions, of the Scythian vans, Aesch.; πλεκτὴ Αἰγύπτου παιδεία the twisted taskwork of Egypt, i. e. ropes of biblus, Eur.
wreathed, ἄνθη Aesch.; στέφανος Eur.

div1.head: πλέκω
div1.sense: to plait, twine, twist, weave, braid, Il., etc. : Med., πεῖσμα πλεξάμενος having twisted me a rope, Od.:—Pass., κράνεα πεπλεγμένα of basket-work, Hdt.; σειραὶ πεπλεγμέναι ἐξ ἱμάντων Hdt.
metaph. to plan, devise, contrive, like ῥάπτειν, ὑφαίνειν, mostly of tortuous means, πλ. δόλον Aesch.; μηχανάς Eur.; παντοίας παλάμας Ar.
of Poets, πλ. ὕμνον, ῥήματα Pind.; πλ. λόγους Eur.
in Pass. to twist oneself round, Aesch.

div1.head: πλεονάζω
div1.sense: to be more, esp. to be more than enough, be superfluous, Arist.
of persons, to go beyond bounds, take or claim too much, Dem.:—c. dat. to presume upon, τῆι εὐτυχίαι Thuc.: of a writer, to be lengthy, tedious, Lat. multus sum, Strab.
πλεονάζειν τινός to have an excess of, abound in a thing, Arist.
c. acc. to state at a larger amount, Strab.:—Pass. to be exaggerated, Thuc.

div1.head: πλεονάκις
div1.sense: more frequently, oftener, Plat.: several times, frequently, Arist.

div1.head: πλεοναχῇ
div1.sense: in many points of view, Plat.

div1.head: πλεοναχός
div1.sense: manifold, adv. in various ways, Arist.

div1.head: πλεονεκτέω
div1.sense: to have or claim more than oneʼs due, to get or have too much, to be greedy, grasping, arrogant, Hdt., Plat.: —also to gain or have some advantage, without any bad sense, Thuc., Xen.
c. gen. rei, to have or claim more of a thing, to have or claim a larger share, Thuc., etc.
c. gen. pers. to have or gain the advantage over, τῶν ἐχθρῶν Plat.
c. acc. pers. to overreach, defraud, Menand., NTest.:— Pass. to be overreached, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πλεονέκτημα
div1.sense: an advantage, gain, privilege, Plat., Dem.: in pl. gains, successes, Xen.
an act of overreaching, selfish trick, Dem.

div1.head: πλεονέκτης
div1.sense: one who has or claims more than his due, greedy, grasping, arrogant, Thuc., etc.:—as adj., λόγος πλ. Hdt.; Sup. πλεονεκτίστατος, Xen.
πλεονέκτης τῶν πολεμίων making gain from their losses, Xen.

div1.head: πλεονεκτητέος
div1.sense: one must take more than oneʼs share, Plat.

div1.head: πλεονεκτικός
div1.sense: disposed to take too much, greedy, Dem., etc. adv. -κῶς, Plat.; πλ. ἔχειν Dem.

div1.head: πλεονεξία
div1.sense: the character and conduct of a πλεονέκτης, greediness, grasping, assumption, arrogance, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
gain, advantage, Xen., etc.; ἐπὶ πλεονεξίᾳ with a view to oneʼs own advantage, Thuc., Xen.
c. gen. pers. advantage over, Xen.
c. gen. rei, a larger share of a thing, Arist.; gain made from a thing, Dem.

div1.head: πλευρά
div1.sense: a rib, Lat. costa, Hdt.: mostly in pl. the ribs, the side, Il., Hdt., Attic:—in sg., also, of one side, Soph.
the side of things and places, πλευραὶ νηός Theogn.; χωρίου, ποταμοῦ Plat.; of an army, αἱ πλ. τοῦ πλαισίου Xen.
the page of a book, Anth.

div1.head: πλευρόθεν
div1.sense: from the side, Soph.

div1.head: πλευροκοπέω
div1.sense: to smite the ribs, Soph.

div1.head: πλευρόν
div1.sense: a rib: mostly in pl. the ribs, the side, Il., Hdt., etc.;—also in sg., Soph.
of places, πλευρὸν νεῶν the side of the bay where the ships lay, Soph.; τὸ δεξιὸν πλ. the right flank (of an army), Xen.

div1.head: πλευροτυπής
div1.sense: striking the sides or ribs, Anth.

div1.head: πλεύρωμα
div1.sense: like πλευρόν, in pl. the side, Aesch.

div1.head: πλευστέος
div1.sense: one must sail, Dem.

div1.head: πλευστικός
div1.sense: fit or favourable for sailing, Theocr.

div1.head: πλέω
div1.sense: to sail, go by sea, Hom., etc.; c. acc. cogn., ὑγρὰ κέλευθα πλεῖν to sail the watery ways, Od.; hence in Pass., τὸ πεπλευσμένον πέλαγος Xen.;—metaph., πλεῖν ὑφειμένηι cf. ὑφίημι ΙΙΙ.
of ships, Il., Hdt., etc.
of other things, to swim, float, Hom., etc.
metaph., ταύτης ἔπι πλέοντες ὀρθῆς while we keep [the ship of] our country right, Soph.; οὐδʼ ὅπως ὀρθὴ πλεύσεται (sc. ἡ πόλις) προείδετο Dem.

div1.head: πλέως
div1.sense: full of a thing, c. gen., πλεῖαι οἴνου κλισίαι Il., etc.
ῥάκη νοσηλείας πλέα rags infected with his sore, Soph.
absol. full, Il., etc.
of Time, full, complete, δέκα πλείους ἐνιαυτούς ten full years, Hes.
comp. πλειότερος Od.

div1.head: πληγή
div1.sense: a blow, stroke, Lat. plaga, Hom., etc.; πληγὴν πέπληγμαι καιρίαν Aesch.; in such phrases πληγήν or πληγάς is often omitted, πολλὰς τυπτόμενος Ar., etc.:—the person struck is said πληγὰς λαβεῖν Ar.; the striker πληγὰς δοῦναι, ἐμβάλλειν, ἐντείνειν τινί Xen.
a stroke by lightning, Hes.: a blow, stroke of calamity, Aesch.; πλ. θεοῦ a blow from heaven, Soph.

div1.head: πλῆθος
div1.sense: a great number, a throng, crowd, multitude, Il., Hdt., etc.
τὸ πλῆθος, the greater number, the greater part, the mass, main body, Hdt., Xen., etc.:— the majority, the people, like δῆμος, Lat. plebs, Hdt., Attic: —also the populace, mob, Xen.
quantity or number, Hdt., Attic; πλήθει παρόντες in force, Thuc.: —absol. in acc., κόσοι πλῆθος Hdt.; πλῆθος ἀνάριθμοι Aesch.
magnitude, size or extent, ὄρος πλήθεϊ μέγιστον Hdt.; πεδίον πλῆθος ἄπειρον Hdt., etc.
quantity or amount, Thuc., Plat., etc.
of Time, length, Thuc., etc.
with Preps., or with ὡς, in adv. sense, ἐς πλ. in great numbers, Thuc.: —ὡς πλήθει upon the whole, in general, Plat.; so, ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ πλ. usually, mostly, Lat. ut plurimum, Plat.

div1.head: πληθύνω
div1.sense: Causal of πληθύω, only in pres. and imperf., to make full, increase, multiply, NTest., Hdt.
Pass. to be in the majority, to prevail, Aesch.; c. inf., ἐπαινεῖν πληθύνομαι I am led by general opinion to approve, Aesch.

div1.head: πληθύς
div1.sense: fulness, a throng, a crowd, of people, Hom., Plut., etc.

div1.head: πληθύω
div1.sense: to be or become full, τινός of a thing, Eur.:— absol., ἀγορῆς πληθυούσης, v. ἀγορά V.:—of rivers, to swell, rise, Hdt.:—so in Mid., Hdt.
to increase in number, multiply, Aesch.
to abound, τινί in a thing, Soph.
to be general, prevail, Lat. invalescere, of reports, Aesch., Soph.; ὁ πληθύων χρόνος increasing time, age, Soph.

div1.head: πλήθω
div1.etym: poet. perf. πέπληθα, in pres. sense
div1.sense: to be or become full of a thing, c. gen., Il., Aesch.; χεῖρας κρεῶν πλήθοντες having them full of flesh, Aesch.; c. dat., Theocr.: absol. of rivers, to be full, brimming, Il.; so, πλήθουσα Σελήνη at her full, Il.; ἀγορᾶς πληθούσης, ἐν ἀγορᾷ πληθούσῃ, etc., v. sub ἀγορά V.
trans., like πληθύνω, Anth.

div1.head: πληθώρα
div1.sense: fulness, πλ. ἀγορῆς, ἀγορὰ πλήθουσα, Hdt.; v. ἀγορά V.
fulness, satiety, Hdt.

div1.head: πλήκτης
div1.sense: a striker, brawler, Plut.

div1.head: πληκτίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.
to bandy blows with one, c. dat., Il.
to beat oneʼs breast for grief, Lat. plangere, Anth.
to indulge in dalliance, Strab.

div1.head: πλῆκτρον
div1.sense: anything to strike with:
an instrument for striking the lyre, plectrum, Hhymn., Eur., etc.
a spear point, π. διόβολον, of lighting, Eur.
a cockʼs spur, Lat. calcar, Ar.
an oar or paddle, Hdt.

div1.head: πλημμέλεια
div1.sense: a mistake in music, false note: metaph. a fault, offence, error, Plat.

div1.head: πλημμελέω
div1.sense: to make a false note in music: metaph. to go wrong, offend, err, τι in a thing, Eur., Plat., etc.; εἴς τινα Aeschin.:—Pass., πλημμελεῖσθαι ὑπό τινος to be ill-treated by one, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: πλημμέλημα
div1.sense: a fault, trespass, Aeschin.

div1.head: πλημμελής
div1.sense: properly, out of tune, opp. to ἐμμελής.
metaph. in discord, faulty, erring, Plat.
of things, dissonant, discordant, unpleasant, πλημμελές τι δρᾶν, παθεῖν Eur., etc.

div1.head: πλήμυρα
div1.sense: the flood-tide, Anth.

div1.head: πλημυρέω
div1.sense: to rise like the flood-tide, to overflow, be redundant, Anth., Plut.

div1.head: πλημυρίς
div1.sense: a rise of the sea, πλημυρὶς ἐκ πόντοιο of the wave caused by the rock thrown by the Cyclops, Od.: flood-tide (cf. ῥαχία) , opp. to ἄμπωτις (ebb), Hdt.
generally, a flood, deluge, Arist.; of tears, Aesch., Eur.
div1.etym: υ in Hom., ῡ in Attic
Deriv. uncertain: perh. from πλήθω, μύρω.

div1.head: πλήμνη
div1.sense: the nave of a wheel, Il., Hes.
div1.etym: Perh. from πλήθω, the filled up or solid part of the wheel.

div1.head: πλήν
div1.sense: as prep. with gen., more than, and so except, save, Od., Hdt.; ὑπεγγύους πλὴν θανάτου liable to any punishment save, short of, death, Hdt.; ἐπιτρέψαι περὶ σφῶν αὐτῶν πλὴν θανάτου save in respect of death, Thuc.
as adv.:

with single words and phrases, when a negat. precedes, οὐκ οἶδα πλὴν ἕν Soph., etc.:—after πᾶς, πάντες, ἕκαστος, and the like, παντὶ δῆλον πλὴν ἐμοί Plat.; πᾶς is sometimes omitted, θνήσκουσι πάντες πλὴν εἷς τις Soph.; after ἄλλος, τί ἄλλο πλὴν ψευδῆ what else but lies, Soph.; after a comp., like ἤ, than, ταῦτʼ ἐστὶ κρείσσω, πλὴν ὑπʼ Ἀργείοις πεσεῖν Eur.
often joined with other Particles:
πλὴν εἰ, πλὴν ἐάν, Lat. nisi si, πλὴν εἴ τις κωμῳδοποιὸς τυγχάνει ὤν Plat.; πλὴν ὅταν Aesch., etc.:—the Verb is often omitted, as with ὡσεί, ὡσπερεί, οὐδεὶς οἶδεν, πλὴν εἴ τις ὄρνις Ar.
πλὴν ἤ, much like πλὴν εἰ, οὐκ ἄλλως πλὴν ἢ Προδίκῳ Ar.
πλὴν οὐ, only not, ἀπέπεμπε κήρυκας ἐς τὴν Ἑλλάδα, πλὴν οὐ ἐς Ἀθήνας Hdt.; πάντες πλὴν οὐχ οἱ τύραννοι Xen.
πλὴν ὅτι except that . . , save that, καίτοι τί διαφέρουσιν ἡμῶν ἐκεῖνοι, πλὴν ὅτι ψηφίσματʼ οὐ γράφουσιν Ar.; so, πλὴν ἢ ὅτι Hdt.
πλὴν ὅσον except or save so far as, Hdt.; πλὴν καθόσον εἰ Thuc.: —without a Verb, πάντων ἐρήμους, πλὴν ὅσον τὸ σὸν μέρος save so far as thou art concerned, Soph.

div1.head: πλήξιππος
div1.sense: striking or driving horses, Il., Hes.

div1.head: πλήρης
div1.sense: c. gen. full of a thing, Hdt., Trag.
filled or infected by, πλήρης ὑπʼ οἰωνῶν τε καὶ κυνῶν βορᾶς polluted by birds and dogs with meat (torn from the body of Polynices), Soph.
satiated with a thing, Soph.; πλήρης ἐστὶ θηεύμενος he has gazed his fill, Hdt.
rarely c. dat. filled with, Eur.
absol. full, of a swoln stream, Hdt.; of the moon, Hdt.; of cups, Eur.: —esp. full of people, Ar.
full, complete, λαβεῖν τι πλῆρες Hdt., Eur.:—of number, τέσσερα ἔτεα πλήρεα four full years, Hdt.

div1.head: πληροφορέω
div1.sense: to fulfil, NTest.
in Pass., of persons, to have full satisfaction, to be fully assured, NTest.; of things, to be fully believed, NTest.

div1.head: πληροφορία
div1.sense: fulness of assurance, certainty, NTest.

div1.head: πληρόω
div1.sense: to make full:
c. gen. rei, to fill full of, Hdt., etc.:—Pass. to be filled full of, Aesch., etc.
to fill full of food, to gorge, satiate, βορᾶς ψυχὴν ἐπλήρουν Eur.; metaph., πληροῦν θυμόν to glut oneʼs rage, animum explere, Soph., etc.
c. dat. to fill with, Eur.: Pass., πνεύμασιν πληρούμενοι filled with breath, Aesch.; πεπληρωμένος ἀδικίαι NTest.
πλ. ναῦν, τριήρη to man a ship, Hdt.; πληροῦτε θωρακεῖα man the breast-works, Aesch.; in Mid., πληροῦσθαι τὴν ναῦν to man oneʼs ship, Xen.:—Pass., of the ships, Thuc.
of number, to make full or complete, τοὺς δέκα μῆνας Hdt.;—so in Mid., NTest.:—Pass. to be completed, Hdt., NTest.
πλ. δικαστήριον to fill it, Dem.
to fulfil, pay in full, make up, Aesch., Thuc.:—Pass., νόμοι πληρούμενοι fully observed, Aesch.
ἐς ἄγγος βακχίου μέτρημα πληρώσαντες having poured wine into the vessel till it was full, Eur.:—Pass. to crowd in to a place, Aesch.
intr., ἡ ὁδὸς πληροῖ ἐς τὸν ἀριθμὸν τοῦτον the length of road comes in full to this number, Hdt.

div1.head: πλήρωμα
div1.sense: a full measure, Eur.
πλ. δαιτός the satiety of the feast, Eur.; πλ. τυρῶν their fill of cheese, Eur.
of ships, a full number, Hdt., Eur.; of single ships, their complement, Thuc., etc.
of number, the sum, total, Hdt., Ar.
a piece inserted to fill up, NTest.
fulness, full and perfect nature, NTest.
a filling up, completing, Soph.; κυλίκων πλ. ἔχων to have the task of filling them, Eur.
fulfilment, NTest.

div1.head: πλήρωσις
div1.sense: a filling up, filling, Plat.: often of eating and drinking, satiety, Plat.
the completion of a number, Hdt.

div1.head: πληρωτής
div1.sense: one who completes, Dem.

div1.head: πλησιάζω
div1.sense: to bring near, τινά τινι Xen.:—Pass. to come near, approach, τινι Eur.
intr., in sense of Pass., absol. to be near, Soph.:— to draw near to, approach, c. dat., Xen.; rarely c. gen., Xen.
c. dat. pers. to be always near, to consort or associate with, τῷ ἀνδρί Soph.; γυναικί Dem.

div1.head: πλησιασμός
div1.sense: Dius in Stob.:— an approaching, approach, Arist.

div1.head: πλησίος
div1.sense: near, close to, c. gen. or dat., πλησίοι ἀλλήλων or ἀλλήλοισι Hom.:—absol. near, neighbouring, Il., Aesch., etc.:—as Subst. a neighbour, ἰδὼν ἐς πλ. ἄλλον Il., etc.
adv. πλησίον, Doric πλᾱτίον, πέλας, near, nigh, hard by, c. gen., Hom., Hdt., etc.; c. dat., Eur.
with the Art., ὁ πλησίον (sc. ὤν) oneʼs neighbour, Theogn., Eur., etc.; so in Doric, ὁ πλᾱτίον Theocr.:—also, with Substs., ὁ πλ. παράδεισος Xen.
comp. πλησιαίτερος, Sup. -αίτατος, Xen.—comp. adv. πλησιαιτέρω, Hdt.; -αίτερον, Xen.; Sup. -αίτατα, Xen.

div1.head: πλησιόχωρος
div1.sense: near a country, bordering upon, τινι Hdt.; absol., οἱ πλ. persons who live in the next country, next neighbours, Lat. finitimi, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: πλησίστιος
div1.sense: filling the sails, οὖρος Od., Eur.
pass. with full sails, Plut.

div1.head: πλήσμιος
div1.sense: filling, satisfying, Plut.: τὸ πλήσμιον satiety, Plut.

div1.head: πλησμονή
div1.sense: a filling or being filled, satiety; esp. of food, repletion, satiety, surfeit, Eur., Xen.:—c. gen., τῶν ἄλλων ἐστι πλ. Ar.

div1.head: πλήσσω
div1.etym: πέπηγα is used as pass. in late writers
div1.sense: to strike, smite, Hom.; of a direct blow, as opp. to βάλλω, Hom., etc.:—c. acc. dupl. pers. et partis, τὸν πλῆξε αὐχένα struck him on the neck, Il.; πὺξ πεπληγέμεν, of boxers, Il.:—c. acc. cogn., πλῆξʼ αὐτοσχεδίην (sc. πληγήν) Il.; πεπληγὼς πληγῆισιν having driven him with blows, Il.; πέπληγον χορὸν ποσίν, like Lat. terram pede pulsare, Od.; ἵππους ἐς πόλεμον πεπληγέμεν to whip on the horses to the fray, Il.; of Zeus, to strike with lightning, Hes.:—Mid., μηρὼ πληξάμενος having smitten his thighs, Il.; πλήξασθαι τὴν κεφαλήν, in sign of grief, Hdt.:—Pass. to be struck, stricken, smitten, Hom., Trag.
with acc. of the thing set in motion, κονίσαλον ἐς οὐρανὸν ἐπέπληγον πόδες ἵππων struck the dust up to heaven, Il.
Pass. to receive a heavy blow, to be beaten, Hdt., Thuc.:— to be stricken by misfortune, Hdt.; στρατὸν τοσοῦτον πέπληγμαι, i. e. I have lost it by this blow, Aesch.
metaph. of violent emotions, to strike one from oneʼs senses, amaze, confound, Hom.:—Pass., συμφορῆι πέπληγμαι Hdt., etc.; δώροισι πληγείς moved by bribes, Hdt.

div1.head: πλινθεύω
div1.sense: to make into bricks, τὴν γῆν Hdt.:—absol. to make bricks, Ar.;—so in Mid., thuc.
to build of brick, τείχη Ar.
to make in the form of a plinth or brick, Ar.

div1.head: πλινθηδόν
div1.sense: brick-fashion, i. e. in courses with the joints alternating, Hdt.

div1.head: πλίνθινος
div1.sense: of brick, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: πλινθίον
div1.sense: a small brick, Thuc., Xen.
= πλαίσιον, a rectangle or square, Plut.

div1.head: πλινθίς
div1.sense: a whetstone, Anth.

div1.head: πλινθόομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to build as with bricks, Anth.

div1.head: πλινθοποιέω
div1.sense: to make bricks, Ar.

div1.head: πλίνθος
div1.sense: a brick, Hdt., Ar., etc.; πλίνθους ἑλκύσαι, εἰρύσαι, Lat. ducere lateres, to make bricks, Hdt.; ὀπτᾶν to bake them, Hdt.

div1.head: πλινθουργέω
div1.sense: to make bricks, Ar.

div1.head: πλινθουργός
div1.sense: a brickmaker, Plat.

div1.head: πλινθοφορέω
div1.sense: carry bricks, Ar.

div1.head: πλινθοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying bricks, Ar.

div1.head: πλινθυφής
div1.sense: brick-built, Aesch.

div1.head: πλίσσομαι
div1.sense: to cross the legs, as in trotting, πλίσσοντο πόδεσσιν they trotted, Od.; in comp., ἂν ἀπεπλίξατο would have trotted off, Ar.

div1.head: πλοητόκος
div1.sense: producing navigation, Anth.

div1.head: πλοιάριον
div1.sense: a skiff, boat, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: πλοῖον
div1.sense: a floating vessel, a ship, vessel, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; πλοῖα λεπτά small craft, Hdt., Thuc.; πλ. ἱππαγωγά transport- vessels, Hdt.; πλ. μακρά ships of war, Hdt.; πλ. στρογγύλα or φορτηγικά ships burthen, merchantmen, Xen.:—when opp. to ναῦς, a merchant-ship or transport, τοῖς πλοίοις καὶ ταῖς ναυσί Thuc.

div1.head: πλοκαμίς
div1.sense: a lock or braid of hair, of women, Bion.: in sg. curling hair, Theocr.

div1.head: πλόκαμος
div1.sense: a lock or braid of hair, Aesch.: in pl. locks, properly of women, Il.:—in sg., collectively, = κόμη, Hdt.; τριχὸς πλ. Aesch.

div1.head: πλόκανον
div1.sense: a plaited rope, Xen.

div1.head: πλοκή
div1.sense: a twining: anything woven, a web, Eur.
metaph. the complication of a plot, opp. to λύσις, Arist.

div1.head: πλόκος
div1.sense: a lock of hair, a braid, curl, Trag.
a wreath or chaplet, πλόκοι σελίνων the parsley- wreath at the Isthmian games, Pind.; μυρσίνης πλόκοι Eur., etc.

div1.head: πλόος
div1.sense: a sailing, voyage, Od., Hdt., Attic; πλοῦν στέλλειν, ποιεῖσθαι Soph.; μῆκός ἐστι πλόος ἡμέραι τέσσερες its length is four daysʼ sail, Hdt.
time or tide for sailing, Hes., Soph., etc.; πλῷ χρῆσθαι to have a fair wind, Thuc.
proverb., δεύτερος πλοῦς, "the next best way" (from those who use oars when the wind fails), Plat.

div1.head: πλουθυγίεια
div1.sense: health and wealth, Ar.; parox. πλουθυγιείᾱ (metri grat.) Ar.

div1.head: πλούσιος
div1.sense: rich, wealthy, opulent, Hes., Theogn., Attic
c. gen. rei, rich in a thing, Lat. dives opum, Eur., Plat.:—also c. dat., Plut.
of things, richly furnished, ample, abundant, Soph., Eur.
adv. -ίως, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: Πλουτεύς
div1.etym: gen. Πλουτέως, -έος, Anth.; dat. Πλουτέϊ, -ῆι; acc. Πλουτέα Anth., etc.

div1.head: πλουτέω
div1.sense: to be rich, wealthy, Hes., Theogn., Hdt., Attic; πλ. ἀπὸ τῶν κοινῶν to be rich from the public purse, Ar.
c. gen. rei, to be rich in a thing, Xen.
c. dat. rei, πλ. ἐμπύροισιν Eur., Xen.
c. acc. cogn., πλ. πλοῦτον Luc.

div1.head: πλουτηρός
div1.sense: enriching, ἔργον Xen.

div1.head: πλουτητέος
div1.sense: one must become rich, Luc.

div1.head: πλουτίζω
div1.sense: to make wealthy, enrich, Aesch., Xen.; ironic., πλ. τινὰ ἄταις Aesch.:—Pass., Ἅιδης γόοις πλουτίζεται Soph.; πλ. ἀπὸ βοσκημάτων, ἐκ τῆς πόλεως to gain oneʼs wealth from . . , Xen.

div1.head: πλουτίνδην
div1.sense: adv. according to wealth, πλ. αἱρεῖσθαι τοὺς ἄρχοντας Arist.

div1.head: πλουτογαθής
div1.sense: rejoicing in riches, wealthy, Aesch.

div1.head: πλουτοδότης
div1.sense: giver of riches, Hes., Anth.

div1.head: πλουτοκρατία
div1.sense: plutocracy, Xen.

div1.head: πλουτοποιός
div1.sense: wealth-creating, Plut.

div1.head: πλοῦτος
div1.sense: wealth, riches, Hom., etc.; πλοῦτος χρυσοῦ, ἀργύρου treasure of gold, silver, Hdt.:—metaph., γᾶς πλ. ἄβυσσος, of the whole earth, Aesch.; πλοῦτος εἵματος Aesch.
as prop. n. Plutus, god of riches, Hes.

div1.head: πλουτόχθων
div1.sense: rich in earthly treasures, in allusion perh. to the silver mines of Laureion, Aesch.

div1.head: Πλούτων
div1.sense: Pluto, god of the nether world, Trag.: (prob. from πλοῦτος) the wealth-giver, as spouse of Demeter, who enriched men with the fruits of the earth.

div1.head: πλοχμός
div1.sense: like πλόκαμος, mostly in pl. locks, braids of hair, Il., Anth.
the tendrils of the polypus, Anth.

div1.head: πλυνός
div1.sense: a trough, tank, or pit, in which dirty clothes were washed by treading, Hom.
metaph., πλυνὸν ποιεῖν τινα, πλύνω II, Ar.

div1.head: πλυντήριος
div1.sense: of or for washing: Πλυντήρια (sc. ἱερά), τά, a festival at Athens, in which the clothes of Athenaʼs statue were washed, Xen., etc.

div1.head: πλύνω
div1.sense: to wash, clean, properly of linen and clothes, (opp. to λούομαι to bathe, νίζω to wash the hands or feet), Hom., Attic
to wash off dirt, Od.
as a slang term, πλύνειν τινά (as we say) "to give him a dressing," Ar., Dem.

div1.head: πλύσις
div1.sense: a washing, Plat.

div1.head: πλωΐζω
div1.sense: Ionic imperf. πλωίζεσκον:— to sail on the sea, Hes.; οἱ Ἕλληνες μᾶλλον ἐπλώιζον began to use ships or practise navigation, Thuc.:—as Dep. πλωίζομαι, Strab., Luc.

div1.head: πλώϊμος
div1.sense: fit for sailing:
of a ship, fit for sea, seaworthy, Thuc.
of navigation, πλωιμωτέρων γενομένων or ὄντων as navigation advanced, as circumstances became favourable for navigation, Thuc.

div1.head: πλώσιμος
div1.sense: navigable, πέλαγος Soph.

div1.head: πλωτεύομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be navigated, of the sea, to navigate, Polyb.

div1.head: πλωτήρ
div1.sense: a sailor, seaman, Ar., Plat.; including rowers and navigators, Arist.

div1.head: πλωτικός
div1.sense: skilled in seamanship, a seaman, Plat., Plut.; also a shipowner, Plut.

div1.head: πλωτός
div1.sense: floating, Od., Hdt.; πλωτοί swimmers, i. e. fish, Anth.
navigable, Hdt.
of seasons, fit for navigation, Polyb.

div1.head: πνεῦμα
div1.sense: a blowing, πνεύματα ἀνέμων Hdt., Aesch.: alone, a wind, blast, Trag., etc.
metaph., θαλερωτέρῳ πν. with more genial breeze or influence, Aesch.; λύσσης πν. μάργῳ Aesch.; πν. ταὐτὸν οὔποτʼ ἐν ἀνδράσιν φίλοις βέβηκεν the wind is constantly changing even among friends, Soph.

like Lat. spiritus or anima, breathed air, breath, Aesch.; πν. βίου the breath of life, Aesch.; πν. ἀθροίζειν to collect breath, Eur.; πν. ἀφιέναι, ἀνιέναι, μεθιέναι to give up the ghost, Eur.; πνεύματος διαρροαί the wind-pipe, Eur.
that is breathed forth, odour, scent, Eur.
spirit, Lat. afflatus, Anth.: inspiration, NTest.
the spirit of man, NTest.
a spirit; in NTest. of the Holy Spirit, τὸ Πνεῦμα, Πν. ἅγιον:— also of angels, NTest.:—of evil spirits, NTest.

div1.head: πνευματικός
div1.sense: of spirit, spiritual, NTest.

div1.head: πνεύμων
div1.note: πνεύμων, in later Attic πλεύμων, ονος, ὁ,
div1.sense: the organ of breathing, the lungs, Lat. pulmo, Il., Plat.: mostly in pl., Trag.; πνεῦμʼ ἀνεὶς ἐκ πλευμόνων Eur.

div1.head: πνευστιάω
div1.sense: to breathe hard, pant, Arist.; Epic part. πνευστιόων, Anth.

div1.head: πνέω
div1.etym: Like other dissyl. Verbs in -έω, this Verb only contracts εε, εει
div1.sense: to blow, of wind and air, Od., Hdt., Attic; ἡ πνέουσα (sc. αὔρα) the breeze, NTest.
to breathe, send forth an odour, Od.:—c. gen. to breathe or smell of a thing, Anth.
of animals, to breathe hard, pant, gasp, Il., Aesch.
generally, to draw breath, breathe, and so to live, Hom.; οἱ πνέοντες οἱ ζῶντες, Soph.

metaph., c. acc. cogn. to breathe forth, breathe, μένεα πνείοντες breathing spirit, of warriors, Il.; so, πῦρ πν. Hes.; φόνον, κότον, Ἄρη Aesch.; so, πνέοντας δόρυ καὶ λόγχας Ar.; Ἀλφειὸν πνέων, of a swift runner, Ar.
μέγα πνεῖν to be of a high spirit, give oneself airs, Eur.; τόσονδʼ ἔπνευσας Eur.:—also, with a nom., as if it were the wind, μέγας πνέων Eur.; πολὺς ἔπνει καὶ λαμπρὸς ἦν Dem.

div1.head: πνιγεύς
div1.sense: an oven, heated by hot coals put inside it, like our brick ovens, Ar.

div1.head: πνιγηρός
div1.sense: choking, stifling, Ar.

div1.head: πνιγμός
div1.sense: a choking or being choked, Xen.

div1.head: πνῖγος
div1.sense: stifling heat, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: πνίγω
div1.sense: to choke, throttle, strangle, Plat.; proverb., ὅταν τὸ ὕδωρ πνίγηι, τί δεῖ ἐπιπίνειν; if water chokes, why should one drink more? Arist.:—Pass. to be choked, stifled, Ar.: to be drowned, Xen.
metaph. to vex, torment, Luc.
to cook in a close-covered vessel, to stew, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: πνικτός
div1.sense: strangled, NTest.

div1.head: πνοή
div1.sense: a blowing, blast, breeze, Hom.: ἅμα πνοιῇς ἀνέμοιο along with, i. e. swift as, blasts of wind, Hom.; μετὰ πνοιῇς ἀνέμοιο Hom., etc.:— the blast of bellows, Thuc.
of animals, a breathing hard, of horses, Il., Soph.
generally, breath, ἔμπνους ἔτʼ εἰμὶ καὶ πνοὰς πνέω Eur.:—metaph., πνοιὴ Ἡφαίστοιο the breath of Hephaestus, i. e. flame, Il.; θεοῦ πνοαῖσιν ἐμμανεῖς Eur.
a breathing odour, a vapour, exhalation, σποδὸς προπέμπει πλούτου πνοάς, of a burning city, Aesch.
the breath of a wind-instrument, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: πνύξ
div1.sense: the Pnyx, the place at Athens where the ἐκκλησίαι were held, Ar.; ἐν πυκνὶ ἐν τῇ ἐκκλησίᾳ Dem. It was cut out of the side of a little hill west of the Acropolis, being of a semicircular form like a theatre.

div1.head: ποάζω
div1.sense: of ground, produce grass, Strab.

div1.head: πόα
div1.sense: grass, herb, Hom., etc.; ποία Μηδική, Lat. herba Medica, sainfoin or lucerne, Ar.
the grass, i. e. a grassy place, plat., Xen.
in Poets, of Time, τέσσαρας πόας four grasses, i. e. summers, Anth.

div1.head: ποδαβρός
div1.sense: tenderfooted, Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: ποδάγρα
div1.sense: a trap for the feet, Xen., Anth.
gout in the feet, opp. to χειράγρα.

div1.head: ποδαγράω
div1.sense: to have gout in the feet, Ar.

div1.head: ποδαγρικός
div1.sense: liable to gout, gouty, Plut.

div1.head: ποδανιπτήρ
div1.sense: a vessel for washing the feet in, a footpan, Hdt.

div1.head: ποδάνιπτρον
div1.sense: water for washing the feet in, in pl., Od.

div1.head: ποδαπός
div1.sense: from what country? Lat. cujas? generally, whence? where born? Hdt., Trag.; τίς καὶ π.; Plat.
generally, of what sort? ποδαπός; οἷος μὴ δάκνειν . . , of what sort? one that will not bite, Dem.
div1.etym: As in ἀλλοδαπός, ἡμεδαπός, ὑμεδαπός, τηλεδαπός, -δαπος is a termin. of uncertain origin.

div1.head: πόδαργος
div1.sense: swiftfooted or whitefooted:— Πόδαργος, ὁ, swiftfoot or whitefoot, a horse, Il.; fem. Ποδάργη, a Harpy, Il.

div1.head: ποδάρκης
div1.sense: sufficient with the feet, swiftfooted, of Achilles, Il.; ποδάρκης ἁμέρα a day of swiftness, i. e. on which swift runners contended, Pind.; ποδαρκέων δρόμων τέμενος the field of swift courses, i. e. the Pythian racecourse, Pind.

div1.head: ποδένδυτος
div1.sense: drawn over the feet, Aesch.

div1.head: ποδεών
div1.sense: in pl., the ragged ends in the skins of animals, formed by the feet and tail, δέρμα λέοντος ἀφημμένον ἄκρων ἐκ ποδεώνων a lionʼs skin hung round oneʼs neck by the paws, Theocr.
in sg. the neck or mouth of a wineskin, formed by one of these ends, the others being sewn up, Hdt.
generally any narrow end, a strip of land, Hdt.
the lower corner of a sail, the sheet, Luc.

div1.head: ποδηγός
div1.sense: a guide, attendant, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ποδηνεκής
div1.sense: reaching to the feet, Il., Hdt.

div1.head: ποδήνεμος
div1.sense: windswift, of Iris, Il.

div1.head: ποδήρης
div1.sense: reaching to the feet, πέπλος, χιτὼν π. a frock that falls over the feet, as in the archaic Greek statues, Eur., Xen.; π. ἀσπίς the large shield which covered the body quite down to the feet, Xen.; στῦλος π. a straight, firm pillar, Aesch.
τὰ ποδήρη the parts about the feet, the feet, Aesch.

div1.head: ποδιαῖος
div1.sense: a foot long, broad, or high, Xen.

div1.head: ποδίζω
div1.sense: to tie the feet:— Pass. to have the feet tied, or to be tied by the foot, of horses, Xen.

div1.head: ποδίκροτος
div1.sense: welded to the feet, Anth.

div1.head: ποδιστήρ
div1.sense: foot-entangling, of a long robe, Aesch.

div1.head: ποδίστρα
div1.sense: a foottrap, Anth.

div1.head: ποδοκάκκη
div1.sense: ποδο-κάκκη, also written ποδοκάκη, properly, foot plague, a kind of stocks, Dem., etc.

div1.head: ποδοκρουστία
div1.sense: a stamping with the feet, Strab.

div1.head: ποδορραγής
div1.sense: bursting forth at a stamp of the foot, Anth.

div1.head: ποδοστράβη
div1.sense: a snare or trap to catch the feet, Xen.

div1.head: ποδόψηστρον
div1.sense: a footwiper, footcloth, Aesch.

div1.head: ποδώκεια
div1.sense: swiftness of foot, Il., Eur.,

div1.head: ποδώκης
div1.sense: swiftfooted, of Achilles, Il.; π. ἄνθρωπος Thuc.; λαγώς Xen.
generally, swift, quick, ὄμμα Aesch.; θεῶν π. βλάβαι Soph.

div1.head: ποηφαγέω
div1.sense: to eat grass, Hdt.

div1.head: ποθεινός
div1.sense: longed for, desired, much desired, esp. if absent or lost (v. πόθος, Trag.; ποθεινὸς ἦλθες Eur.; π. δάκρυα tears of regret, Eur.; π. τοῖς φίλοις Ar.:—adv., ποθεινοτέρως ἔχειν τινός to long greatly for a thing, Xen.

div1.head: ποθεν
div1.sense: enclit, adv. from some place or other, εἴ ποθεν Il.; εἰ καί π. ἄλλοθεν ἔλθοι Od.

div1.head: πόθεν
div1.sense: interrog. adv. whence?
of place, ἠρώτα, τίς εἴη καὶ π. ἔλθοι Od.; ποῖ δὴ καὶ πόθεν; Plat.;—c. gen., τίς πόθεν εἶς ἀνδρῶν; who and from what country art thou? Il.; πόθεν γῆς; Eur.
of origin, πόθεν γένος εὔχεται εἶναι; from what source does he boast that his race is? Od.
in speaking, π. ἄρξωμαι; Aesch.
of the cause, whence? wherefore? Aesch.; alone, πόθεν; how can it be? impossible! Eur., Ar.

div1.head: ποθέω
div1.sense: to long for, yearn after what is absent, to miss or regret what is lost, Lat. desiderare, Hom., etc.; ποθεῖς τὸν οὐ παρόντα Ar.; π. τὰς ἐν τῆι νεότητι ἡδονάς Plat.:—Pass., ὦ ποθουμένη (sc. Εἰρήνη) Ar.
of things, to require, ποθεῖ ἡ ἀπόκρισις ἐρώτησιν τοιάνδε Plat.
c. inf. to be anxious to do, Eur.; τὸ νοσοῦν ποθεῖ σε ξυμπαραστάτην λαβεῖν my sickness needs to take thee as an assistant, Soph.
absol., τὸ ποθοῦν oneʼs desiring, oneʼs longing, Soph.
as Dep., ποθουμένη φρήν the longing soul, Soph.

div1.head: ποθή
div1.sense: fond desire for one, ἐμεῖο ποθὴν ἀπεόντος ἔχουσιν Il.; σῇ ποθῇ from longing after thee, Il.
want of a thing, c. gen., Od.

div1.head: ποθι
div1.sense: enclit, adv., poet. for του, anywhere or somewhere, Il., Soph.
of Time, αἴ κέ ποθι Ζεὺς δῷσι if ever Zeus grant, Il.: at length, Od.
indefinite, soever, haply, probably, Hom.

div1.head: πόθι
div1.sense: interrog. adv. where? Od., Soph.;—c. gen., πόθι Νύσας; in what part of Nysa? Eur.
for ποῖ; whither? Anth.

div1.head: ποθόβλητος
div1.sense: love-stricken, Anth.

div1.head: πόθος
div1.sense: a longing, yearning, fond desire or regret (for something absent or lost), Lat. desiderium, Hom., etc.
c. gen. desire or regret for a person or thing, Hom.; so, δὸς π. yearning after thee, Od.; τοὐμῷ πόθῳ Soph.
love, desire, Hes., etc.

div1.head: ποιέω
div1.etym: Att. Poets often use the penult. short, as ποιῶ, ποιεῖν, etc., which are often written ποῶ, ποεῖν, etc., as in Lat. poeta, poesis.
the perfect passive is also used in middle sense
div1.sense: Used in two general senses, to make and to do.

to make, produce, create, in Hom. often of building, π. δῶμα, τεῖχος, etc.; of smithʼs work, π. σάκος Il.; of works of art, Il., etc.; ποιεῖν τι ἀπὸ ξύλου to make something of wood, Hdt.; π. πλοῖα ἐξ ἀκάνθης Hdt.; so, c. gen., π. νηὸν λίθου Hdt.; φοίνικος αἱ θύραι πεποιημέναι Xen.:—Mid., οἰκία ποιήσασθαι to build them houses, Il.; also, to have a thing made, get it made, Hdt., Dem.
to make, create, ἕτερον φίλιππον ποιήσετε Dem.

of Poets, to compose, write, (old English to make), Lat. carmina facere, Hdt., Attic:—also, to make or represent in poetry, Ὅμηρος Ἀχιλλέα πεποίηκε ἀμείνω Ὀδυσσέως Plat.: to describe in verse, Plat.: to put into verse, Plat.
to bring to pass, bring about, cause, Hom., etc.: c. acc. et inf. to cause or bring about that . . , Od., etc.

of sacrifices, and the like, π. ἱρά, like ἕρδειν, Lat. sacra facere, Hdt., Xen., Thuc., etc.; π. Ἴσθμια to hold the Isthmian games, Xen.; π. ἐκκλησίαν (as we say, to make a house), Thuc.:—Mid. in same sense, but implying indirect action, ἀγορὴν ποιήσατο Il.

of war and peace, πόλεμον ποιεῖν to cause a war, but, π. ποιεῖσθαι to make war (on oneʼs own part), Xen.;—so, εἰρήνην π. to bring about a peace (for others); but, εἰρήνην ποιεῖσθαι to make peace (for oneself), etc.

the Mid. is often used periphr. with Nouns, ποιεῖσθαι ὁδοιπορίην for ὁδοιπορεῖν, π. πλόον for πλέειν, θαῦμα π. for θαυμάζειν, ὀργὴν π. for ὀργίζεσθαι, Hdt. etc.:— π. λόγον τινός to make account of . . , Hdt.; but, τοὺς λόγους π. to hold a conference, Thuc.

with an adj. as predic. to make so and so, ποιεῖν τινα ἄφρονα to make one senseless, Od.; δῶρα ὄλβια ποιεῖν to make them blest, i. e. prosper them, Od.; π. τοὺς Μήδους ἀσθενεῖς Xen.:—so with a Subst., ποιεῖν τινα βασιλῆα Od.; Ἀθηναῖον π. τινα Thuc.:—Mid., ποιεῖσθαί τινα ἄλοχον or ἄκοιτιν to take her to oneself as wife, Il.; ποιεῖσθαί τινα υἱόν to make him oneʼs son, i. e. to adopt him as son (cf. εἰσποιέω), Il., Attic:—also, ἑωυτοῦ ποιεῖσθαί τι to make a thing oneʼs own, Hdt.
to put, π. τι ἐνὶ φρεσί τινι Hom.; π. τι ἐπὶ νόον τινί Hdt.
in war, π. τινας ὑπό τινι to bring under the power of . . , Dem.:—Mid., ποιεῖσθαι ὑπʼ ἑωυτῶι Hdt.; ποιεῖσθαί τινας ἐς τὸ συμμαχικόν Hdt., etc.

in Mid. to hold, deem, consider, reckon, esteem a thing as . . , συμφορὴν ποιεῖσθαί τι to take it for a visitation, Hdt.; δεινὸν ποιεῖσθαί τι, Lat. aegre ferre, Hdt.; μέγα π., c. inf., to deem it a great matter that . . , Hdt.; οὐκ ἀνάσχετον π. τι Thuc., etc.:—often with Preps., διʼ οὐδενὸς π. τι to hold as naught, Soph.;—ἐν ἐλαφρῶι, ἐν ὁμοίωι π. Hdt.; ἐν σμικρῶι, ἐν ὀργῆι Dem.;—παρʼ ὀλίγον, παρʼ οὐδὲν π. τι Xen.;—περὶ πολλοῦ, περὶ πλείονος, περὶ πλείστου ποιεῖσθαί τι Attic
to put the case assume, that . . , Hdt., Xen.:—Pass., οἱ φιλοσοφώτατοι ποιούμενοι those who are reputed . . , Plat.
of Time, οὐ π. χρόνον to make no long time, i. e. not to delay, Dem.; τὴν νύκτα ἐφʼ ὅπλοις ποιεῖσθαι to spend it under arms, Thuc.
to do, much like πράσσω, Hom., etc.; οὐδὲν ἂν ὧν νυνὶ πεποίηκεν ἔπραξεν Dem.; Σπαρτιητικὰ ποιέειν to act like a Spartan, Hdt.; προσταχθὲν π. Soph., etc.
c. acc. dupl. to do something to another, κακά or ἀγαθὰ ποιεῖν τινά Hdt., etc.; also εὖ, κακῶς π. τινά Xen., etc.:—also c. dat. pers., ἵππωι τἀναντία π. Xen.; so in Mid., φίλα ποιεῖσθαί τινι Hdt.

with an adv., ὧδε ποίησον do thus, Hdt.; ποίει ὅπως βούλει Xen.;—so with a partic., εὖ ἐποίησας ἀπικόμενος Hdt., etc.:— καλῶς ποιῶν is sometimes almost Adverbial, καλῶς ποιοῦντες πράττετε Dem.; εὖ ποιοῦν fortunately, Dem.

absol. to be doing, to do or act, ποιέειν ἢ παθέειν to do or have done to one, Hdt.:—of medicine, to work, operate, Plat.; so, ἡ εὔνοια παρὰ πολὺ ἐποίει ἐς τοὺς Λακεδαιμονίους good-will made greatly for the Lacedaemonians, Thuc.; so impers., ἐπὶ πολὺ ἐποίει τῆς δόξης τοῖς μὲν ἠπειρώταις εἶναι it was the general character of the one to be landsmen, etc., Thuc.

div1.head: ποιήεις
div1.sense: grassy, rich in grass, Hom., Soph.: neut. pl. contr. ποιᾶντα Pind.

div1.head: ποίημα
div1.sense: anything made or done; hence,
a work, Hdt., Plat.
a poetical work, poem, Plat.
a deed, act, Plat.

div1.head: ποίησις
div1.sense: a making, fabrication, creation, production, opp. to πρᾶξις (action), Hdt., Attic
of poetry, ἡ π. τῆς τραγῳδίας, etc., Plat.: absol. poetic faculty, poesy, art of poetry, Hdt., Ar., etc.
a poetic composition, poem, Thuc., Plat.
= εἰσποίησις, adoption, Dem.

div1.head: ποιητέος
div1.sense: to be made or done, Hdt., Attic; τὸ ποιητέον what must be done, Thuc.

div1.head: ποιητής
div1.sense: one who makes, a maker, Xen., etc.
the maker of a poem, a poet, Hdt., etc.
generally, a writer, Plat.

div1.head: ποιητικός
div1.sense: capable of making, creative, productive, Arist.
fitted for a poet, poetical, Plat.;— ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the art of poetry, poetry, Plat.:—adv. -κῶς, Plat.

div1.head: ποιητός
div1.sense: made, in the sense of εὖ ποιητός, well-made, δόμοις ἐνὶ ποιητοῖσι Hom.:— made, created, opp. to self-existent, Theogn.
made into something, esp. made into a son, adopted, Plat.; π. πολῖται factitious citizens, not so born, Arist.
made by oneself, i. e. invented, feigned, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: ποιήτρια
div1.sense: a poetess, Luc.

div1.head: ποικιλάνιος
div1.sense: with broidered reins, Pind.

div1.head: ποικιλείμων
div1.sense: with spangled garb, νὺξ π., in reference to the stars, Aesch.

div1.head: ποικιλία
div1.sense: a marking with various colours, embroidering, embroidery, Plat.: in pl. pieces of broidery, Xen.
varied aspect, diversity, Plat.
versatility, subtlety, craft, Dem.

div1.head: ποικίλλω
div1.sense: to work in various colours, to broider, work in embroidery, Eur.; χορὸν ποίκιλλε he wrought a χορός of cunning workmanship, Il.
to embroider a robe, Pind., Plat., etc.
generally, to diversify, vary, Eur., Plat.:—of style, to embellish, Pind.:— to speak as in riddles, Soph.

div1.head: ποίκιλμα
div1.sense: a broidered stuff, brocade, Aesch.
broidered work, broidery, Hom.
generally, a variety, diversity, Plat.

div1.head: ποικιλόβουλος
div1.sense: of changeful counsel, wily-minded, Hes., Anth.

div1.head: ποικιλόγηρυς
div1.note: ποικῐλό-γηρυς, Doric ποικῐλό-γᾱρυς, υος, ὁ, ἡ,
div1.sense: of varied voice, many-toned, Pind.

div1.head: ποικιλόδειρος
div1.sense: with variegated neck, Anth.

div1.head: ποικιλοδέρμων
div1.sense: with pied skin, Eur.

div1.head: ποικιλόθριξ
div1.sense: with spotted hair, dappled, Eur.

div1.head: ποικιλόθρονος
div1.sense: on rich-worked throne, Sapph.

div1.head: ποικιλομήτης
div1.sense: full of various wiles, wily-minded, Hom.

div1.head: ποικιλομήχανος
div1.sense: full of various devices, Anth.

div1.head: ποικιλόμορφος
div1.sense: of varied form, variegated, Ar.

div1.head: ποικιλόμυθος
div1.sense: of various discourse, Anth.

div1.head: ποικιλόνωτος
div1.sense: with back of various hues, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: ποικιλόπτερος
div1.sense: with wings of changeful hue, Eur.

div1.head: ποικίλος
div1.sense: many-coloured, spotted, mottled, pied, dappled, of leopards, fawns, Hom., etc.
of robes, wrought in various colours, broidered, Il., etc.; ἐν ποικίλοις κάλλεσιν, of a rich carpet, Aesch.; so, τὰ ποικίλα Aesch.
of metal work, τεύχεα π. χαλκῷ in-wrought with brass, Il., etc.: but, π. δεσμός intricate, Od.
ἡ στοὰ ἡ ποικίλη, the Poecile or great hall at Athens adorned with paintings of the battle of Marathon by Polygnotus, Aeschin., etc.
metaph. changeful, various, diversified, manifold, Aesch., Plat.;— π. μῆνες the changing months, Pind.
of Art, π. ὕμνος a song of changeful strain or full of diverse art, Pind.; so, ποικίλον κιθαρίζων Pind.
intricate, complex, Hdt., Soph., etc.: —adv., ποικίλως αὐδώμενος speaking in double sense, Soph.
of abstruse knowledge, intricate, subtle, ποικίλον τι εἰδέναι Eur.; οὐδὲν π. nothing abstruse or difficult, Plat.:—so, of persons, subtle, wily, Aesch.; π. γὰρ ἁνήρ Ar.
changeable, changeful, unstable, Arist.:— ποικίλως ἔχειν to be different, Xen.

div1.head: ποικιλόστολος
div1.sense: of a ship, with variegated prow, Soph.

div1.head: ποικιλοτερπής
div1.sense: delighting by variety, Anth.

div1.head: ποικιλότευκτος
div1.sense: manifold, Anth.

div1.head: ποικιλότραυλος
div1.sense: twittering in various notes, Theocr.

div1.head: ποικιλοφόρμιγξ
div1.sense: accompanied by the various notes of the lyre, Pind.

div1.head: ποικιλτέος
div1.sense: one must work in embroidery, Plat.

div1.head: ποικιλτής
div1.sense: a broiderer, Aeschin.

div1.head: ποικιλῳδός
div1.sense: of perplexed and juggling song, Soph.

div1.head: ποιμαίνω
div1.sense: to be shepherd, ἐπʼ ὄεσσι over the sheep, Il.: c. acc. to tend a flock, Od., Eur., etc.; absol., Theocr.:—Pass., like νέμομαι, to roam the pastures, of flocks, Il., Eur.
in Aesch., πᾶς πεποίμανται τόπος every place has been traversed (as by a shepherd seeking after stray sheep).
metaph. to tend, cherish, mind, Pind., Aesch.
like βουκολέω, to beguile, Theocr.: generally, to deceive, Eur.

div1.head: ποιμανόριον
div1.sense: a herd: metaph. an army, Aesch.

div1.head: ποιμενικός
div1.sense: of or for a shepherd, Theocr.: —ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , Plat.

div1.head: ποιμήν
div1.sense: voc. ποιμήν, a herdsman or shepherd, Hom.: after Hom. always a shepherd, Eur., Plat., etc.
metaph. a shepherd of the people, of Agamemnon, Hom., etc.; generally, a captain, chief, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ποιμνήϊος
div1.sense: of a flock or herd, Il., Hes.

div1.head: ποίμνη
div1.sense: a flock, Od.; properly of sheep (cf. ποιμήν) , Hes., Hdt.; of a ram, Eur.
metaph. of persons, Aesch.

div1.head: ποίμνιον
div1.sense: syncop. for ποιμένιον, ποίμνη, a flock, Hdt., Soph., etc.
metaph. of disciples, NTest.

div1.head: ποιμνίτης
div1.sense: ὑμέναιος π. a shepherdʼs marriage song, Eur.

div1.head: ποιναῖος
div1.sense: punishing, avenging, Anth.

div1.head: ποινάτωρ
div1.sense: an avenger, punisher, Aesch.

div1.head: ποινάω
div1.sense: to avenge, punish:—Mid. to avenge oneself on another, c. acc., Eur.

div1.head: ποινή
div1.sense: quit-money for blood spilt, paid by the slayer to the kinsmen of the slain, (old Engl. were-gild); c. gen. pers., δῶχʼ υἷος ποινήν gave ransom or were-gild for the son, Il., etc.:—generally, a price paid, satisfaction, retribution, requital, penalty, Lat. poena, ἀπετίσατο ποινὴν ἑτάρων exacted penalty for his comrades, Od.; δυώδεκα κούρους, ποινὴν Πατρόκλοιο in retribution for the death of Patroclus, Il.; τῶν ποινήν in return for these things, Il.; ποινὴν τῖσαι Ξέρξῃ τῶν κηρύκων ἀπολομένων to give Xerxes satisfaction for the death of his heralds, Hdt.; in Attic the pl. is more common; ποινὰς τῖσαι, δοῦναι to pay penalties, Lat. dare poenas, Aesch., etc.; ποινὰς λαβεῖν to exact them, Lat. sumere poenas, Eur.
in good sense, recompense, reward for a thing, τινος Pind.
as the result of the quit-money, redemption, release, Pind.
personified, the goddess of Vengeance, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ποινῆτις
div1.sense: avenging, Anth.

div1.head: ποίνιμος
div1.sense: avenging, punishing, Soph.
in good sense, bringing return or recompense, Pind.

div1.head: ποιολογέω
div1.sense: to gather corn into sheaves, Theocr.

div1.head: ποιονόμος
div1.sense: feeding on grass or herbs, Aesch.

div1.head: ποιός
div1.sense: Indef. adj., of a certain nature, kind or quality, Plat.

div1.head: ποῖος
div1.sense: of what nature? of what sort? Lat. qualis? used in questions:—in Hom. expressing surprise and anger, ποῖον τὸν μῦθον ἔειπες what manner of speech hast thou spoken! ποῖόν σε ἔπος φύγεν ἕρκος ὀδόντων! ποῖον ἔειπες! etc.
ποῖος οὐ; interrog., equiv. to ἕκαστος affirm., Hdt., Soph.
in Attic, often with Art., τὸ ποῖον φάρμακον; Aesch.; τὰ ποῖα τρύχη; Ar.; τὸ ποῖον; Plat., etc.
ποῖός τις; makes the question less definite, κοῖόν μέ τινα νομίζουσιν εἶναι; Hdt.; ποῖʼ ἄττα; Plat.; τὰ τοῖʼ ἄττα; Xen.
ποίᾳ, Ionic κοίῃ, as Adv., = πῶς; Lat. quomodo? Hdt., Ar.
like ὁποῖος, in indirect questions, διδάξω ποῖα χρὴ λέγειν Aesch. etc. (ποῖος, πόσος must be referred to a primitive *πός, as the correlat. Adjs. οἷος, ὅσος to ὅς.)

div1.head: ποιότης
div1.sense: quality, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: ποι
div1.sense: enclit. adv. somewhither, Soph., Ar., etc.

div1.head: ποιπνύω
div1.etym: υ of pres. long before a long syll., short before a short syll
div1.sense: to be out of breath from haste, to puff or bustle about, Lat. satagere, exert oneself, be busy, Hom.; aor1 part. with another Verb. δῶμα κορήσατε ποιπνύσασαι make haste and sweep the house, Od.

div1.head: ποῖ
div1.sense: interrog. adv. whether? Lat. quo? theogn., etc.
c. gen., ποῖ χθονός; ποῖ γῆς; to what spot of earth? Aesch.; ποῖ φροντίδος; ποῖ φρενῶν; ποῖ γνώμης; Soph.

trans.i: to what end? in what point?

div1.head: ποίφυγμα
div1.sense: a blowing, snorting, Aesch.

div1.head: ποιφύσσω
div1.sense: to blow, snort: c. acc. to puff out, Anth.

div1.head: ποιώδης
div1.sense: like grass, Hdt.

div1.head: ποκίζω
div1.sense: to shear wool: Mid. to shear for oneself, τρίχας ἐποκίξατο (Doric aor1) Theocr.

div1.head: ποκόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be clothed with wool, Anth.

div1.head: πόκος
div1.sense: wool in its raw state, a fleece, Il., Eur., etc.: a lock or tuft of wool, Soph.
proverb. in heterocl. acc. of 3rd decl., εἰς ὄνου πόκας to an ass shearing, i. e. to no-place, Ar.

div1.head: πολεμάρχειος
div1.sense: of or belonging to the Polemarch; —τὸ πολεμάρχειον his residence, Xen.

div1.head: πολεμαρχέω
div1.sense: to be Polemarch, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: πολέμαρχος
div1.sense: one who begins or leads the war, a leader, chieftain, Aesch.
a Polemarch,
at Athens, the third archon, who presided in the court in which the causes of the μέτοικοι were tried, Ar.;—in earlier times he was general-in-chief, as at Marathon, Hdt.
at Sparta, a kind of brigadier, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
at Thebes officers of chief rank after the Boeotarchs, Xen.
similarly at Mantineia, and in other states, Thuc.

div1.head: πολεμέω
div1.sense: to be at war or go to war, make war, τινί with one, Hdt., etc.; ἐπί τινα, πρός τινα Xen.
to fight, do battle, ἀπὸ τῶν ἵππων Plat.; ἀπὸ καμήλων Xen.
generally, to quarrel, wrangle, dispute with one, Soph., etc.
c. acc. to make war upon: Pass. to have war made upon one, to be treated as enemies, Thuc., Xen.
c. acc. cogn., πόλεμον πολ. Plat.:—Pass., ὁ πόλεμος οὕτως ἐπολεμήθη Xen.; so, ὅσα ἐπολεμήθη whatever hostilities passed, Xen.

div1.head: πολεμηδόκος
div1.sense: war-sustaining, Pind.

div1.head: πολεμήϊος
div1.etym: Ionic adj.,for no Attic form in -ειος exists
div1.sense: warlike, πολεμήια ἔργα Il.; τεύχεα Il.; πολεμήια= πολέμια, ων, τά, Hdt.

div1.head: πολεμητέος
div1.sense: one must go to war, Arist.:—pl. πολεμητέα, Thuc.

div1.head: πολεμίζω
div1.sense: Epic πτολεμίζω, fut. ίξω, poet. form of πολεμέω, to wage war, make war, fight, τινί with one, Hom.; π. ἄντα τινός, ἐναντίβιόν τινος Il.:—also in Mid., Pind.
to fight with, absol. ῥηίτεροι πολεμίζειν Il.

div1.head: πολεμικός
div1.sense: of or for war, Thuc.; ἀσπὶς πολεμικωτάτη most fit for service, Xen.
ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the art of war, war, Plat.: —τὰ πολεμικά warlike exercises, Thuc., Xen.
τὸ πολεμικόν the signal for battle, Xen.
the military class, opp. to the civilian, Arist.
of persons, skilled in war, warlike, Thuc., etc.
like an enemy, stirring up hostility, Xen.:—adv., πολεμικῶς ἔχειν to be hostile, Xen.

div1.head: πολέμιος
div1.sense: of or belonging to war, Pind., Aesch., etc.: —τὰ πολέμια whatever belongs to war, war and its business, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
of or like an enemy, hostile, Pind., Trag., etc.: —p. tini hostile to one, Hdt., etc.:—as Subst. an enemy, Hdt., Attic; οἱ π. the enemy, Thuc.: —τὸ π. hostility, Thuc.
generally, opposed, adverse, Hdt., Plat.
of or from the enemy, Aesch., Thuc.; πολέμια, ων, τά, enemyʼs wares, contraband, Ar.: —ἡ πολεμία (sc. γῆ, χώρα) , the enemyʼs country, Xen.
adv. -ίως, in hostile manner, Thuc.

div1.head: πολεμιστήριος
div1.sense: of or for a warrior, Hdt.; βοή, θώραξ π. Ar.; π. ἅρματα war- chariots, Hdt.; ἐλᾶν τὰ πολεμιστήρια to drive the war-chariots, a military game, Ar.
τὰ πολεμιστήρια, τὰ πολεμικά, Xen.

div1.head: πολεμιστής
div1.sense: a warrior, combatant, Il., Pind., etc.
π. ἵππος a war-horse, charger, Theocr.

div1.head: πολεμόκλονος
div1.sense: raising the din of war, Batr.

div1.head: πολεμόκραντος
div1.sense: finishing war, Aesch.

div1.head: πολεμολαμαχαϊκός
div1.etym: a compd. of πόλεμος, Λάμαχος, Ἀχαϊκός
div1.sense: a very Lamachus in war, Ar.

div1.head: πόλεμόνδε
div1.sense: to the war, into the fight, Il.

div1.head: πολεμοποιέω
div1.sense: to stir up war, Xen.

div1.head: πολεμοποιός
div1.sense: engaging in war, Arist.

div1.head: πόλεμος
div1.sense: battle, fight, war, Hom., etc.; πόλεμον αἴρεσθαί τινι to levy war against another, Aesch.; π. θέσθαι τινί Eur.; π. ἀναιρεῖσθαι, κινεῖν, ἐγείρειν, καθιστάναι, ἐπάγειν to begin a war; π. ποιεῖσθαι to make war, — opp. to π. ἀναπαύειν, καταλύεσθαι to put an end to it, make peace, all in Attic

div1.head: πολεμοφθόρος
div1.sense: wasting by war, Aesch.

div1.head: πολεμόω
div1.sense: to make hostile, make an enemy of, τινά:—Mid., πῶς οὐ πολεμώσεσθε αὐτούς; surely you will make them your enemies, Thuc.:— Pass. to be made an enemy of, become an enemy, Thuc.

div1.head: πολεύω
div1.etym: πολεύω like πολέω, only in pres.
div1.sense: intr. to turn about, Lat. versari, κατὰ ἄστυ π. to go about the city, i. e. live therein, Od.
trans. to turn up the soil with the plough, Soph.

div1.head: πολέω
div1.etym: πολέω like πολεύω, only in pres.
div1.sense: to go about, range over, νῆσον Αἴαντος πολεῖ Aesch.; τί σὺ τῆιδε πολεῖς; Eur.:—so in Mid., Aesch.
trans. to turn up the earth with the plough, to plough, Hes.

div1.head: πολιαίνομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to grow white, Aesch.

div1.head: πολιά
div1.sense: grayness of hair, Menand.

div1.head: πολίαρχος
div1.sense: ruler of a city, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: Πολιάς
div1.sense: guardian of the city, epith. of Athena in her oldest temple on the Acropolis of Athens, as distinguished from Ἀθ. Παρθένος, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: πολίζω
div1.sense: to build a city, to build, Il.:—Pass., Ἴλιος πεπόλιστο (Epic 3rd sg. plup.) Il.; so Hdt.
χωρίον πολίζειν to colonise a country by building a city, Xen.

div1.head: πολιήτης
div1.sense: a citizen, Il., Hdt., Aesch.; a fellow-citizen, countryman, Hdt.
as adj., ψάμαθοι πολιήτιδος ἀκτᾶς sands on my countryʼs shore, Eur.

div1.head: πόλινδε
div1.sense: into or to the city, Il.

div1.head: πολιόθριξ
div1.sense: grayhaired, Strab.

div1.head: πολιοκρόταφος
div1.sense: with gray hair on the temples, i.e. just beginning to be gray, Il., Hes.

div1.head: πολιορκέω
div1.sense: to hem in a city, blockade, beleaguer, besiege, Hdt., Attic:—Pass. to be besieged, in a state of siege, Hdt.; of Scamander, to be dammed back, Plat.
metaph. to be besieged, pestered, Xen.

div1.head: πολιορκητέος
div1.sense: to be besieged, Xen.

div1.head: πολιορκητής
div1.sense: taker of cities, name of Demetrius son of Antigonus, Plut.

div1.head: πολιορκητικός
div1.sense: of or for besieging, Polyb.

div1.head: πολιορκία
div1.sense: a besieging, siege, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
metaph. a besieging, pestering, Plut.

div1.head: πολιός
div1.sense: gray, grizzled, grisly, of wolves, of iron, of the sea, Il.

mostly of hair, gray or hoary from age, Hom.; πολιοί gray-haired men, Od., Soph., etc.:—absol., αἱ πολιαί (sc. τρίχες) Pind.; ἅμα ταῖς πολιαῖς κατιούσαις as the gray hairs come down (i.e. from the temples to the beard), Ar.; π. δάκρυον ἐμβαλών an old manʼs tear, Eur.
metaph. hoary, venerable, Eur.
like λευκός, bright, clear, serene, Hes., Eur.

div1.head: πολιοῦχος
div1.sense: protecting a city, Eur.:—mostly like Πολιεύς, Πολιάς, of the guardian deity of a city, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: πολιόχρως
div1.sense: white-coloured, white, Eur.

div1.head: πόλισμα
div1.sense: a city, town, Hdt., Attic
the community, Soph.

div1.head: πόλις
div1.etym: gen. πόλεως dissyll. in Attic Poets
Ionic and Doric πόλιος dissyll. in Il.
div1.sense: Doric πολίεσι:—acc. πόλεις, πόλιας:— a city, Hom., Hes., etc.; πόλις ἄκρη and ἀκροτάτη, ἀκρόπολις, the citadel, Il.: this at Athens was often called simply πόλις, while the rest of the city was called ἄστυ, Thuc., etc.:—the name of the city was often added in gen., Ἰλίου π., Ἄργους π. the city of . . , Aesch., etc.; also in appos., ἡ Μένδη π. Thuc.
oneʼs city or country, Od., etc.
when πόλις and ἄστυ are joined, the former is the body of citizens, the latter their dwellings, Il.; ὧν πόλις ἀνάριθμος ὄλλυται, where πόλις a number of citizens, Soph.:—hence,
the state (πολιτεία) , Hes., Pind., Attic: esp. a free state, republic, Soph., Xen., etc.
the right of citizenship, like Lat. civitas, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: πολισσονόμος
div1.sense: managing or ruling a city, Aesch.; π. βιοτά a life of social order, Aesch.

div1.head: πολισσόος
div1.sense: guarding cities, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολισσοῦχος
div1.sense: poetic for πολιοῦχος, Aesch.
dwelling in the city, Aesch.

div1.head: πολιτάρχης
div1.sense: a civic magistrate, at Thessalonica, NTest.

div1.head: πολιτεία
div1.sense: the condition and rights of a citizen, citizenship, Lat. civitas, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; πολιτείαν δοῦναί τινι Xen.
the life of a citizen, civic life, Dem.
as a concrete, the body of citizens, Arist.
the life and business of a statesman, government, administration, Ar., Thuc., etc.:—in a collective sense, the measures of a government, Dem.
civil polity, the condition or constitution of a state, Thuc., etc.:— a form of government, Plat., etc.
a republic, commonwealth, Xen., etc.

div1.head: πολίτευμα
div1.sense: the business of government, an act of administration, Dem.; ἔν τε τοῖς κατὰ τὴν πόλιν πολιτεύμασι καὶ ἐν τοῖς Ἑλληνικοῖς both in my home and foreign policy, Dem.
the government, Arist.
= πολιτεία III, Arist.

div1.head: πολιτεύω
div1.sense: to live as a citizen or freeman, live in a free state, Thuc., etc.
to have a certain form of polity, conduct the government, Thuc.:—Pass., of the state, to be governed, Plat., Xen., etc.; τὰ αὐτοῖς πεπολιτευμένα the measures of their administration, Dem.
Dep. like the Act. to be a free citizen, live as such, Xen., etc.
to take part in the government, Thuc., Dem.: to meddle with politics, Plat.

c. acc. to administer or govern, Dem.; π. πόλεμον ἐκ πολέμου to make perpetual war the principle of government, Aeschin.: absol. to conduct the government, Ar., Dem.; οἱ πολιτευόμενοι the ministers, Dem.
to have a certain form of government, Plat., Aeschin.

div1.head: πολίτης
div1.sense: a member of a city or state (πόλις) , a citizen, freeman, Lat. civis, Hom., etc.
like Lat. civis, a fellow-citizen, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
θεοὶ πολῖται πολιοῦχοι, Aesch.

div1.head: πολιτικός
div1.sense: of, for, or relating to citizens, Plat., etc.
