befitting a citizen, like a citizen, civic, civil, Lat. civilis, Thuc.; πολιτικωτέρα ἐγένετο ἡ ὀλιγαρχία more constitutional, Arist.:— adv., πολιτικῶς like a citizen, in a constitutional manner, Lat. civiliter, Dem.
consisting of citizens, τὸ πολιτικόν, οἱ πολῖται, the community, Hdt., Thuc.: the civic force, opp. to οἱ σύμμαχοι, Xen., etc.
living in a community, Arist.
of or befitting a statesman, statesmanlike, Xen., Plat.

belonging to the state or its administration, political, Lat. publicus, Thuc.: —ἡ πολιτική (sub. τέχνη) , the art of government, ἡ π. ἐπιστήμη or ἡ π. alone, the science of politics, Plat.: —τὰ πολιτικά, state-affairs, public matters, government, Thuc., etc.
civil, municipal, opp. to natural or general, Dem.
generally, of or for public life, public, opp. to κατʼ ἰδίας, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πολῖτις
div1.etym: fem. of πολίτης, Soph., Eur., etc.

div1.head: πολιτοφύλαξ
div1.sense: one who watches citizens; οἱ π., in Larissa, the chief magistrates, Arist.

div1.head: πολίχνη
div1.sense: a small town, Plut.

div1.head: πολιώδης
div1.sense: grayish, whitish, Luc.

div1.head: πολλάκις
div1.sense: of Time, many times, often, oft, Il., etc.; c. gen., π. τοῦ μηνός often in the month, Xen.
of Degree and Number, π. μύριοι many tens of thousands, Plat.
τὸ π. mostly, for the most part, Pind.: very much, altogether, Theocr.
in Attic, after εἰ, ἐάν, ἄν, perhaps, perchance, Lat. si forte, Ar., Plat.; so, μὴ πολλάκις, Lat. ne forte, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: πολλαπλάσιος
div1.sense: many times as many, many times more or larger, Hdt.
πολλ. ἢ . . , or ἤπερ . . , many times as many as . . , many times more or larger than . . , Hdt., Plat.; so c. gen., Hdt., Thuc., etc.:— neut. pl. as adv., Xen.

div1.head: πολλαπλασιόω
div1.sense: to multiply, Plat.

div1.head: πολλαπλασίωσις
div1.sense: multiplication, Plat.

div1.head: πολλαπλόος
div1.sense: manifold, many times as long, Plat.; ὄνομα πολλαπλοῦν multicompound, opp. to ἁπλοῦν, Arist.
metaph., ἀνὴρ π. not simple and straightforward, Plat.

div1.head: πολλαχῇ
div1.sense: many times, often, Hdt., Xen.
in divers manners, Hdt., Soph., etc.

div1.head: πολλαχόθεν
div1.sense: from many places or sides, Thuc., etc.
from or for many reasons, Thuc.

div1.head: πολλαχόθι
div1.sense: in many places, Xen.

div1.head: πολλαχόσε
div1.sense: towards many sides, into many parts or quarters, Thuc.; c. gen., π. τῆς Ἀρκαδίας Xen.

div1.head: πολλαχοῦ
div1.sense: in many places, Eur., Plat.
c. gen., π. τῆς γῆς Plat.
= πολλαχῇ, many times, often, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: πολλαχῶς
div1.sense: in many ways, Dem., etc.

div1.head: πολλοδεκάκις
div1.sense: many tens of times, Ar.

div1.head: πολλοστημόριος
div1.sense: many times smaller, Arist.

div1.head: πολλοστός
div1.sense: one of many, Lat. unus e multis, i.e. the smallest, least, Thuc., etc.:— adv., δευτέρως καὶ πολλοστῶς in a very small degree, Arist.
of Time, πολλοστῷ χρόνῳ after a very long time, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: πόλος
div1.sense: a pivot, hinge, axis:
the axis of the globe, Plat., etc.
the sphere which revolves on this axis, i. e. the vault of heaven, the sky or firmament, Lat. polus, Aesch., Eur.
the orbit of a star, Anth.
land turned up with the plough, Xen.
a concave dial (called πόλος from being shaped like the vault of heaven), Hdt., Anth.

div1.head: πολύαγρος
div1.sense: catching much game, Anth.

div1.head: πολύαθλος
div1.sense: conquering in many contests, Luc.

div1.head: πολύαιγος
div1.sense: abounding in goats, Anth.

div1.head: πολύαινος
div1.sense: much-praised, or full of wise speech and lore, Hom., Eur.

div1.head: πολυᾶϊξ
div1.sense: much-rushing, impetuous, furious, Hom.; κάματος π. weariness caused by much fighting, Il.

div1.head: πολυανδρέω
div1.sense: to be full of men, to be populous, Thuc.

div1.head: πολύανδρος
div1.sense: of places, with many men, full of men, Aesch.
of persons, numerous, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυανθής
div1.sense: much-blossoming, blooming, Od.

div1.head: πολυανθρωπία
div1.sense: a large population, multitude of people, Xen.

div1.head: πολυάνθρωπος
div1.sense: full of people, populous, Thuc., etc.
much-frequented, crowded, Luc.
numerous, Polyb.

div1.head: πολυάνωρ
div1.sense: with many men, much-frequented, Eur., Ar.
γυνὴ π. wife of many husbands, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυάργυρος
div1.sense: rich in silver, Hdt.

div1.head: πολυάρατος
div1.sense: much-desired, Od.

div1.head: πολυαρκής
div1.sense: much-helpful, supplying many wants, Hdt.: —τὸ π. durability, Luc.

div1.head: πολυάρματος
div1.sense: with many chariots, Soph.

div1.head: πολυαρμόνιος
div1.sense: many-toned, Plat.

div1.head: πολύαρνος
div1.sense: with many lambs or sheep, rich in flocks, heterocl. dat. πολύαρνι, Il.

div1.head: πολυαρχία
div1.sense: the government of many, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πολυαστράγαλος
div1.sense: with many joints, Anth.

div1.head: πολύαστρος
div1.sense: with many stars, starry, Eur.

div1.head: πολυαῦλαξ
div1.sense: with many furrows, Anth.

div1.head: πολυαύχενος
div1.sense: with many necks, Anth.

div1.head: πολυβαφής
div1.sense: much-dipped, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυβενθής
div1.sense: very deep, Hom.

div1.head: πολύβοσκος
div1.sense: much-nourishing, Pind.

div1.head: πολυβότειρα
div1.sense: much or all nourishing, Hom., Hes., in Epic form πουλυβότειρα.

div1.head: πολύβοτος
div1.sense: much-nourishing, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύβοτρυς
div1.sense: abounding in grapes, Eur.

div1.head: πολύβουλος
div1.sense: much-counselling, Hom.

div1.head: πολυβούτης
div1.sense: rich in oxen, Il.

div1.head: πολύβροχος
div1.sense: with many nooses, Eur.

div1.head: πολυγάλακτος
div1.sense: with much milk; poet. Sup. πουλυγαλακτοτάτη Anth.

div1.head: πολυγηθής
div1.sense: much-cheering, delightful, gladsome, Il., Hes.

div1.head: πολύγλευκος
div1.sense: abounding in new wine, Anth.

div1.head: πολύγλωσσος
div1.sense: many-tongued, δρῦς π. the vocal (oracular) oak of Dodona, Soph.; π. βοή an oft-repeated or loud-voiced cry, Soph.

div1.head: πολύγναμπτος
div1.sense: much-bent, much-twisting, Pind.: curling, frizzled, σέλινον Theocr.

div1.head: πολυγνώμων
div1.sense: very sagacious, Plat.

div1.head: πολύγνωτος
div1.sense: well-known, Pind.

div1.head: πολύγομφος
div1.sense: well-bolted, νῆες Hes.

div1.head: πολυγονέομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to multiply, Luc.

div1.head: πολυγονία
div1.sense: fecundity, Plat.

div1.head: πολύγονος
div1.sense: producing many at a birth, prolific, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: πολυδαίδαλος
div1.sense: much wrought, richly dight, of metal work, Hom.; of embroidery, Hes.
act. working with much art, very skilful, Il.

div1.head: πολύδακρυς
div1.sense: of or with many tears: hence,
much-wept, tearful, Il., Aesch.
of persons, much-weeping, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: πολυδάκρυτος
div1.sense: much wept or lamented, Il.
very lamentable, tearful, Od., Aesch.
act. much-weeping, Eur.

div1.head: πολυδάπανος
div1.sense: causing great expense, Hdt., Xen.
of a person, extravagant, Xen.

div1.head: πολυδειράς
div1.sense: with many ridges, Il.

div1.head: πολυδέκτης
div1.sense: the all-receiver, i. e. Hades, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολύδενδρος
div1.sense: with many trees, abounding in trees, heterocl. dat. pl. πολυδένδρεσσι Eur.

div1.head: πολυδερκής
div1.sense: much-seeing, Hes.

div1.head: πολύδεσμος
div1.sense: fastened with many bonds, Od.

div1.head: Πολυδεύκης
div1.sense: Pollux, one of the Dioscuri, son of Leda, brother of Castor, Hom.

div1.head: Πολυδεύκιον
div1.sense: Com. Dim. of Πολυδεύκης, Luc.

div1.head: πολύδικος
div1.sense: having many lawsuits, litigious, Strab.

div1.head: πολυδινής
div1.sense: much-whirling, Anth.

div1.head: πολυδίψιος
div1.sense: very thirsty, Il.

div1.head: πολύδονος
div1.sense: much-driven, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύδοξος
div1.sense: having various opinions, Anth.

div1.head: πολυδωρία
div1.sense: open-handedness, Xen.

div1.head: πολύδωρος
div1.sense: richly dowered, Hom.

div1.head: πολύεδρος
div1.sense: polyhedral, Plut.

div1.head: πολυειδής
div1.sense: of many kinds, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: πολυειδία
div1.sense: diversity of kind, Plat.

div1.head: πολυέλαιος
div1.sense: yielding much oil, Xen.

div1.head: πολυέλικτος
div1.sense: much convoluted, πολ. ἁδονά the pleasure of the mazy dance, Eur.

div1.head: πολυεπαίνετος
div1.sense: much-praised, Xen.

div1.head: πολυεπής
div1.sense: much-speaking, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυέραστος
div1.sense: much-loved, Xen.

div1.head: πολύεργος
div1.sense: much-working, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: πολυετής
div1.sense: of many years, full of years, Eur.

div1.head: πολύευκτος
div1.sense: much-wished-for, much-desired, Orac. ap. Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: πολύζηλος
div1.sense: full of jealousy and rivalry, Soph.
much-desired, longed-for, loved, Soph.

div1.head: πολυζήλωτος
div1.sense: much envied, Eur.

div1.head: πολύζυγος
div1.sense: many-benched, νηῦς Il.

div1.head: πολυηγόρος
div1.sense: much-speaking, Anth.

div1.head: πολυήκοος
div1.sense: having heard much, much-learned, Plat.

div1.head: πολυήμερος
div1.sense: of many days, Plut.

div1.head: πολυήρατος
div1.sense: much-loved, very lovely, Od.

div1.head: πολυηχής
div1.sense: many-toned, of the nightingaleʼs voice, Od.: much or loud sounding, Il.

div1.head: πολυήχητος
div1.sense: loud-sounding, Eur.

div1.head: πολυθαρσής
div1.sense: much-confident, Hom.

div1.head: πολυθεάμων
div1.sense: having seen much, c. gen., Plat.

div1.head: πολύθεος
div1.sense: of or belonging to many gods, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύθερμος
div1.sense: very warm or hot, Plut.

div1.head: πολύθηρος
div1.sense: abounding in wild beasts, Eur.

div1.head: πολυθρέμμων
div1.sense: feeding many, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυθρήνητος
div1.sense: lamentable, Anth.

div1.head: πολύθρηνος
div1.sense: much-wailing, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύθριξ
div1.sense: with much hair, Anth.

div1.head: πολύθροος
div1.sense: with much noise, clamorous, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυθρύλητος
div1.sense: much-spoken-of, well known, notorious, Plat.

div1.head: πολύθυρος
div1.sense: with many doors or openings, Luc.
with many leaves, of tablets, Eur.

div1.head: πολύθυτος
div1.sense: abounding in sacrifices, Pind., etc.

div1.head: πολυϊδρεία
div1.sense: much knowledge or wisdom, in pl., νόου πολυϊδρείῃσι Od.

div1.head: πολύϊδρις
div1.sense: of much knowledge, wisdom, shrewdness, Od., Ar.

div1.head: πολύϊππος
div1.sense: rich in horses, Il.

div1.head: πολυΐστωρ
div1.sense: very learned, Anth.

div1.head: πολύϊχθυς
div1.sense: abounding in fish, Strab.: also πολυ-ίχθυος, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολυκαγκής
div1.sense: drying or parching exceedingly, δίψαι Il.
very dry, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκαής
div1.sense: much-burning, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκαισαρίη
div1.sense: the government of many emperors at once, Plut.

div1.head: πολυκάμμορος
div1.sense: very miserable, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκαμπής
div1.sense: much bent, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκανής
div1.sense: much-slaughtering, θυσίαι π. βοτῶν slaughter of many beasts, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύκαπνος
div1.sense: with much smoke, smoky, Eur.

div1.head: πολυκάρηνος
div1.sense: many-headed, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκαρπία
div1.sense: abundance of fruit, Xen.

div1.head: πολύκαρπος
div1.sense: rich in fruit, Od., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: πολυκέρδεια
div1.sense: great craft, πολυκερδείῃσιν Od.

div1.head: πολυκερδής
div1.sense: very crafty or wily, Od.

div1.head: πολύκερως
div1.sense: many-horned, π. φόνος the slaughter of much horned cattle, Soph.

div1.head: πολύκεστος
div1.sense: well-stitched, Il.

div1.head: πολυκέφαλος
div1.sense: many-headed, Plat.

div1.head: πολυκηδής
div1.sense: full of care, grievous, Od.

div1.head: πολυκήριος
div1.sense: very deadly, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκήτης
div1.sense: full of monsters, Theocr.

div1.head: πολύκλαυστος
div1.sense: much lamented, Aesch., Eur.
act. much lamenting, Mosch.

div1.head: πολύκλειτος
div1.sense: far-famed, Pind.

div1.head: πολυκλήεις
div1.sense: far-famed, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκλήϊς
div1.sense: with many benches of rowers, in dat., νηὶ πολυκλήιδι, νηυσὶ πολυκλήισι Hom.; acc. νῆα πολυκλήιδα Hes.

div1.head: πολύκληρος
div1.sense: of a large lot, with a large portion of land, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: πολύκλητος
div1.sense: called from many a land, of the Trojan allies, Il.

div1.head: πολύκλυστος
div1.sense: much-dashing, Od. Hes.
pass. washed by many a wave, Hes.

div1.head: πολύκμητος
div1.sense: much-wrought, wrought with much toil, epith. of iron, as distinguished from copper, Il.; π. θάλαμος Od.
laborious, τέχνη Anth.

div1.head: πολύκνημος
div1.sense: with many mountain-spurs, mountainous, Il.

div1.head: πολύκοινος
div1.sense: common to many or to all, Pind., Soph.

div1.head: πολυκοιρανία
div1.sense: the rule of many, Il.

div1.head: πολυκοίρανος
div1.sense: wide-ruling, Aesch. ap. Ar.

div1.head: πολυκόλυμβος
div1.sense: oft-diving, μέλη π., of the frogs, Ar.

div1.head: πολύκρανος
div1.sense: many-headed, Eur.

div1.head: Πολυκράτειος
div1.sense: of or belonging to Polycrates, Arist.

div1.head: πολυκρατής
div1.sense: very mighty, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύκροτος
div1.sense: loud-ringing, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολύκρουνος
div1.sense: with many springs, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκτήμων
div1.sense: with many possessions, exceeding rich, Il., Soph.; c. gen., π. βίου Eur.

div1.head: πολύκτητος
div1.sense: of large possessions, wealthy, Eur.

div1.head: πολυκτόνος
div1.sense: much-slaying, murderous, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: πολυκυδής
div1.sense: much-praised, very glorious, Anth.

div1.head: πολυκύμων
div1.sense: swelling with many waves, Solon.

div1.head: πολυκώκυτος
div1.sense: much-lamenting, Theogn.

div1.head: πολύκωμος
div1.sense: much-revelling, Anth.

div1.head: πολύκωπος
div1.sense: many-oared, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: πολυλήϊος
div1.sense: with many cornfields, Il.

div1.head: πολύλλιθος
div1.sense: very stony, Anth.

div1.head: πολύλλιστος
div1.sense: sought with many prayers, πολύλλιστον δέ σʼ ἱκάνω, says Ulysses to the river which receives him from the sea (cf. τρίλλιστος) , Od.

div1.head: πολυλογία
div1.sense: much talk, loquacity, Xen.

div1.head: πολύλογος
div1.sense: much-talking, talkative, loquacious, Xen., etc.

div1.head: πολυμαθής
div1.sense: having learnt or knowing much, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: πολυμαθία
div1.sense: much-learning, Plat., etc.

div1.head: πολύμακαρ
div1.sense: most blissful or happy, Eust.

div1.head: πολυμανής
div1.sense: very furious, Anth.

div1.head: πολυμάχητος
div1.sense: much-fought-for, Luc.

div1.head: πολυμεθής
div1.sense: drinking much wine, Anth.

div1.head: πολυμελής
div1.sense: with many members, Plat.

div1.head: πολυμερής
div1.sense: consisting of many parts, manifold, of divers kinds, Arist.: adv. -μερῶς, in many portions, NTest.

div1.head: πολύμετρος
div1.sense: of many measures, hence copious, abundant, Eur. ap. Ar.
consisting of many metres, Ath

div1.head: πολυμηκάς
div1.sense: much bleating, Bacis ap. Hdt.

div1.head: πολύμηλος
div1.sense: with many sheep or goats, rich in flocks, Il., Hes., Eur.

div1.head: πολύμηνις
div1.sense: abounding in wrath, Anth.

div1.head: πολύμητις
div1.sense: of many counsels, Hom.

div1.head: πολυμηχανία
div1.sense: the having many resources, inventiveness, readiness, Od.

div1.head: πολυμήχανος
div1.sense: full of resources, inventive, ever-ready, of Ulysses, Il.

div1.head: πολυμιγής
div1.sense: much-mixed, Anth.

div1.head: πολυμισής
div1.sense: much-hating, Luc.

div1.head: πολυμνήστευτος
div1.sense: much-wooed, Plut.

div1.head: πολυμνήστη
div1.sense: much courted or wooed, wooed by many, Od.

div1.head: πολύμνηστος
div1.sense: much-remembering, mindful, Aesch.
pass. much-remembered, Aesch.

div1.head: Πολύμνια
div1.sense: contr. for Πολυ-ύμνια, Polymnia or Polyhymnia, i. e. she of the many hymns, one of the nine Muses, Hes.

div1.head: πολύμουσος
div1.sense: rich in the Musesʼ gifts, Luc.

div1.head: πολύμοχθος
div1.sense: much-labouring, suffering many things, Soph., Eur.
pass. won by much toil, Anth.: wrought with much toil, Theocr.

div1.head: πολύμυθος
div1.sense: of many words, i. e. wordy, Hom.
pass. much talked of, famous in story, Pind.

div1.head: πολύναος
div1.sense: with many temples, Theocr.

div1.head: πολυναύτης
div1.sense: with many sailors or ships, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυνεικής
div1.sense: much-wrangling, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυνεφέλας
div1.sense: overcast with clouds, Pind.

div1.head: πολυνιφής
div1.sense: deep with snow, Eur.

div1.head: πολύνοσος
div1.sense: liable to many sicknesses, Strab.

div1.head: πολύξενος
div1.sense: of persons, entertaining many guests, very hospitable, Hes.
visited by many guests, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: πολύξεστος
div1.sense: much-polished, Soph.

div1.head: πολυοινέω
div1.sense: to be rich in wine, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολύοινος
div1.sense: rich in wine, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πολύολβος
div1.sense: very wealthy, Anth.: of things, very abundant, Anth.
act. rich in blessings, Anth.

div1.head: πολυόμματος
div1.sense: many-eyed, Luc.

div1.head: πολυόρνιθος
div1.sense: abounding in birds, Eur.

div1.head: πολύοχλος
div1.sense: much-peopled, populous, Polyb.
very numerous, Arist.

div1.head: πολυοψία
div1.sense: abundance of meats or fish, Xen.

div1.head: πολύοψος
div1.sense: abounding in fish, Strab.
luxurious, Luc.

div1.head: πολυπαθής
div1.sense: subject to many passions, much perturbed, Anth.

div1.head: πολυπαίπαλος
div1.sense: exceeding crafty, Od.

div1.head: πολύπαις
div1.sense: with many children, Anth.

div1.head: πολυπάμφαος
div1.sense: very bright-shining, Anth.

div1.head: πολυπάμων
div1.sense: exceeding wealthy, Il.

div1.head: πολυπειρία
div1.sense: great experience, Thuc.

div1.head: πολυπείρων
div1.sense: with many boundaries, manifold, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολυπενθής
div1.sense: much-mourning, exceeding mournful, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: Πολυπημονίδης
div1.sense: son of Polypemon, with a play upon πολυπήμων, Od.

div1.head: πολυπήμων
div1.sense: causing manifold woe, baneful, Hhymn.; π. νόσοι diseases manifold, Pind.

div1.head: πολύπηνος
div1.sense: thick-woven, close-woven, Eur.

div1.head: πολυπῖδαξ
div1.sense: with many springs, many-fountained, of Mt. Ida, Il.

div1.head: πολύπικρος
div1.sense: very keen or bitter; πολύπικρα as adv., Od.

div1.head: πολυπινής
div1.sense: very squalid, Eur.

div1.head: πολύπλαγκτος
div1.sense: much-wandering, wide-roaming, Od., Soph., Eur.
act. leading far astray, driving far from oneʼs course, ἄνεμος Il.—In Soph. Ant. 615, π. ἐλπίς may be either wandering, uncertain hope, or, misleading, deceitful; cf. πολυπλανής II.

div1.head: πολυπλανής
div1.sense: roaming far or long, Eur.; π. κισσός the straying ivy, Anth.
much-erring, or, act., leading much astray, Anth.

div1.head: πολυπλάνητος
div1.sense: Hdt., Eur.; π. πόνοι the pains of wandering, Eur.
of blows, falling in every direction, Aesch.

div1.head: πολύπλεθρος
div1.sense: many πλέθρα in size, farstretching, Eur.
of persons, rich in land, Luc.

div1.head: πολυπλοκία
div1.sense: cunning, craft, Theogn.

div1.head: πολύπλοκος
div1.sense: much-tangled, thick-wreathed, of a serpentʼs coils, Eur.; of the polypus, with tangled, twisting arms, Theogn.
metaph. much-twisting, complex, intricate, Eur., Xen., Anth.

div1.head: πολυποίκιλος
div1.sense: much-variegated, Eur.

div1.head: πολύπονος
div1.sense: of men, much-labouring, much-suffering, Pind., Eur.
of things, full of pain and suffering, painful, toilsome, Trag. adv. -νως.

div1.head: πολυπόταμος
div1.sense: with many or large rivers, Eur.

div1.head: πολυπότης
div1.sense: a hard drinker, Anth.

div1.head: πολύπους
div1.sense: many-footed, Soph., Plat.

div1.head: πολύπους2
div1.sense: the sea-polypus or octopus, Lat. polypus (Hor.), Od., Theogn., etc.

div1.head: πολυπραγμονέω
div1.sense: to be busy about many things, in bad sense, to be a meddlesome, inquisitive busybody, Ar., Plat.: also, like νεωτερίζω, to meddle in state affairs, intrigue, Hdt., Xen.
c. acc. to be curious after, Menand.

div1.head: πολυπραγμοσύνη
div1.sense: the character and conduct of the πολυπράγμων, curiosity, officiousness, meddlesomeness, Ar., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: πολυπράγμων
div1.sense: busy after many things, over-busy, mostly in bad sense, meddlesome, officious, a busybody, Lat. curiosus, an epith. often given to the restless Athenians, Ar., etc.

div1.head: πολυπρόβατος
div1.sense: rich in sheep or cattle, πολυπροβατωτάτοις Hdt.

div1.head: πολυπρόσωπος
div1.sense: many-faced, with many masks or characters, Luc.

div1.head: πολυπτόητος
div1.sense: much scared, much-agitated, Anth.

div1.head: πολύπτυχος
div1.sense: of or with many folds, of mountains, Il., Hes., Eur.

div1.head: πολύπυργος
div1.sense: with many towers, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολύπυρος
div1.sense: rich in corn, Hom.

div1.head: πολύρραφος
div1.sense: well-stitched, Soph., Theocr.

div1.head: πολύρρηνος
div1.sense: rich in sheep, Od.:—in pl. we have a heterocl. nom., ἄνδρες πολύρρηνες Il.

div1.head: πολύρριζος
div1.sense: with many roots, Anth.

div1.head: πολύρροδος
div1.sense: abounding in roses, Ar.

div1.head: πολύρροθος
div1.sense: much-roaring, φροίμια π. the cries of many voices, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυρροίβδητος
div1.sense: much-whirring, Anth.

div1.head: πολύρρυτος
div1.sense: much or strong flowing, Soph.

div1.head: πολυσαρκία
div1.sense: fleshiness, plumpness, Xen.

div1.head: πολύσαρκος
div1.sense: very fleshy, Arist.

div1.head: πολυσέβαστος
div1.sense: the Lat. augustissimus, Anth.

div1.head: πολύσεμνος
div1.sense: exceeding venerable, Anth.

div1.head: πολυσημάντωρ
div1.sense: giving commands to many, Hhymn.

div1.head: πολυσινής
div1.sense: very hurtful, baneful, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυσιτία
div1.sense: abundance of corn or food, Xen. From.

div1.head: πολύσιτος
div1.sense: abounding in corn, Xen.
high-fed, full of meat, Theocr.

div1.head: πολύσκαλμος
div1.sense: many-oared, Anth.

div1.head: πολύσκαρθμος
div1.sense: far-bounding, Il.

div1.head: πολύσκηπτρος
div1.sense: wide-ruling, Anth.

div1.head: πολυσπαθής
div1.sense: thick-woven, Anth.

div1.head: πολύσπαστος
div1.sense: drawn by many cords:— πολύσπαστον, ου, a compound pulley, Plut.

div1.head: πολυσπερής
div1.sense: wide-spread, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: πολύσπλαγχνος
div1.sense: of great mercy, NTest.

div1.head: πολύς
div1.etym: the Ionic declension πολλός, ή, όν is retained by the Attic in all cases, except the nom. and acc. masc. and neut. Hom. uses both Ionic and Attic forms.
div1.sense: of Number, many, opp. to ὀλίγος, Hom., etc.;— with nouns of multitude, πουλὺς ὅμιλος Od.; πολλὸν πλῆθος Hdt., etc.:—also of anything often repeated, πολλὸν ἦν τοῦτο τὸ ἔπος Hdt.; πολλὸς αἰνεόμενος Hdt.; τούτῳ πολλῷ χρήσεται τῷ λόγῳ often, Dem.

of Size, Degree, Force, much, mighty, great, Il., etc.; π. ὕπνος deep sleep, Od.; π. ὑμέναιος a loud song, Il., etc.:—rarely of a single person, μέγας καὶ πολλὸς ἐγένεο Hdt.; ἢν πολλῇ ῥυῇ if she flow with full stream, metaph. from a river, Eur.; πολλῷ ῥέοντι Dem.; from the wind, πολὺς ἔπνει was blowing strong, Dem.; often with a Partic., πολλὸς ἦν λισσόμενος he was all intreaties, Lat. multus erat in precando, Hdt.; so, π. ἦν ἐν τοῖσι λόγοισι Hdt., etc.
of Value or Worth, πολέος or πολλοῦ ἄξιος Hom.; πολλοῦ and περὶ πολλοῦ ποιεῖσθαί τι, Lat. magni facere, cf. περί A.IV; ἐπὶ πολλῷ at a high price, Dem.
of Space, large, wide, wide-stretched, π. χώρη, πεδίον Il., Hes., etc.; πόντος, πέλαγος Hes., etc.;— πολλὸς ἔκειτο he lay outstretched, Il.;— π. κέλευθος a far way, Aesch., etc.
of Time, long, πολὺν χρόνον Hom., etc.; πολλοῦ χρόνου Ar.; ἐκ πολλοῦ Thuc.; ἔτι πολλῆς νυκτός, Lat. multa nocte, while still quite night, Thuc.
Special usages:
partitive c. gen., e. g. πολλοὶ Τρώων for πολλοὶ Τρῶες, Il.; πολλὸν σαρκός for πολλὴ σάρξ, Od.; in Prose, the adj. generally takes the gender of the gen., τῆς γῆς οὐ πολλήν Thuc.
joined to another adj. by καί, πολέες τε καὶ ἐσθλοί many men and good, Il.; π. καὶ πονηρά Xen.; μεγάλα καὶ π. Dem.

with the Art., of persons or things well known, Ἑλένα μία τὰς πολλὰς ψυχὰς ὀλέσασʼ those many lives, Aesch.; ὡς ὁ πολλὸς λόγος the common report, Hdt.:—esp. οἱ πολλοί the many, i. e. the greater number, Thuc.; hence, like τὸ πλῆθος, the people, the commonalty, Thuc.; εἷς τῶν πολλῶν one of the multitude, Dem.
τὺ πολύ, c. gen., τῆς στρατιῆς τὸ πολλόν Hdt.; τῶν λογάδων τὸ πολύ Thuc.; but also, ὁ στρατὸς ὁ πολλός Hdt.
τὰ πολλά the most, Od., etc.
the pl. πολλά is used with Verbs in the sense of very much, too much, πολλὰ πράσσειν πολυπραγμονεῖν, Eur., Ar.; π. ἔρξαι τινά to do one much harm, Aesch.
πολλάς with Verbs of beating, the Subst. πληγάς being omitted, v. πληγή 1.
Adverbial usages:

neut. πολύ (Ionic πολλόν) , πολλά, much, very, Hom., etc.; μάλα πολλά Hom.; πάνυ πολύ Plat.:—also of repetition, many times, ofttimes, often, much, Hom., etc.:—also with the Art., τὸ πολύ for the most part, Plat.; ὡς τὸ π. Xen.; so, τὰ πολλά, ὡς τὰ π. Thuc.
of Degree, far, very much, Hdt.; so absol. gen. πολλοῦ, very, θρασὺς εἶ πολλοῦ Ar.; πολλοῦ πολύς, πολλοῦ πολλή, πολλοῦ πολύ, much too much, Ar.
of Space, a great way, far, οὐ πολλόν Hdt., etc.
of Time, long, Hdt.
πολύ is often joined with Adjs. and Advs.,
with a comp. to increase its compar. force, πολὺ κάλλιον, μεῖζον, πολλὸν ἀμείνων, παυρότεροι much, far more beautiful, etc., Hom., etc.:—so dat. πολλῷ by far, Hdt., etc.
with a Sup., πολὺ πρῶτος, πολλὸν ἄριστος far the first, etc., Il., etc.:—also, πολλῷ πλεῖστοι Hdt.
in Attic with a Positive, ὦ πολλὰ μὲν τάλαινα, πολλὰ δʼ αὖ σοφή Aesch.
with Preps.,
διὰ πολλοῦ at a great distance, V. διά A. II. 2.
ἐκ πολλοῦ from a great distance, Thuc.; for a long time, v. ἐκ II. 1.
ἐπὶ πολύ,
over a great space, far, οὐκ ἐπὶ πολλόν Hdt.
for a long time, long, Thuc.
to a great extent, Plat.; so, ὡς ἐπὶ π. very generally, Thuc.; ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ π. for the most part, Thuc.
παρὰ πολύ, by far, v. παρά C. I. 5.
περὶ πολλοῦ, v. supr. I. 3.
for comp. πλείων, πλέων; Sup. πλεῖστος, v. sub vocc.

div1.head: πολύσπορος
div1.sense: very fruitful, Eur.

div1.head: πολυστάφυλος
div1.sense: rich in grapes, Il., Soph.

div1.head: πολύσταχυς
div1.sense: rich in ears of corn, Theocr.

div1.head: πολύστεγος
div1.sense: with many stories, Strab.

div1.head: πολυστέλεχος
div1.sense: with many stems, Anth.

div1.head: πολυστένακτος
div1.sense: causing many groans, Anth.

div1.head: πολυστεφής
div1.sense: decked with many a wreath, Aesch.; c. gen. wreathed with, δάφνης Soph.

div1.head: πολυστιχία
div1.sense: a number of lines, Anth.

div1.head: πολύστιχος
div1.sense: in many rows, Strab.

div1.head: πολύστονος
div1.sense: much-sighing, mournful, Od., Aesch.
of things, causing many sighs, mournful, Il., Trag.

div1.head: πολυστροφία
div1.sense: convolution, Anth.

div1.head: πολύστροφος
div1.sense: much-twisted, Anth.

div1.head: πολύστυλος
div1.sense: with many columns, Strab., Plut.

div1.head: πολυσύλλαβος
div1.sense: polysyllabic, Luc.

div1.head: πολυσχήμων
div1.sense: of many shapes, varied in form, Strab.

div1.head: πολύσχιστος
div1.sense: many-branching, κέλευθα Soph., Arist., Strab.

div1.head: πολύσωρος
div1.sense: rich in heaps of corn, Anth.

div1.head: πολυτάλαντος
div1.sense: worth many talents, Luc.
possessing many talents, Luc.

div1.head: πολυταρβής
div1.sense: much-frightened, Anth.

div1.head: πολυτεκνία
div1.sense: abundance of children, Arist.

div1.head: πολύτεκνος
div1.sense: with many children, prolific, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυτέλεια
div1.sense: extravagance, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: πολυτελής
div1.sense: very expensive, very costly, opp. to εὐτελής, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
of persons, spending much, lavish, extravagant, Menand., etc.: —adv. -λῶς, Xen.; Sup. -λέστατα, in the costliest manner, Hdt.

div1.head: πολυτερπής
div1.sense: much-delighting, Anth.

div1.head: πολυτέχνης
div1.sense: skilled in divers arts, Solon.

div1.head: πολυτεχνία
div1.sense: skill in many arts, Plat.

div1.head: πολύτεχνος
div1.sense: skilled in many arts, Strab.

div1.head: πολυτίμητος
div1.sense: highly honoured, most honoured, Ar., Plat.
very costly, Ar.

div1.head: πολύτιμος
div1.sense: very costly, Anth., Babr.

div1.head: πολύτιτος
div1.sense: worthy of high honour, ap. Hdt.

div1.head: πολύτλας
div1.sense: having borne much, much-enduring, epith. of Ulysses, Hom., Soph.

div1.head: πολυτλήμων
div1.sense: much-enduring, Hom., Ar.

div1.head: πολύτλητος
div1.sense: having borne much, miserable, Od.

div1.head: πολύτμητος
div1.sense: much-lacerated, παρειά Anth.

div1.head: πολυτρήρων
div1.sense: abounding in doves, Il.

div1.head: πολύτρητος
div1.sense: much-pierced, full of holes, porous, Od.; of a flute, Anth.

div1.head: πολυτρίπους
div1.sense: abounding in tripods, Anth.

div1.head: πολυτροπία
div1.sense: versatility, craft, Hdt.

div1.head: πολύτροπος
div1.sense: much-turned, i. e. much-travelled, much-wandering, Lat. multum jactatus, of Ulysses, Od.
turning many ways, of the polypus, Theogn.
metaph. shifty, versatile, wily, of Hermes, Hhymn., Plat.; τὸ π. τῆς γνώμης their versatility of mind, Thuc.
various, manifold, Thuc.:—of diseases and war, changeful, complicated, Plut.:—adv. -πως in many manners, NTest.

div1.head: πολύτροφος
div1.sense: well-fed, Plut.

div1.head: πολυύμνητος
div1.sense: much-famed in song, Pind.

div1.head: πολύυμνος
div1.sense: much sung of, famous, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: πολυφάρμακος
div1.sense: knowing many drugs or charms, Hom.

div1.head: πολύφατος
div1.sense: much-spoken-of, very famous, excellent, Pind.

div1.head: πολύφημος
div1.sense: abounding in songs and legends, Od., Pind.
many-voiced, wordy, Od.; ἐς πολύφημον ἐξενεῖκαι to bring it forth to the many-voiced, i. e. the agora (the "parliament"), Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: πολύφθορος
div1.sense: pass. utterly destroyed, Soph.

div1.head: πολυφθόρος
div1.sense: destroying many, deathful, rife with death or ruin, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: πολυφιλία
div1.sense: abundance of friends, Arist.

div1.head: πολύφιλος
div1.sense: dear to many, Pind.

div1.head: πολύφιλτρος
div1.sense: suffering from many love-charms, love-sick, Theocr.

div1.head: πολύφλοισβος
div1.sense: loud-roaring, θάλασσα Hom., etc.

div1.head: πολύφονος
div1.sense: murderous, Eur.

div1.head: πολύφορβος
div1.sense: feeding many, bountiful, Il., Hes.

div1.head: πολυφορία
div1.sense: productiveness, Xen.

div1.head: πολυφόρος
div1.sense: bearing much, Plat.
that will bear much water, of strong wine: metaph., πολυφόρῳ δαίμονι συγκεκρᾶσθαι to have a fortune that wants tempering, Ar.

div1.head: πολυφραδής
div1.sense: very eloquent or wise, Hes.

div1.head: πολυφρόντιστος
div1.sense: much-thinking, thoughtful, Anth.

div1.head: πολυφροσύνη
div1.sense: fulness of understanding, great shrewdness, Theogn., Hdt.

div1.head: πολύφρων
div1.sense: much-thinking, thoughtful, ingenious, inventive, Hom.

div1.head: πολύφωνος
div1.sense: much-talking, loquacious, Luc.

div1.head: πολύχαλκος
div1.sense: wrought of brass, all-brasen, Hom.

div1.head: πολυχανδής
div1.sense: wide-yawning, Theocr.

div1.head: πολυχειρία
div1.sense: a multitude of hands, i. e. workmen or assistants, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: πολύχειρ
div1.sense: with many hands, many handed, Soph.
with many men, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυχορδία
div1.sense: the use of many strings in the lyre, Plat.

div1.head: πολύχορδος
div1.sense: many-stringed, Theocr.: many-toned, of the flute, Plat.; also, π. ᾠδαί Eur.; π. γῆρυς the sound of many strings, Eur.

div1.head: πολυχρηματέω
div1.sense: to abound in money, Strab.

div1.head: πολυχρηματία
div1.sense: greatness of wealth, Xen.

div1.head: πολύχρηστος
div1.sense: useful for many purposes, Arist.

div1.head: πολυχρόνιος
div1.sense: long-existing, of olden time, ancient, Hhymn., Hdt., Xen.
lasting for long, Arist.:—comp. -ώτερος, Plat.; Sup. -ώτατος, Xen.

div1.head: πολύχρυσος
div1.sense: rich in gold, Hom.; of Aphrodite, Lat. aurea Venus, Hes.

div1.head: πολύχυτος
div1.sense: widely diffused, Plut.

div1.head: πολύχωρος
div1.sense: spacious, extensive, Luc.

div1.head: πολύχωστος
div1.sense: high-heaped, Aesch.

div1.head: πολυψηφία
div1.sense: number or diversity of votes, Thuc.

div1.head: πολυψήφις
div1.sense: with many pebbles, pebbly, of a river-bed, Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: πολύψηφος
div1.sense: with many votes, Luc.

div1.head: πολυώδυνος
div1.sense: very painful, Theocr.
pass. suffering great pain, Anth.

div1.head: πολυώνυμος
div1.sense: having many names, Plat.:— worshipped under many names, Hhymn., Soph.
of great name, famous, Hhymn., Hes.

div1.head: πολυωπός
div1.sense: with many meshes, δίκτυον Od., Anth.

div1.head: πολυωρέω
div1.sense: to be very careful, opp. to ὀλιγωρέω, Aeschin., Arist.

div1.head: πολυωφελής
div1.sense: very useful, useful in many ways, Arist. adv. -λῶς, Sup. -ωφελέστατα, Xen.

div1.head: πομπαῖος
div1.sense: escorting, conveying, Eur.; π. οὖρος a fair wind, Pind.
of Hermes, who escorted the souls of the dead, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: πομπεία
div1.sense: a leading in procession, Polyb.
jeering, ribaldry, such as was allowed to those who took part in the processions at the festivals of Bacchus and Demeter, Dem.

div1.head: πομπεῖον
div1.sense: any vessel employed in solemn processions, Dem.
at Athens, a storehouse for such vessels, Dem.

div1.head: πομπεύς
div1.sense: one who attends or escorts, a conductor, guide, Od.; of favourable winds, οὖροι πομπῆες νηῶν Od.
one who attends a procession, Thuc.

div1.head: πομπεύω
div1.sense: to conduct, escort, e. g. as a guide, Od.; Ἑρμοῦ τέχνην π. to use the escorting art of Hermes, Soph.
to lead a procession, π. πομπήν, Lat. pompam ducere, ap. Dem.:—Pass. to be led in triumph (at Rome), Plut.
absol. to march in a procession, Dem., Theocr.
to abuse with ribald jests (cf. πομπεία II), Dem.

div1.head: πομπή
div1.sense: conduct, escort, guidance, Hom., etc.; οὐρία π. the conduct of a fair wind, Eur.
concrete, an escort, Aesch., Eur.
a sending away, a sending home, Od.
a sending, mission, Hdt., Plat.: simply, a sending, ξύλων Thuc.
a solemn procession, Lat. pompa, ὑπὸ πομπῆς, σὺν πομπῇ in procession, Hdt.; μήλων κνισάεσσα πομπή the flesh of sheep for sacrifice carried in procession, Pind.; τὰς πομπὰς πέμπουσιν Dem.
τείνειν π. to lead a long procession, of a military expedition, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: πομπικός
div1.sense: of or for a solemn procession, π. ἵππος a horse of state, Xen.:—metaph. pompous, showy, Plut.

div1.head: πόμπιμος
div1.sense: conducting, escorting, guiding, Trag.:—c. gen., π. χώρα φίλων a land that lends escort to friends, Eur.; νόστου πόμπιμον τέλος the home-sending end of oneʼs return, i. e. oneʼs safe return, Pind.
pass. sent, conveyed, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: πομπός
div1.sense: a conductor, escort, guide, Hom., Hdt.; of Hermes (cf. πομπαῖος) , Soph.; πομποί attendants, guards, Soph.: also πομπός, a conductress, Od.
c. gen. rei, τῆσδε προστροπῆς π. conveyor, carrier of these suppliant offerings, Aesch.
a messenger, one who is sent for a person or thing, Soph.
as adj., π. ἀρχαί the conducting chiefs, Aesch.; πῦρ πομπόν the missive fire, Aesch.

div1.head: πομποστολέω
div1.sense: to lead in procession, Strab.

div1.head: πομφολυγοπάφλασμα
div1.sense: the noise made by bubbles rising, Ar.

div1.head: πομφολύζω
div1.sense: to bubble up, gush forth, Pind.

div1.head: πομφόλυξ
div1.sense: a bubble, Plat.

div1.head: πονέω
div1.sense: in early Greek only as Dep.
absol. to work hard, do work, suffer toil, Hom.; περὶ δόρπα πονέοντο were busied about their supper, Il.; so, πεπόνητο καθʼ ἵππους was busy with the horses, of a charioteer, Il.
metaph. to be in distress, to distress oneself, Il.:— to suffer, be sick, Thuc.
c. acc. to work hard at, to make or do with pains or care, Hom., Hes.
after Hom., the act. form prevails
intr. to toil, labour, Theogn., Hdt., Attic; μάτην π. to labour in vain, Soph.; c. acc., τὰ μηδὲν ὠφελοῦντα μὴ πόνει do not labour at things that profit not, Aesch.
c. acc. cogn., π. πόνον, μόχθους to go through, suffer them, Trag.; also c. acc. partis, πονεῖν τὰ σκέλη Ar.
absol. to labour, be hard-pressed, suffer, Thuc., Xen.: to be worn out, spoilt, Dem.
Pass., impers., οὐκ ἄλλως αὐτοῖς πεπόνηται πεπονήκασι, Plat.
trans.,
c. acc. pers. to afflict, distress, Pind.:—Pass. to be worn out, to suffer greatly, Soph., Thuc.
Pass., also, to be trained or educated, Arist., Theocr.
c. acc. rei, like ἐκπονεῖν, to gain by toil or labour, χρήματα Xen.: Pass. to be won or achieved by toil, Pind.

div1.head: πόνημα
div1.sense: that which is wrought out, work, Eur.: a work, book, Anth.

div1.head: πονήρευμα
div1.sense: a knavish trick, in pl., Dem.

div1.head: πονηρεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to be evil, act wickedly, play the rogue, Arist.; οἱ πεπονηρευμένοι Dem.

div1.head: πονηρία
div1.sense: a bad state or condition, badness, Plat.
in moral sense, wickedness, vice, knavery, Lat. pravitas, Plat., Xen.: in pl. knavish tricks, rogueries, Dem.
baseness, cowardice, Eur.

div1.head: πονηροδιδάσκαλος
div1.sense: teaching wickedness, Strab.

div1.head: πονηροκρατέομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be governed by the bad, Arist.

div1.head: πονηροκρατία
div1.sense: government of the bad, Arist.

div1.head: πονηρός
div1.sense: toilsome, painful, grievous, Theogn., Ar.
in bad case, in sorry plight, useless, good-for-nothing, Ar., Plat., etc.:—adv., πονηρῶς ἔχειν to be in bad case, Thuc.
in moral sense, bad, worthless, knavish, Lat. pravus, improbus, Aesch., Eur.; πονηρὸς κἀκ πονηρῶν rogue and son of rogues, Ar.; πόνῳ πονηρός laboriously wicked, Ar.:— ὁ π. the evil one, NTest.
base, cowardly, Soph.; π. χρώματα the cowardʼs hue, Xen.

div1.head: πονηρόφιλος
div1.sense: fond of bad men, Arist.

div1.head: πονητέος
div1.sense: one must toil, Plat.

div1.head: πόνος
div1.sense: work, esp. hard work, toil, Lat. labor, in Hom. mostly of war, μάχης π. the toil of battle, and π. alone = μάχη, πόνον ἔχειν, μάχεσθαι, Il.; ὁ Μηδικὸς π. battle with the Medes, Hdt.; οἱ Τρωικοὶ πόνοι Hdt.
generally, toil, labour, Il., etc.
bodily exertion, exercise, Eur., Xen.; ἐνάλιος π., i. e. fishing, Pind.
a work, task, business, ἐπεὶ π. ἄλλος ἔπειγεν Od., Soph.
implements for labour, stock in trade, Theocr.; πόνος ἐντὶ θάλασσα the sea is their workshop, Mosch.
the consequence of toil, distress, trouble, suffering, pain, Il., etc.
anything produced by work, a work, τρητὸς μελισσᾶν π., of honey, Pind.; τοὺς ἡμετέρους π. the fruits of our labour, Xen.
Πόνος a mythol. person, son of Eris, Hes.

div1.head: ποντιάς
div1.etym: poet. fem. of πόντιος, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: ποντίζω
div1.sense: to plunge in the sea, Aesch.

div1.head: Ποντικός
div1.sense: from Pontus, Pontic, Il. δένδρεον, prob., the bird-cherry, Hdt.

div1.head: πόντιος
div1.sense: of the sea, of Poseidon, Hhymn., Soph.; π. δάκη sea monsters, Aesch.; π. κύματα Aesch.; ᾅδης πόντος, i. e. death by drowning, Aesch.
by the sea, of places, Pind., Aesch.
in the sea, of islands, Pind.; of ships, Aesch., etc.
of persons, δέχεσθαι ποντίους from the sea, Eur.; ἀφιέναι πόντιον into the sea, Eur.
brought by sea or from beyond sea, of iron, Aesch.

div1.head: πόντισμα
div1.sense: that which is cast into the sea, esp. as an offering, Eur.

div1.head: ποντόθεν
div1.sense: from or out of the sea, Il.

div1.head: ποντοθήρης
div1.sense: one who fishes in the sea, Anth.

div1.head: ποντομέδων
div1.sense: lord of the sea, Pind., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: πόντονδε
div1.sense: into the sea, Od.

div1.head: Ποντοπόρεια
div1.sense: a Nereid, Sea-traverser, Hes.

div1.head: ποντοπορεύω
div1.sense: to pass over the sea, Epic inf. -έμεναι Od.; part. ποντοπορεύων sea-traversing, Od.

div1.head: ποντοπορέω
div1.sense: to pass the sea, νῆυς ποντοποροῦσα sea-sailing, Od.

div1.head: ποντοπόρος
div1.sense: passing over the sea, seafaring, of ships, Hom., Soph.

div1.head: Ποντοποσειδῶν
div1.sense: Sea-Poseidon, Ar.

div1.head: πόντος
div1.sense: the sea, esp. the open sea, Hom., etc.

of special seas, π. Ἰκάριος, Θρηίκιος Il.; ὁ Αἰγαῖος π. Hdt.; Ἰόνιος, Σαρωνικός, Σικελός, Eur.:—but most commonly π. Εὔξεινος Eur.; ὁ Εὔξεινος π. Hdt.; generally called simply ὁ Πόντος or Πόντος, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: πόπανον
div1.sense: like πέμμα, a round cake, used at sacrifices, Ar.

div1.head: πόπαξ
div1.sense: like πόποι, an exclamation, Aesch.

div1.head: πόποι
div1.sense: exclam. of surprise, anger or pain, ὦ πόποι oh strange! oh shame! Hom., Trag.

div1.head: ποποποῖ
div1.sense: cry of the hoopoe, Ar.

div1.head: ποππύζω
div1.sense: to whistle, cheep or chirp, Ar.
of an inarticulate sound, commonly used by the Greeks in case of thunder, as a sort of charm, Ar.
in bad sense, to play ill on the flute, let the breath be heard in playing, Theocr.

div1.head: ποππυσμός
div1.sense: a whistling, Xen.

div1.head: πορεία
div1.sense: a walking, mode of walking or running, gait, Plat.
a going, a journey, way, passage, Aesch., Plat.
a march, Thuc., Xen.
a crossing of water, passage, Aesch.

div1.head: πόρευμα
div1.sense: a place in which one walks, βροτῶν πορεύματα their haunts, Aesch.

div1.head: πορεύσιμος
div1.sense: that may be crossed, passable, Xen.:—of a road, possible to pass, Eur.

div1.head: πορευτέος
div1.sense: to be traversed, Soph., Xen.
πορευτέον, one must go, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: πορευτός
div1.sense: gone over, passed, passable, Polyb.; καιρὸς π. the season for travelling, Polyb.
act. going, travelling, Aesch.

div1.head: πορεύω
div1.sense: Act. to make to go, carry, convey, Pind., Soph.:—c. dupl. acc. to carry or ferry over, Νέσσος ποταμὸν βροτοὺς ἐπόρευσε Soph.; γυναῖκʼ λίμναν πορεύσας Eur.
of things, to bring, furnish, bestow, find, Eur.
Pass. and Mid. to be driven or carried, Soph.
to go, walk, march, Hdt., Attic; to go across, pass, Hdt., etc.; c. acc. loci, to enter, π. στέγας Soph., etc.; c. acc. cogn., μακρὰν ὁδὸν π. Xen.:—c. acc. loci, to go over, traverse, Soph.
to walk, i. e. live, Soph.

div1.head: πορθέω
div1.sense: collat. form of πέρθω, to destroy, ravage, waste, plunder, Hom., Hdt., Trag.
in pres. and imperf. to endeavour to destroy, to besiege a town, Hdt.:—to destroy, despoil, ruin, Aesch.:—in Pass. to be ruined, undone, Eur.

div1.head: πόρθησις
div1.sense: the sack of a town, Dem.

div1.head: πορθητής
div1.sense: a destroyer, ravager, Eur.

div1.head: πορθμεῖον
div1.sense: a place for crossing, a passage over, ferry, Hdt.
a passage-boat, ferry-boat, Hdt., Xen.
the fare of the ferry, ferrymanʼs fee, Luc.

div1.head: πόρθμευμα
div1.sense: a passage, ferry, ὠκύπορον π. ἀχέων, of the river Acheron, Aesch.

div1.head: πορθμεύς
div1.sense: Ionic ῆος, ὁ, a ferryman, Lat. portitor, Od., etc.; π. νεκύων, of Charon, Eur.
generally, a boatman, seaman, Hdt., Theocr.

div1.head: πορθμευτικός
div1.sense: engaged as a ferryman, Arist.

div1.head: πορθμεύω
div1.sense: to carry or ferry over a strait, river, Lat. trajicere, Eur.; π. τινὰς εἰς Σαλαμῖνα Aeschin.: then, generally, to carry, bring, Trag.:— Pass. to be carried or ferried over, to pass from place to place, Hdt., Eur.; c. acc. loci, to pass through, Eur.
the Act. is also used intr., like Lat. trajicere, to pass over, Anth.

div1.head: πορθμίς
div1.sense: a ship, boat, Eur.

div1.head: πορθμός
div1.sense: a ferry or a place crossed by a ferry, a strait, firth, Od.; of the straits of Salamis, Hdt.; π. Ἕλλας the Hellespont, Aesch.; ὁ εἰς Ἅιδου π. the Styx, Eur.
a crossing by a ferry, passage, Soph., Eur.; π. χθονός a passage to it, Eur.

div1.head: πορίζω
div1.sense: Properly, like πορεύω, to carry: to bring about, to furnish, provide, supply, procure, cause, Ar., Plat.; absol., θεοῦ πορίζοντος καλῶς Eur.:—often with a notion of contriving or inventing, Eur., etc.:—Mid. to furnish oneself with, to provide, procure, Lat. sibi comparare, Ar., Thuc.:— Pass. to be provided, Thuc., etc.
πορίζεταί τινι, impers., it is in oneʼs power to do, c. inf., Xen.

div1.head: πόριμος
div1.sense: able to provide, full of resources, inventive, contriving, Ar.:—c. acc., ἄπορα πόριμος making possible the impossible, Aesch.
pass. practicable, Luc.
well-provided, Thuc.

div1.head: πορισμός
div1.sense: a providing, procuring, Polyb.: — a means of getting, Plut.: means of gain, NTest.

div1.head: ποριστής
div1.sense: one who supplies or provides, Thuc.
at Athens the πορισταί were a financial board appointed to raise extraordinary supplies, Procurators, Ar.
the name used by robbers of themselves, conveyancers, Arist.

div1.head: ποριστικός
div1.sense: able to furnish, Xen.

div1.head: πόρκης
div1.sense: a ring or hoop, passed round the joint of the spearhead and shaft, Il.

div1.head: πορνεία
div1.sense: fornication, prostitution, Dem.

div1.head: πορνεῖον
div1.sense: a house of ill-fame, brothel, Ar.

div1.head: πορνεύω
div1.sense: to prostitute:—Pass., of a woman, to be or become a prostitute, Hdt., Dem., etc.
intr. in Act., = Pass., Luc.

div1.head: πόρνη
div1.sense: a harlot, prostitute, Ar.

div1.head: πορνικός
div1.sense: of or for harlots, π. τέλος the tax paid by brothel-keepers, Aeschin.

div1.head: πορνοβοσκέω
div1.sense: to keep a brothel, Ar.

div1.head: πορνοβοσκία
div1.sense: the trade of a brothel-keeper, Aeschin.

div1.head: πορνοβοσκός
div1.sense: a brothel-keeper, Aeschin., Dem.

div1.head: πορνοφίλης
div1.sense: loving harlots, Anth.

div1.head: πόρος
div1.sense: a means of passing a river, a ford, ferry, Lat. vadum, Il., Hdt., etc.; Πλούτωνος π. the Stygian ferry, Aesch.
a narrow sea, strait, firth, Lat. fretum, Hes., Aesch.; Ἰόνιος π. the Ionian sea which is the passage-way from Greece to Italy, Pind.:— ἐν πόρῳ in the passage-way (of ships), in the "fair-way" Hdt.
periphr., πόροι ἁλός the paths of the sea, i. e. the sea, Od.; ἐνάλιοι π. Aesch., etc.; so, of rivers, πόρος Ἀλφεοῦ, Σκαμάνδρου, i. e. the Alpheus, etc., Pind.
a way over a river, a bridge, Hdt.
generally a pathway, way, Aesch., Soph.; πόρος οἰωνῶν their pathway, Aesch.
a passage through the skin, οἱ πόροι the pores, Plat.

c. gen. rei, a way or means of achieving, accomplishing, οὐκ ἐδύνατο π. οὐδένα ἀνευρεῖν Hdt.; π. ὁδοῦ a means of performing the journey, Ar.; π. κακῶν a means of averting evils, Eur.:—c. inf., πόρος τις τίσασθαι Eur.
absol. a means of providing, contrivance, device, resource, Aesch., Ar.
at Athens, π. χρημάτων a way of getting or raising money, Xen., Dem.: in pl., "ways and means, " resources, revenue, Dem.
a going, journey, voyage, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: πόρπαμα
div1.sense: a garment fastened with a πόρπη, in pl., Eur.

div1.head: πόρπαξ
div1.sense: the handle of a shield, Soph., Eur., etc.; ἔχουσι πόρπακας αἱ ἀσπίδες, i. e. they are ready for use, Ar.
part of a horseʼs headgear, Eur.

div1.head: πορπάω
div1.sense: to fasten with a buckle, to buckle or pin down, Aesch.

div1.head: πόρπη
div1.sense: a buckle-pin, Eur.;—in pl. a buckle or brooch, Il., Eur.

div1.head: πορρωτέρωθεν
div1.sense: from a more distant point, Isocr.
of Time, from long, long ago, Eur., Plat., etc.

div1.head: προσωνέομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to buy besides, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: πορσύνω
div1.sense: to offer, present what one has prepared, in Hom. of the wife preparing her husbandʼs bed.
generally, to make ready, prepare, provide, Soph., Eur., etc.:—Mid. to provide for oneself, get ready, Aesch.
of evils, ἐχθροῖς π. ἐχθρά Aesch.; π. τοῖς πολεμίοις κακά Xen.:—Pass., ἐπορσύνθη κακά Aesch.
to arrange, adjust, manage, π. τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ Hdt.; τάδε Soph., etc.
to treat with care, tend, Pind., etc.

div1.head: πόρταξ
div1.sense: a calf, Il.

div1.head: πόρτις
div1.sense: a calf, young heifer, Il., Soph.:— a young cow, Theocr., Mosch.

div1.head: πορτιτρόφος
div1.sense: nourishing calves, Hhymn.

div1.head: πορφύρα
div1.sense: the purple-fish, Lat. murex, Aesch.
purple dye, purple, Hdt.
= πορφυρίς, purple raiment, Aesch.

div1.head: πορφύρεος
div1.note: πορφύρεος, η, ον, Att. οῦς, ᾶ, οῦν
div1.sense: Homeric usage
of the swoln sea, dark-gleaming, dark; so, π. νεφέλη.
of blood, Il.; π. θάνατος, of death in battle, Il.
of stuff, cloths, etc., dark, russet.
of the rainbow, prob. bright, lustrous; and of serpents glittering.— Hom. seems not to have known the πορφύρα, so that the word does not imply any definite colour.
after Hom. (from πορφύρα dark red, purple or crimson, Pind., Hdt., Trag.
purple-clad, in purple, Luc.

div1.head: πορφυρεύς
div1.sense: a fisher for purple fish, Hdt.

div1.head: πορφυρευτικός
div1.sense: of or for a purple-dyer, Eur.

div1.head: πορφυρίς
div1.sense: a purple garment or covering, Xen.
a red-coloured bird, Ar.

div1.head: πορφυρίων
div1.sense: the water-hen, Ar.

div1.head: πορφυροειδής
div1.sense: purple-like, purply, Eur.

div1.head: πορφυροπώλης
div1.sense: a dealer in purple, fem. πορφυρό-πωλις, ιδος, NTest.

div1.head: πορφυρόστρωτος
div1.sense: spread with purple cloth, Aesch.

div1.head: πορφύρω
div1.sense: properly of the sea, ὡς ὅτε πορφύρῃ πέλαγος μέγα κύματι κωφῷ as when the huge sea gleams darkly with dumb swell (i. e. with waves that do not break), Il.
metaph., πολλὰ δέ οἱ κραδίη πόρφυρε much was his heart troubled, Hom.
after Hom., when the purple-fish (πορφύρα) and its dye became known, to grow purple or red, Bion., Anth.:—so in Mid., εὔδια μέν Anth.

div1.head: πορεῖν
div1.note: Pres. not attested; aor2 ἔπορον; perfect πέπρωται.
div1.sense: to furnish, offer, present, give, Hom., Hes.; εὖχος π. to fulfil a wish, Od.; ὅρκον π. to offer to take an oath, Aesch.:—c. inf. to grant that . . , πόρε κούρηισιν ἕπεσθαι τιμάς (for ὥστε ἕπεσθαι) Il.; σοι θεοὶ πόροιεν ὡς (= οἷα) ἐγὼ θέλω Soph.
= πορεύω, to bring, εἴ τις δεῦρο Θησέα πόροι Soph.

perf. only in 3rd sg. πέπρωται, plup. πέπρωτο, it has or had been (is or was) fated, foredoomed, c. acc. pers. et inf., ἄμφω πέπρωται γαῖαν ἐρεῦσαι it is fated that both should redden earth, Il.; τί γὰρ πέπρωται Ζηνὶ πλὴν ἀεὶ κρατεῖν; Aesch.; so, πεπρωμένον ἔστι πέπρωται, Aesch., Xen.

part. as adj., πεπρωμένος, η, ον, allotted, fated to one, Il.; of persons, destined to a thing, αἴσηι Il.:—absol. destined, Pind.; πεπρ. βίος oneʼs natural life (as in Lat. mors fatalis is a natural death), Pind.; so in Trag. and Xen.: ἡ πεπρωμένη (sc. μοῖρα), an appointed lot, fate, destiny, Hdt., Trag.

div1.head: πός
div1.sense: who, Pron., traced in the interrog. forms, ποῦ,ποῖ, πῆ, πῶς, πω, πόθι, πόθεν, πότε, πότερος, πόστος,ποῖος, πόσος, to each of which there is a correspondingenclitic form, που, ποι, πη, πως, etc.;—in these forms π in Ionic Gr. is represented by κ, as κοῦ, κοῖ, etc.

div1.head: ποσάκις
div1.sense: how many times? how often? Lat. quoties? Epic Plat.

div1.head: ποσαπλάσιος
div1.sense: how many times multiplied? how many fold? Lat. quotuplex? Plat.
c. gen. what multiple of . . ? Plat.

div1.head: Ποσειδεών
div1.sense: the sixth month of the Athen. year, = latter half of December and former of January.

div1.head: Ποσειδώνιος
div1.sense: sacred to Poseidon, Eur.:—poet. Ποσειδαώνιος, and -όνιος, Soph., Anth.: Doric Ποσειδά_νιος, Pind.
Ποσειδώνιον, (sc. ἱερόν) , τό, the temple of Poseidon, Thuc.
Ποσειδώνια, τά, his festival, Strab.

div1.head: Ποσειδῶν
div1.sense: Poseidon, Lat. Neptunus, son of Cronos and Rhea, brother of Zeus, god of the sea, husband of Amphitrite, Hom., etc.

div1.head: πόσθη
div1.sense: membrum virile, Ar.

div1.head: πόσθων
div1.sense: comic word for a little boy, Ar.

div1.head: Ποσιδήϊος
div1.sense: sacred to Poseidon, Il.
Ποσιδήιον, ου, τό, Ionic for Ποσίδειον, the temple of Poseidon, Od.

div1.head: ποσίνδα
div1.sense: how many times? π. παίζειν ἀρτιάζειν, Xen.

div1.head: πόσις
div1.sense: a husband, spouse, mate, Hom., etc.; κρυπτὸς π., of a paramour, Eur.

div1.head: πόσις2
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: a drinking, drink, beverage, Hom.; συγγίνεσθαι ἐς πόσιν to meet for a carousal, Hdt.; παρὰ τὴν πόσιν, Lat. inter pocula, over their cups, Hdt.; πόσιος ἐν βάθει Theocr.
a draught, Aesch.

div1.head: ποσός
div1.sense: indef. adj. of a certain quantity or magnitude, Lat. aliquantus, Plat., etc.

div1.head: πόσος
div1.note: πόσος;, Ionic and Aeolic κόσος, η, ον
div1.sense: interrog. adj. corresponding to the relat. ὅσος and demonstr. τόσος, Lat. quantus? of what quantity? opp. to πηλίκος (which refers to bulk), often with τις added:
of Number, how many? Hdt., Attic: with sg. Nouns, how great? how much? π. τι πλῆθος; Aesch.
of Distance, how far? Xen.
of Time, how long? Soph., etc.
of Value, how much? Ar.; πόσου; for how much? at what price? Lat. quanti? Ar.; so, ἐπὶ πόσῳ; Plat.

div1.head: ποσόω
div1.sense: to reckon up, count, τὰς ψήφους Theophr.

div1.head: ποσσίκροτος
div1.sense: struck with the foot in dancing, Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: ποσταῖος
div1.sense: in how many days? Lat. quota die? Xen.

div1.head: πόστος
div1.sense: which of a number? Lat. quotus? πόστον δὴ ἔτος ἐστὶν ὅτε ξείνισσας ἐκεῖνον; how many years is it since . . ? Od.:—in indirect questions, πόστῳ μέρει with how small a part, Xen.

div1.head: ποταίνιος
div1.sense: fresh, new, Lat. recens, Pind., Aesch.
metaph. new, unexpected, unheard of, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: ποταμηδόν
div1.sense: adv. like a river, Luc.

div1.head: ποτάμιος
div1.sense: of or from a river, Aesch., Eur.; οἱ ἵπποι οἱ π., v. ἱπποπόταμος.

div1.head: ποταμόκλυστος
div1.sense: washed by a river, Strab.

div1.head: ποταμόνδε
div1.sense: to or towards a river, Hom.

div1.head: ποταμός
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: a river, stream, Hom., etc.:—proverb., ἄνω ποταμῶν χωροῦσι παγαί, of extraordinary events, Eur.:—of rivers of fire or lava, Pind.
as a person, Ποταμός, a river-god, Il.

div1.head: ποταμοφόρητος
div1.sense: carried away by a river, NTest.

div1.head: ποταμόχωστος
div1.sense: deposited by a river, Strab.

div1.head: ποτανός
div1.sense: winged, flying, furnished with wings, Pind., Eur.; ἐν ποτανοῖς among fowls, Pind.:—metaph., ποτανὸς ἐν Μοίσαισι, i. e. soaring in the arts of the Muses, Pind.; ποτανᾷ μαχανᾷ by soaring art, i. e. by poesy, Pind.

div1.head: ποτάομαι
div1.sense: to fly about, Hom.; κεραυνοὶ ποτέοντο Hes.: simply = πέτομαι, to fly, Aesch., Eur.; τὰ ποτήμενα συλλαβεῖν, of vain pursuits, Theocr.:—perf. (with pres. sense), to be upon the wing, Hom.
metaph. to hover, Aesch.
to be on the wing, be fluttered, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: ποτέος
div1.sense: ποτέον, one must drink, Plat.

div1.head: ποτε
div1.sense: enclit. Particle:
at some time or other, at some time, Hom., etc.

at any time, ever, Soph., etc.; often after relat. words, ὅστις ποτέ, ὅστις δήποτε, ὅστις δηποτοῦν, v. δήποτε; also after πω, v. πώποτε; and after negatives, when it often becomes one word with the negat., οὔποτε, μήποτε, οὐδέποτε, μηδέποτε.
in correl. clauses it stands first, with accent, ποτὲ μέν . . , ποτὲ δέ . . , at one time . . , at another . . , Lat. modo . . , modo . . , Plat.
of some unknown point of time,
the past, once, erst, Il., Trag.; in telling a story, once upon a time, Ar.
the future, at some time, Il., etc.:—with imperat., Lat. tandem aliquando, Soph.
in questions, τίς ποτε; Lat. qui tandem? who in the world? Aesch., etc.; v. τίποτε; τίπτε.

div1.head: πότε
div1.sense: interrog. Particle used in direct and indirect questions, corresponding to the relat. ὅτε, ὁπότε and demonstr. τότε, when? at what time? Hom.; πότʼ, εἰ μὴ νῦν Aesch.; also, ἐς πότε λήξει; Soph.

div1.head: πότερος
div1.sense: whether of the two? Lat. uter? both in direct and indirect questions, ὁπότερος being the relat. form., Il., Hdt., Attic

neut. πότερον, πότερα, as adv. at the beginning of an interrog. sentence containing two alternative propositions, πότερον . . , ἤ . . , Lat. utrum . . , an . . , whether . . or . . , τίνες κατῆρξαν, πότερον Ἕλληνες ἢ παῖς ἐμός; Aesch.; πότερʼ ἄκων ἢ ἑκών; Dem.
sometimes a third clause (with ἤ) is inaccurately added, πότερα παρὰ δήμου ἢ ὀλιγαρχίης ἢ μουνάρχου; Hdt.
the second alternative is sometimes left to be supplied, πότερα δὴ κερτομῶν λέγεις τάδε ἢ μή . .; Soph.
without interrog., like ἅτερος, either of the two, Lat. alteruter, Plat.

div1.head: ποτέρωθι
div1.sense: on whether of the two sides? on which side (of two)? Xen., etc.

div1.head: ποτέρως
div1.sense: in which of two ways? Lat. utro modo? Xen., etc.
in indirect questions, διορίσαι π. λέγεις to define which you mean, Plat.

div1.head: πότημα
div1.sense: a flight, Aesch.

div1.head: ποτή
div1.sense: flight, Od.

div1.head: ποτήριον
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: a drinking-cup, wine-cup, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: ποτήρ
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: a drinking-cup, wine-cup, Eur.

div1.head: πότης
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: a drinker, tippler, toper:—metaph., πότης λύχνος a tippling lamp, i. e. that consumes much oil, Ar.: Comic Sup., ποτίστατος, Ar.

div1.head: ποτής
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: a drinking, drink, Hom.

div1.head: ποτητός
div1.sense: flying, winged: ποτητά, τά, fowls, birds, Od.

div0.note: Ποτῑδᾶς, Ποτῑδάν, Ποτῑδάων, Doric for Ποσειδῶν, q.v.

div1.head: Ποτιδαία
div1.sense: Doric city named after Poseidon (Doric Ποτῑδάν), Ar., etc.

div1.head: Ποτιδαιάτης
div1.sense: a Potidaean, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Ποτιδαιατικός
div1.sense: Potidaen, Thuc.

div1.head: ποτιδόρπιος
div1.etym: Doric form used by Hom., the common form προσδόρπιος not in use
div1.sense: of or serving for supper, ὄβριμον ἄχθος ὕλης ἵνα οἱ ποτιδόρπιον εἴη that it might serve to dress his supper, Od.

div1.head: ποτίζω
div1.sense: to give to drink, c. dupl. acc., τοὺς ἵππους νέκταρ ἐπότισε gave them nectar to drink, Plat.; ποτήριον π. τινά NTest.
to water the ground, Xen.; to water cattle, Theocr.

div1.head: ποτικός
div1.sense: fond of drinking, Plut.: adv., ποτικῶς ἔχειν to be given to drinking, Plut.

div1.head: ποτίκρανον
div1.sense: a cushion, Theocr.

div1.head: πότιμος
div1.sense: of water, drinkable, fresh, Hdt., Xen., etc.
metaph. fresh, sweet, pleasant, Plat.:—of persons, mild, gentle, Theocr.

div1.head: ποτιπτήσσω
div1.etym: Doric for προσπτήσσω, which is not in use
div1.sense: to crouch or cower towards, c. gen., ἀκταὶ λιμένος ποτιπεπτηυῖαι (Epic perf. part. fem. for προσπεπτηκυῖαι) verging towards it, so as to shut it in, Od.

div1.head: πότμος
div1.sense: that which befals one, oneʼs lot, destiny: commonly of evil destiny, death, of the killer, πότμον ἐφεῖναι, or of the killed, πότμον ἐπισπεῖν, Hom.;—also in Pind. and Trag.
without a sense of evil, π. συγγενής oneʼs natural gifts, Pind.; εὐτυχεῖ πότμῳ Aesch.; π. ξυνήθης πατρός my fatherʼs customary fortune, Soph.

div1.head: πότνα
div1.sense: πότνα θεά Od.; πότνα θεάων Hhymn.; πότνα θεῶν Eur.

div1.head: Ποτνιαί
div1.sense: an ancient Boeot. town, Strab.

div1.head: ποτνιάομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to cry or lament aloud, shriek, howl, Plut., Luc.

div1.head: πότνια
div1.etym: from same Root as πόσις, δεσπότης
div1.sense: a poet. title of honour, used chiefly in addressing goddesses or ladies:

= δέσποινα, mistress, queen, c. gen., πότνια θηρῶν (nom.) queen of wild beasts, Lat. potens ferarum, Il.; πότνια βελεων Pind.: absol., πότνιʼ Ἐρινύς Aesch.; often in voc., ὦ πότνιʼ Ἥρα Aesch.; ὦ πότνια (sc. Ἀθηναία) Ar.:—in pl. of the Eumenides, Hdt., Soph.; also of Demeter and Proserpine, Soph., etc.
as adj. revered, august, Hom.

div1.head: ποτνιασμός
div1.sense: lamentation, Strab.

div1.head: Ποτνιάς
div1.sense: Potnian, Ποτνιάδες ἵπποι Boeotian mares, noted for their hot temper, hence raging, furious, Eur.

div1.head: ποτός
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω
div1.sense: drunk, fit for drinking, Aesch., Eur.
as Subst., ποτόν, οῦ, τό, that which one drinks, drink, esp. of wine, Hom., Hdt., Attic; σῖτα καὶ ποτά meat and drink, Hdt.
πάτριον π. drink of my sires, Aesch.; π. κρηναῖον Soph.

div1.head: πότος
div1.etym: !πο, Root of some tenses of πίνω.
div1.sense: drinking, a drinking-bout, carousal, Xen.; παρὰ πότον, Lat. inter pocula, Xen.; ἐν τοῖς πότοις Aeschin.

div1.head: που
div1.sense: anywhere, somewhere, Hom., etc.; often with other Advs. of Place, οὐχ ἑκάς που somewhere not far off, Soph.; πέλας που Soph.; ἄλλοθί που Dem.:—c. gen., ἀλλά που αὐτοῦ ἀγρῶν in some part there of the fields, Od.; εἴ που τῆς χώρας τοῦτο συνέβη Dem.

also without reference to Place, in some degree, καί πού τι Thuc.:—often to qualify an expression, anyway, possibly, perhaps, I suppose, I ween, Hom., etc.; εἴ που, ἐάν που, εἰ μή που Xen.; τί που . . ; what in the world? Aesch.;with numerals, δέκα κου about ten, Hdt.:— οὔ τί που denies with indignation or wonder, surely it cannot be, Soph., etc.; whereas οὐ δήπου adds a suspicion that it is so, οὐ δήπου Στράτων; Ar.

div1.head: ποῦ
div1.etym: properly a gen. of Πός quis
div1.sense: interrog. adv., in direct or indirect questions, corresponding to the relat. ὅπου, where? Lat. ubi? Hom., etc.:—c. gen. loci, ποῦ γῆς; ποῦ χθονός; where in theworld? Lat. ubinam terrarum? Aesch., etc.; so, ποῦ ποτʼ εἶ φρενῶν; Soph.; ποῦ γνώμης εἶ; Soph..; ποῦ τύχης; at what point of fortune? Soph.

of manner, how? Eur.; to express an inference very strongly, κοῦ γε δὴ . . οὐκ ἂν χωσθείη κόλπος . . ; how then would it not . . ? i. e. it certainly would . . , Hdt.; also in Trag., in indignant questions, how? by what right? ποῦ σὺ μάντις εἰ σοφός; Soph.

div1.head: πούς
div1.sense: a foot, Lat. pes, pedis, Hom., etc.; in pl., also, a birdʼs talons, Od.; the arms of a polypus, Hes.; ξύλινος π., of an artificial foot, Hdt.: phrases in respect to the footrace, περιγιγνόμεθʼ ἄλλων πόδεσσιν, to be better than others in running, Od.; ποσὶν ἐρίζειν to race on foot, Il.; ποσὶ νικᾶν, ἀέθλια ποσσὶν ἄροντο Hom.:—the dat. ποσί is added to all kinds of Verbs denoting motion, ποσὶ βῆναι, δραμεῖν, ὀρχεῖσθαι, etc.; for πόδα βαίνειν, v. βαίνω A. II. 3:—metaph., νόστιμον ναῦς ἐκίνησεν πόδα started on its homeward way, Eur.

as a mark of close proximity, πρόσθεν ποδός or ποδῶν, προπάροιθε ποδῶν just before one, Hom.; πὰρ ποδί close at hand, Pind.; but, παρά or πὰρ ποδός off-hand, at once, Theogn.:—so, παρὰ πόδα in a moment, Soph.; παρὰ πόδας Plut.:— ἐν ποσί, like ἐμποδών, close at hand, Hdt., Attic; τὰ πρὸς ποσί Soph.:—these phrases are opp. to ἐκ ποδῶν, out of the way, far off, Hdt. (cf. ἐκποδών) .
to denote close pursuit, κατὰ πόδας on the track, Lat. e vestigio, Hdt., Attic; c. gen. pers., κατὰ πόδας τινος ἔρχεσθαι, ἰέναι to come close at his heels, Hdt.
various phrases: ἐπὶ πόδα backwards, facing the enemy, ἐπὶ π. ἀναχωρεῖν, ἀνάγειν, ἀναχάζεσθαι to retire leisurely, Lat. pedetentim, Xen.
περὶ πόδα, properly of a shoe, round the foot, i. e. fitting exactly, Theophr., Luc.
ὡς ποδῶν ἔχει as he is off for feet, i. e. as quick as he can, Hdt.
ἔξω τινὸς πόδα ἔχειν to have oneʼs foot out of a thing, i. e. be clear of it, ἔξω κομίζου πηλοῦ πόδα Aesch.; πημάτων ἔξω πόδα ἔχειν Aesch.:—opp. to εἰς ἄντλον ἐμβῆσαι πόδα, Eur.
to denote energetic action, ἀμφοῖν ποδοῖν, Ar.; βοηθεῖν ποδὶ καὶ χειρὶ καὶ πάσῃ δυνάμει Aeschin.; for ὀρθῷ ποδί, v. ὀρθός II.
πούς τινος, periphr. for a person, σὺν πατρὸς μολὼν ποδί, i. e. σὺν πατρί, Eur.; παρθένου δέχου πόδα Eur.:—also, ἐξ ἑνὸς ποδός, i. e. μόνος ὤν, Soph.; οἱ ἀφʼ ἡσύχου π., i. e. οἱ ἡσύχως ζῶντες, Eur.
metaph. of things, the foot or lowest part, esp. the foot of a hill, Lat. pes montis, Il., etc.

in a ship, πόδες are the lower corners of the sail or the ropes fastened thereto, the sheets, Od.; χαλᾶν πόδα to slack away or ease off the sheet, Eur.; τοῦ ποδὸς παριέναι to let go hold of it, Ar.; ἐκπετάσαι πόδα (with reference to the sail), Eur.: —opp. to τείνειν πόδα, to haul it tight, Soph.; ναῦς ἐνταθεῖσα ποδί a ship with her sheet close hauled, Eur.
a foot, as a measure of length, 4 palms (παλασταί) or 6 fingers, about 1/8 of an inch longer than our foot, Hdt., etc.
a foot in Prosody, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ποώδης
div1.sense: like grass, grassy, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: πρᾶγμα
div1.sense: that which has been done, a deed, act, Lat. facinus, Hdt., Attic; τῶν πραγμάτων πλέον more than facts, Eur.; τὸ σὸν τί ἐστι τὸ πρ.; what is your work in life? Plat.; γύναιον πρ. ποιεῖν to do a womanʼs work, Dem.
like Lat. res, a thing, matter, affair, Hdt., Attic; σφισί τε καὶ Ἀθηναίοις εἶναι οὐδὲν πρ. they had no thing in common, Hdt.
anything necessary or expedient, πρῆγμά ἐστι, c. inf., it is necessary, expedient to do, ʼtis my duty or business to do, like Lat. opus est, Hdt.

a thing of consequence or importance, πρ. ποιεῖσθαί τι Hdt.; of a person, ἦν μέγιστον πρ. Δημοκήδης παρὰ βασιλέϊ he was made much of by the king, Hdt.; ἄμαχον πρ., of a woman, Xen.; ἀσταθμητότατον πρ. ὁ δῆμος Dem.
used of a battle, as we say an action, affair, Xen.
euphem. for something bad or disgraceful, the thing, the business, Thuc.; Εὐρυβάτου πρᾶγμα, οὐ πόλεως ἔργον his job, Dem.
in pl., πράγματα,

circumstances, affairs, Hdt., Attic; τοῖς πράγμασιν τέθνηκα τοῖς δʼ ἔργοισι δʼ οὔ by circumstances, not by acts, Eur.; ἀπηλλάχθαι πραγμάτων to be quit of the business of life, Plat.; ἀποτυγχάνειν τῶν πρ. to fail in success, Xen.

state-affairs, Eur., etc.; τὰ πολιτικὰ πρ. Plat.:—also, τὰ Περσικὰ πρ. the Persian power, Hdt.; ἐν ταῖς ναυσὶ τῶν Ἑλλήνων τὰ πρ. ἐγένετο Thuc.; καταλαμβάνειν τὰ πρ. to seize the government, Lat. rerum potiri, Thuc.; ἔχειν, κατέχειν τὰ πρ. Thuc.; οἱ ἐν τοῖς πράγμασι, like οἱ ἐν τέλει, those who are in power or office, the ministers, Thuc.; οἱ ἐπὶ τοῖς πρ. ὄντες, οἱ ἐπὶ τῶν πρ., Dem.:— νεώτερα πρ. innovations, Lat. res novae, Oratt.
oneʼs private affairs or circumstances, Hdt., Attic

in bad sense, troublesome business, trouble, annoyance, Ar.; πράγματα ἔχειν, c. part., to have trouble about a thing, Hdt.; πρ. παρέχειν τινί to cause one trouble, Hdt.; c. inf., to cause one the trouble of doing, Plat.

div1.head: πραγματεία
div1.sense: the careful prosecution of an affair, diligent study, hard work, Plat., Dem., etc.
occupation, business, Plat., Aeschin.:—in pl. affairs in general, dealings, Plat., etc.
the treatment of a subject, Plat.; a treatise, Arist.; an historical work, systematic history, Polyb., Luc.

div1.head: πραγματεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to busy or exert oneself, take trouble, Hdt., Xen., Plat.
to be engaged in business, spend oneʼs time in business, Xen., etc.
c. acc. rei, to take in hand, treat laboriously, undertake, Plat.:—of authors, to elaborate a work, Ar., Plat.
of historians, to treat systematically, Polyb.; οἱ πραγματευόμενοι systematic historians, Polyb.
perf. πεπραγμάτευμαι also in pass. sense, to be laboured at, worked out, Plat., Aeschin.

div1.head: πραγματευτέος
div1.sense: to be laboured at, Arist.

div1.head: πραγματικός
div1.sense: fit for business, active, business-like; οἱ πραγματικοί men of action, Polyb.
in Roman writers, pragmaticus was a kind of attorney, Cic.
of history, systematic, Polyb.: of a speech, conduct, etc., able, prudent, Polyb.:—adv. -κῶς, Polyb.

div1.head: πραγμάτιον
div1.sense: a trifling matter, petty lawsuit, Ar.

div1.head: πραγματοδίφης
div1.sense: one who hunts after lawsuits, a pettifogger, Ar.

div1.head: πραγματώδης
div1.sense: laborious, troublesome: adv. -δως, comp. -έστερον Dem.

div1.head: πρᾶγος
div1.sense: poetic for πρᾶγμα, Pind., Aesch., Soph., Ar.
= πράγματα, state-affairs, Aesch.

div1.head: πραιτώριον
div1.sense: = Lat. Praetorium, the residence of the Governor, Government-house, NTest.:—at Rome, the Castra Praetoriana, NTest.

div1.head: πρακτέος
div1.sense: to be done, Plat., etc.
πρακτέον, one must do, Soph., Plat.

div1.head: πρακτήρ
div1.sense: one that does, a doer, Il.
a trader, Lat. negotiator, Od.

div1.head: πρακτικός
div1.sense: fit for action, fit for business, business-like, practical, Xen., Plat.; αἱ πρ. ἀρχαί the principles of action, Arist.
active, effective, Polyb.; πρ. παρά τινος carrying oneʼs point with another, Xen.
c. gen. able to effect a thing, etc., Arist.
of things, active, vigorous, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: πρακτός
div1.sense: τὰ πρακτά things to be done, points of moral action, Arist.

div1.head: πράκτωρ
div1.sense: one who does or executes, an accomplisher, Soph.; with a fem. Subst., Soph.
one who exacts payment, a tax-gatherer, Dem., etc.
in Poets also, one who exacts punishment, a punisher, avenger, Aesch., Soph.:—so as adj., with a fem. Subst., avenging, Aesch.

div1.head: Πράμνειος
div1.sense: πράμνειος οἶνος, ὁ, Pramnian wine, Hom.; also Πράμνιος, Ar.:—so named from Pramne, prob. a hill in the island of Icaria.

div1.head: πράν
div1.sense: aforetime, erst, Theocr.

div1.head: πραξικοπέω
div1.sense: to take by surprise or treachery, Polyb.:— to overreach, outwit, τινά Polyb.

div1.head: πρᾶξις
div1.sense: a doing, transaction, business, πλεῖν κατὰ πρῆξιν on a trading voyage, Od.; πρῆξις δʼ ἥδʼ ἰδίη, οὐ δήμιος a private, not a public affair, Od.
the result or issue of a business, οὐ γάρ τις πρ. πέλεται γόοιο no good comes of weeping, Il.; so, ὄυ τις πρ. ἐγίγνετο μυρομένοισιν Od.; πρ. οὐρίαν θέλων Aesch.; χρησμῶν πρ. their issue, Aesch.
an acting, transacting, doing, κακότητος Theogn.; πρ. πολεμική, ποιητική, πολιτική Plat.:— action, opp. to πάθος, Plat.; ἐν ταῖς πράξεσι in actual life, Plat.
action, exercise, χειρῶν, σκελῶν Plat.
an action, act, Soph., etc.
like τὸ εὖ or κακῶς πράσσειν, a doing well or ill, faring so and so, oneʼs fortune, state, condition, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
practical ability, dexterity, Polyb.:— also, practice, trickery, Polyb.
the exaction of money, recovery of outstanding debts or arrears, πρ. συμβολαίων Plat., Dem.:—hence, the exaction of vengeance, retribution, Eur.
in pl. public or political life, Dem.

div1.head: πραόνως
div1.sense: temperately, Ar.

div1.head: πρᾶος
div1.etym: the declension varies between the two forms πρᾶος and πρᾱύς—the Attic sg. is from πρᾶος, except that the fem. is πραεῖα: poet. sg. from πραΰς
div1.sense: Mild, soft, gentle, meek, Hhymn., Pind., Plat.:—of a horse, gentle, Xen.; of other animals, tame, Xen.
of actions, feelings, mild, Plat.
making mild, taming, Pind.

adv. πράως, ( from πρᾶος) mildly, gently, Plat.; πράως ἔχειν πρός τι Plat.; πράως λέγειν τὸ πάθος to speak lightly of it, Xen.; πράως διακεῖσθαι, opp. to ὀργίζεσθαι, Dem.;—comp., Plat.;—Sup., πραότατα Plat.

div1.head: πραότης
div1.sense: mildness, gentleness, Plat., etc.

div1.head: πραπίδες
div1.sense: poet. word,
properly = φρένες, the midriff, diaphragm, Il.: then
like φρένες, the wits, understanding, mind, heart, Il.:—sg. πραπίς, ίδος, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: πρασιά
div1.sense: properly a bed of leeks: generally, a garden-plot, Od.:—metaph., πρασιαὶ πρασιαί in companies or groups, NTest.

div1.head: πράσιμος
div1.sense: for sale, Lat. venalis, Xen.

div1.head: πρᾶσις
div1.sense: a selling, sale, ὠνῇ τε καὶ πρήσι (Ionic dat.) χρέονται Hdt.; ἐπὶ πρήσι for sale, Hdt.; πρᾶσιν ποιεῖσθαι Aeschin.

div1.head: πρασόκουρον
div1.sense: a leek-slice, Anth.

div1.head: πράσον
div1.sense: a leek, Lat. porrum, Ar.

div1.head: Πρασσαῖος
div1.sense: leek-green, name of a frog, Batr.

div1.head: Πρασσοφάγος
div1.sense: leek-eater, name of a frog, Batr.

div1.head: πράσσω
div1.sense: to pass over, ἅλα πρήσσοντες Od.; πρ. κέλευθον to accomplish a journey, Hom.; also c. gen., ἵνα πρήσσωμεν ὁδοῖο Il.

to achieve, bring about, effect, accomplish, Il.; οὔτι πρ. to avail naught, Il.; πρ. δεσμόν to cause oneʼs bondage, bring it on oneself, Pind.; πρ. ὥστε, Lat. efficere ut, Aesch.: —Pass., πέπρακται τοὖργον Aesch.; τὰ πεπραγμένα, Lat. acta, Pind., Attic
absol. to effect an object, be successful, Hom.
to make so and so (cf. ποιέω III), Νηρηίδων τινὰ πρ. ἄκοιτιν Pind.
to have to do, be busy with, τὰ ἑαυτοῦ πράττειν to mind oneʼs own business, Soph., etc.
πράττειν τὰ πολιτικά, τὰ τῆς πόλεως to manage state-affairs, take part in the government, Plat.:—then, absol., without any addition, ἱκανὸς πράττειν, of a statesman, Xen.

generally, to transact, negotiate, manage, πρ. Θηβαίοις τὰ πράγματα to manage matters for their interest, Dem.; and in Pass., τῶι Ἱπποκράτει τὰ πράγματα ἐπράττετο matters were negotiated with him, Thuc.;—but τὰ πράγματα may be omitted, οἱ πράσσοντες αὐτῶι those who were treating with him, Dem.; so, πράσσειν πρός τινα Dem.; ἔς τινα Dem.; also, πρ. περὶ εἰρήνης Xen.; οἱ πράσσοντες the traitors, Thuc.; also, πρ. ὅπως πόλεμος γένηται Thuc.; c. acc. et inf., τὴν ναῦν μὴ δεῦρο πλεῖν ἔπραττεν Dem.:—Pass., of secret practices, εἰ μή τι σὺν ἀργύρωι ἐπράσσετο unless some bribery was a-practising, Soph.; ἐπράσσετο προδόσιος πέρι Thuc.
to practise, Lat. agere, ἀρετάς Pind.; δίκαια ἢ ἄδικα Plat.: absol. to act, Plat., etc.

intr. to be in a certain state or condition, to do or fare so and so, ὁ στόλος οὕτω ἔπρηξε Hdt., etc.; εὖ or κακῶς πράττειν to do or fare well or ill, Hdt., etc.; πρ. καλῶς Aesch.; εὐτυχῶς Soph.; πρ. ὡς ἄριστα καὶ κάλλιστα Thuc.; the perf. 2 πέπρᾱγα is mostly used in this sense, Hdt., Ar., etc.
c. dupl. acc. pers. et rei, πράττειν τινά τι to do something to one, Eur., etc.

πράττειν τινὰ ἀργύριον to exact money from one, Hdt.: often in Attic, of state officers, who collected the taxes (cf. εἰσπράσσω, ἐκπράσσω III), Plat., etc.; also, πρ. τι παρά τινος to obtain or demand from another, Hdt.:—metaph., φόνον πρ. to exact punishment for murder, to avenge, punish, Aesch.:—Pass., πεπραγμένος τὸν φόρον called on to pay up the tribute, Thuc.:—Mid., πράξασθαί τινα ἀργύριον, χρήματα, μισθόν, τόκους to exact for oneself, Hdt., etc.; φόρους πράσσεσθαι ἀπό or ἐκ τῶν πόλεων Thuc.:—perf. and plup. pass. are used in mid. sense, εἰ μὲν ἐπεπράγμην τοῦτον τὴν δίκην if I had exacted from him the full amount, Dem.

div1.head: πρατέος
div1.sense: to be sold, for sale, Lat. venalis, Plat.

div1.head: πρατήριον
div1.sense: a place for selling, a market, Hdt.

div1.head: πρατήρ
div1.sense: a dealer, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: πρᾶτος
div1.etym: Doric for πρῶτος (contr. from πρόατος) Ar., Theocr.

div1.head: πρατός
div1.sense: sold, Soph.

div1.head: πραΰγελως
div1.sense: softly-smiling, Anth.

div1.head: πραΰμητις
div1.sense: of gentle counsel, gracious, Pind.

div1.head: πραΰνοος
div1.sense: of gentle mind, Anth.

div1.head: πράϋνσις
div1.sense: a softening, appeasing, Arist.

div1.head: πραϋντικός
div1.sense: fit for appeasing, Arist.

div1.head: πραΰνω
div1.sense: to make soft, mild or gentle, to soften, soothe, calm, Hes., etc.; πρ. ἕλκος to soothe a raging sore, Soph.; πρ. τινὰ λόγοις Aesch.:—Pass. to become soft or gentle, grow milder, Hdt.; of passion, to abate, Hdt.
to tame wild animals, Hes., Xen.

div1.head: πραϋτένων
div1.sense: with tamed neck, Anth.

div1.head: πρέμνοθεν
div1.sense: from the stump, i. e. root and branch, utterly, Aesch.

div1.head: πρέμνον
div1.sense: the bottom of the trunk of a tree, the stump: generally, the stem, trunk, Lat. codex, caudex, Hhymn., Xen., etc.
the root or bottom of anything, πρέμνον πράγματος Ar.

div1.head: πρεπόντως
div1.sense: in fit manner, meetly, beseemingly, gracefully, Pind., Aesch.
c. dat. in a manner befitting, suitably to, Plat.; also c. gen., like ἀξίως, Plat.

div1.head: πρεπτός
div1.sense: distinguished, renowned, Aesch.

div1.head: πρεπώδης
div1.sense: fit, becoming, suitable, proper, Ar.; c. dat., Xen., etc.

div1.head: πρέπω
div1.sense: of impressions on the senses,

on the eye, to be clearly seen, to be conspicuous, ὁ δʼ ἔπρεπε καὶ διὰ πάντων Il.; c. dat. rei, to be distinguished in or by a thing, Aesch., Eur.:—absol. to shine forth, shew itself, appear, Pind., Aesch.; with a part., to be clearly seen as doing or being, Aesch.
on the ear, βοὰ πρέπει the cry sounds loud and clear, Pind., Aesch.
on the smell, to be strong or rank, Aesch.
to be conspicuously like, to be like, to resemble, c. dat., Pind., Eur.
c. inf., δράμημα φωτὸς Περσικὸν πρέπει μαθεῖν his running is like Persian to behold, i. e. one may see it is Persian, Aesch.; so, πρέπει ὡς τύραννος εἰσορᾶν Soph.
to be conspicuously fit, to become, beseem, suit, c. dat. pers., θνατὰ θνατοῖσι πρέπει Pind., etc.

often in part., πρέπον ἐστί or ἦν for πρέπει or ἔπρεπε, Thuc., etc.; rarely c. gen., πρ. ἦν δαίμονος τοὐμοῦ τόδε Soph.:—part. neut. τὸ πρέπον, οντος, that which is seemly, fitness, propriety, Lat. decorum, Plat.
rarely with a person as the subject, πρέπων ἔφυς φωνεῖν art the fit person to speak, Soph.

impers. πρέπει, Lat. decet, it is fitting, it beseems, suits, becomes, c. dat. pers. et inf., οὐ πρέπει ἄμμιν λύειν τείχη Theogn.; ὡς πρέπει δούλοις λέγειν Eur.:—also c. acc. pers. et inf., τὸν πρέπει τυγχανέμεν ὕμνων Pind., etc.:—c. inf. only, πρέπει γαρυέμεν Pind.:—when an acc. alone follows, an inf. must be supplied, τίσασθαι ὡς ἐκείνους πρέπει (sc. τίσασθαι) Hdt.

div1.head: πρέσβα
div1.sense: Epic fem. of πρέσβυς, the august, honoured, mostly of Hera, Ἥρη, πρέσβα θεά Il.

div1.head: πρεσβεία
div1.sense: age, seniority, κατὰ πρεσβείαν Aesch.
rank, dignity, Plat.
an embassy, embassage, Thuc., Plat.
the body of ambassadors, as we say, the Embassy, Ar., Thuc.:— the ambassadors, of early times were elders.

div1.head: πρεσβεῖον
div1.sense: a gift of honour, such as was offered to elders, Il.
the privilege of age, and generally, a privilege, Plat., etc.
the right of the eldest, his share of the inheritance, Dem.

div1.head: πρέσβειρα
div1.etym: fem. of πρέσβυς, πρέσβα, Hhymn., Eur.

div1.head: πρέσβευμα
div1.sense: an ambassador, embassy, in pl., Eur.

div1.head: πρέσβευσις
div1.sense: #an embassage, Thuc.

div1.head: πρεσβευτής
div1.sense: an ambassador, Thuc., Plat., etc.
an agent or commissioner, Dem.

div1.head: πρεσβεύω
div1.sense: properly of age,
intr. to be the elder or eldest, Soph.; τῶν προτέρων ἐπρέσβευε he was the eldest of the former children, Hdt.; πρ. ἀπʼ αὐτοῦ to be his eldest son, Thuc.
to take the first place, be best, Soph.:—c. gen. to rank before, take precedence of others, πρ. τῶν πολλῶν Plat.; to rule over, Ὀλύμπου πρ. Soph.

trans. to place as eldest or first, to put first in rank, to pay honour or worship to, Aesch., Soph.:—Pass. to be put in the first rank, hold the first place, Lat. antiquior sum, Aesch.; c. gen., πρεσβεύεται κακῶν is most notable of mischiefs, Aesch.
to be an ambassador or go as one, serve or negociate as one, Hdt., Eur., etc.; v. πρεσβεία fin.
c. acc. objecti, πρ. τὴν εἰρήνην to negotiate peace, Dem.; so, πρ. ὑπὲρ τουτωνί Dem.
Mid. to send ambassadors, Thuc.:—also to go as ambassador, Thuc.
Pass., τὰ ἑαυτῶι πεπρεσβευμένα his negotiations, Dem.

div1.head: πρεσβηΐς
div1.sense: πρεσβηὶς τιμή the highest or most ancient honour, Hhymn.

div1.head: πρέσβις
div1.sense: age, κατὰ πρέσβιν according to age, Hhymn., Plat.

div1.head: πρέσβιστος
div1.sense: eldest, most august, most honoured, Hhymn., Aesch.

div1.head: πρέσβος
div1.sense: an object of reverence, Aesch.; πρ. Ἀργείων august assembly of Argives, Aesch.

div1.head: πρεσβυγένεια
div1.sense: seniority of birth, Hdt.

div1.head: πρεσβυγενής
div1.sense: eldest-born, first-born, Il., Eur.
οἱ πρεσβυγενεῖς the senators, Plut.

div1.head: πρέσβυς
div1.sense: an old man, Lat. senex, (the prose form is πρεσβύτης) , Soph., Eur.:— ὁ πρέσβυς is used much like ὁ πρεσβύτερος, the elder, Aesch.:—pl. πρέσβεις, elders, always implying dignity, chiefs, princes, Aesch.; Epic πρέσβηες Hes.

Hom. uses only the comp. and Sup., comp. πρεσβύτερος, α, ον, elder, older, Il., Hdt., Pind., Attic; ἐνιαυτῷ by a year, Ar.; βουλαὶ πρεσβύτεραι the wise councils of age, Pind.;—Sup. πρεσβύτατος, η, ον, eldest, Il., Hes., etc.: —the comp. and Sup. were used of things, πρεσβύτερόν τι (or οὐδὲν ἔχειν) ἔχειν = Lat. aliquid (or nihil) antiquius habere, to deem higher, more important, τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ πρεσβύτερα ποιεῖσθαι ἢ τὰ τῶν ἀνδρῶν Hdt.; πρεσβύτατον κρίνειν τι Thuc.; πρεσβυτέρως γυμναστικὴν μουσικῆς τετιμηκέναι more highly than . . , Plat.: —hence, merely of magnitude, πρεσβύτερον κακὸν κακοῦ one evil greater than another, Soph.
like πρεσβευτής, an ambassador, Aesch., Ar.;—pl. πρέσβεις is more used than πρεσβευταί, Ar., Xen., etc.
a chief, president: comp. πρεσβύτερος, an elder of the Jewish Council, NTest., etc.: an elder of the Church, presbyter, NTest.

div1.head: πρεσβυτέριον
div1.sense: a council of elders, NTest.

div1.head: πρεσβυτικός
div1.sense: like an old man, elderly, Lat. senilis, ὄχλος Ar.; κακὰ πρ. the evils of age, Ar.
old-fashioned, antiquated, Ar.:—adv. -κῶς, Plut.

div1.head: πρεσβῦτις
div1.sense: an aged woman, Aesch.

div1.head: πρευμένεια
div1.sense: gentleness of temper, graciousness, Eur.

div1.head: πρευμενής
div1.sense: poet. adj. gentle of mood, friendly, gracious, favourable, Aesch., Eur.:—adv. -νῶς, Aesch.
propitiatory, Aesch.

div1.head: πρηγορεών
div1.sense: the crop of birds, Ar.
